A market-coverage strategy in which a firm targets several market segments and designs separate offers for each is known as:
  • A.Differentiated Market Segmentation
  • B.Undifferentiated Market Segmentation
  • C.Target Market
  • D.Micromarketing
Correct Answer: Differentiated Market Segmentation

Targeting strategies for Marketing are:

Differentiated (segmented) Marketing: A market-coverage strategy in which a firm targets several market segments and designs separate offers for

each.

Undifferentiated (mass) Marketing: A market-coverage strategy in which a firm decides to ignore market segment differences and go after the whole market with one offer.

Target market: A set of buyers who share common needs or characteristics that a company decides to serve.

Micromarketing: Tailoring products and marketing programs to the needs and wants of specific individuals and local customer segments; it includes local marketing and individual marketing.

Local marketing: Tailoring brands and marketing to the needs and wants of local customer segments—cities, neighbourhoods, and even specific stores.

Question 66
Differentiation approaches such as competence, courtesy, reliability, and responsiveness are forms of:
  • A.Product differentiation
  • B.Relationship differentiation
  • C.Image differentiation
  • D.Service differentiation
Correct Answer: Relationship differentiation

The correct answer is (B) Relationship differentiation.

 

There are many ways to differentiate in marketing, in order to gain competitive advantage.

a) Product Differentiation - It includes actual physical and perceived differences, of which the latter can be acquired through advertising. Product differentiation may take the form of features, performance, efficacy (or the ability of the product to do what it is purported to do), meeting specifications, or a number of other criteria.

 

b) Service Differentiation - Differentiation of service includes not only delivery and customer service, but all other supporting elements of a business such as training, installation, and ease of ordering.

 

c) Distribution Differentiation - Channels of distribution can also be an effective means of differentiation. Distribution can provide coverage or availability, immediate access to expertise, and greater ease of ordering, and higher levels of customer or technical service.

 

d) Relationship Differentiation - This differentiation is closely related to service, but focuses specifically on the people. Building this relationship takes time, but establishes a highly differentiated position. Employees, associates, or team members with customer interface can provide and demonstrate competence, courtesy, credibility, reliability, and responsiveness.

 

e) Image/Reputation Differentiation - Some businesses set themselves apart by their image either as part of another differentiation avenue or as a separate strategic path. Image is controlled and managed by symbols used in communications, advertising, and all types of media — written, digital, and audio, as well as the atmosphere of the physical place where customers encounter the business.

 

f) Price Differentiation - Price differentiation (or discrimination) recognizes that the value of goods is subjective, which varies by customer, use occasion, and operating environment. Successfully competing on price requires recognition that every customer has a different price they would be willing to pay for your product. Segmentation and differentiation allows a business to come close to maximizing the potential revenue by offering each segment a differentiated product at a different price.

Question 67
The ______ refers to the aggregating of prospective buyers into groups with common needs and who respond similarly to a marketing action.
  • A.Market Targeting
  • B.Market Positioning
  • C.Market Segmentation
  • D.Market Strategy
Correct Answer: Market Segmentation

The correct answer is (C) Market Segmentation.

 

Market segmentation is the process of aggregating prospective buyers into groups or segments with common needs and characteristics. These segments are defined based on factors such as demographics, psychographics, behavior, and other relevant criteria. The goal of market segmentation is to better understand and reach specific customer groups with tailored marketing strategies and messages.

Question 68
Which one of the following statements is true according to VALS framework of Psychographic segmentation? (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.The consumers who are primarily motivated by ideals are guided by knowledge and principles.
  • B.The consumers who are motivated by achievement look for knowledge and principles.
  • C.The consumers who are motivated by self-expression don’t desire social or physical activity, variety, and risk.
  • D.The consumers who are motivated by achievement desire social or physical activity, variety, and risk.
Correct Answer: The consumers who are primarily motivated by ideals are guided by knowledge and principles.

The VALS Research by social scientist Arnold Mitchell. Values and Lifestyles (VALS) has been extensively used for Psychographic segmentation. VALS was developed from the theoretical base of Maslow’s hierarchy of needs and the concept of social character. According to it, there are two concepts that are critical for understanding the target consumers:

(a) Primary motivation (horizontal dimension) includes three motivations that explain consumer attitude:

1. Ideals

2. Achievement

3. Self-expression.

 

(b) Resources (vertical dimension)

A person's tendency to consume goes beyond age, income, gender or education. Certain psychological traits like energy, intellectualism, self-confidence in conjunction with key demographics determine an individual's resources.

 

Determined on this basis, there are 8 VALS types which are used to study a customer:

1. Innovators: successful, sophisticated, abundant resources, exhibit all three primary motivations

2. Experiencers: young, enthusiastic, impulse buyers

3. Thinkers: mature, satisfied, well-educated, seek out information in decision making process

4. Achievers: goal-oriented lifestyle, deep commitment to family and career

5. Believers: conservative, conventional, follow established codes

6. Strivers: fun-loving, trendy, seek approval of others, money defines success

7. Makers: enough energy and skill to carry out their projects themselves

8. Survivors: narrowly-focused lives, few resources

Question 69
Which of the following is not a method of segmenting a market? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.Behavioural segmentation
  • B.Psychographic segmentation
  • C.Benefits segmentation
  • D.Customer segmentation
Correct Answer: Customer segmentation

The correct answer is (D) Customer segmentation.

 

Customer segmentation is not typically considered a distinct method of segmenting a market. Instead, customer segmentation is a broader concept that encompasses various methods and criteria, such as behavioral, psychographic, and benefits segmentation, among others. Customer segmentation involves dividing a market into groups of customers based on different characteristics or behaviors to better understand and target them effectively.

Question 70
A method for achieving maximum market response from limited marketing resources by reorganizing differences in the response characteristics of various parts of the market is known as: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.Market targeting
  • B.Market positioning
  • C.Market segmentation
  • D.Market strategy
Correct Answer: Market segmentation

The correct answer is (C) Market segmentation.

 

Market segmentation is a method for achieving maximum market response from limited marketing resources by reorganizing differences in the response characteristics of various parts of the market. It involves dividing the overall market into distinct segments or groups based on common characteristics or behaviors. Once segmented, a company can tailor its marketing efforts to each segment to optimize its response and effectiveness in reaching different parts of the market.

Question 71
In order to be useful, market segments must have each of the following characteristics except: (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Accessibility
  • B.Adaptability
  • C.Measurability
  • D.Substantiality
Correct Answer: Adaptability

The correct answer is (B) Adaptability.

 

To be useful, market segments must possess specific characteristics that help businesses effectively target their marketing efforts and resources. These characteristics ensure that customers are more likely to identify and purchase the right products or services, and they minimize the wastage of resources by reducing the time spent marketing to the wrong customers. The key characteristics used to measure market segments are as follows:

 

Measurable: Market segments are typically measured in terms of sales value or volume, such as the number of customers within the segment. Reliable market research should provide a reasonably accurate assessment of the segment's size, allowing strategists to decide how and to what extent they should focus their marketing efforts on that segment.

 

Substantial: It's crucial that a market segment is sufficiently large and has significant spending power. A viable market segment is usually a homogeneous group with clearly defined characteristics, such as age group, socio-economic background, and brand perception. It should also have longevity, ensuring that the segment remains stable and doesn't disperse or change significantly within a short period.

 

Accessible: When defining a market segment, it's important to consider how the group can be accessed and whether this aligns with the strengths and capabilities of the company's marketing department. Different segments may respond better to various marketing approaches, such as outdoor advertising, social media campaigns, or television infomercials.

 

Differentiable: An ideal market segment should be internally homogeneous, meaning that customers within the segment share similar preferences and characteristics. However, they should also be externally heterogeneous, meaning that differences between market segments are clearly defined. This differentiation allows businesses to tailor their marketing strategies without overlap.

 

Actionable: The market segment must have practical value. Its characteristics should provide data that supports a marketing position or sales approach. Additionally, the outcomes of these strategies should be easily quantifiable, ideally in relation to the initial measurements of the segment as defined through market research.

Question 72
Market sub-divided on the basis of behavioural characteristics is termed as: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)
  • A.Segmentation
  • B.Aggregation
  • C.Precision
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Segmentation

The correct answer is (A) Segmentation.

 

Market sub-division based on behavioral characteristics is termed as market segmentation. It involves dividing the market into distinct segments or groups based on observable behaviors, such as purchasing patterns, product usage, brand loyalty, or other behavioral traits. This segmentation allows businesses to tailor their marketing strategies and messages to specific groups with similar behavioral characteristics.

Question 73
The most important Retail marketing decision a retailer has to make is to: (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.select the product assortment.
  • B.identify its target market.
  • C.choose the desired service level.
  • D.develop an effective store atmosphere.
Correct Answer: identify its target market.

The correct answer is (B) identify its target market.

 

One of the most crucial retail marketing decisions a retailer has to make is identifying its target market. Understanding the specific customer segment or audience that the retailer aims to serve is fundamental to making informed decisions about product assortment, service level, store atmosphere, and all other aspects of retail strategy. Once the target market is well-defined, the retailer can tailor its offerings and marketing efforts to meet the needs and preferences of that specific group of customers effectively.

Question 74
Straddle Positioning uses: (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)(a) Point of parity(b) Point of differenceCodes:
  • A.(a) only
  • B.(b) only
  • C.Both (a) and (b)
  • D.Neither (a) nor (b)
Correct Answer: Both (a) and (b)

The correct answer is (C) Both (a) and (b).

 

Straddle positioning involves using both points of parity (PoP) and points of difference (PoD) in a company's positioning strategy. Points of parity are characteristics or attributes that a brand shares with its competitors and are considered essential to be considered a legitimate player in the market. Points of difference, on the other hand, are unique attributes or benefits that distinguish a brand from its competitors.

 

In straddle positioning, a brand strategically combines elements of both PoP and PoD to appeal to a broad range of customers. This approach acknowledges the importance of being competitive in terms of essential attributes (PoP) while also highlighting what makes the brand unique (PoD).

Question 75
Match the following. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)List – I(a) Geographic Segmentation(b) Demographic Segmentation(c) Psychographic Segmentation(d) Behavioral SegmentationList – II(i) Gender, income, religion(ii) Knowledge, attitude, response(iii) Regions, cities, neighborhoods(iv) Lifestyle, personality traits, valuesCodes:
  • A.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(iii) d-(i)
  • B.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(ii)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(ii)

A market can be segmented on the basis of the following variables:

1. Geographic Segmentation: The characteristics of customers often differ across nations, states, regions cities or neighborhoods. The marketer can decide to operate in one or a few or all the geographic areas, but pay attention to differences in geographic needs and preferences.

2. Demographic Segmentation: Variables such as age, sex, family size, income, occupation, education, religion, race and nationality are widely used for market segmentation.

3. Psychological Variables: Personality, life style, social class, value, etc. can also be used for market segmentation. For example, some products like pens, watches, cosmetics and briefcases are designed differently for common men and status seekers.

4. Behavioural Segmentation: Buyers are divided into groups on the basis of their knowledge, attitude, use or response to a product.

Question 76
Target marketing involves which of the following activities? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)(a) Market positioning(b) Market targeting(c) Market behavior(d) Market segmentationCodes
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(b) and (d)
  • C.(a), (b) and (d)
  • D.(b), (c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (d)

The correct answer is (C) (a), (b), and (d).

 

Target marketing involves the following activities:

 

(a) Market positioning: This is the process of creating a distinctive image or identity for a product or brand in the minds of the target audience. It defines how a product is perceived relative to competitors in the market.

 

(b) Market targeting: This refers to the process of selecting specific segments of the market as target audiences for a company's products or services. It involves identifying and focusing on the most relevant and profitable customer groups.

 

(d) Market segmentation: This is the process of dividing the overall market into distinct segments or groups based on common characteristics, behaviors, or needs. It is the foundation for effective target marketing.

Question 77
Which of the following Positioning Strategies is adopted by marketers to position their product in 2 categories simultaneously? UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.Point of Difference
  • B.Point of Parity
  • C.Straddle Positioning
  • D.Emotional Positioning
Correct Answer: Straddle Positioning

The correct answer is (C) Straddle Positioning.

 

Straddle positioning is a strategy adopted by marketers to position their product in two categories simultaneously. This strategy aims to appeal to a broad range of customers by emphasizing both points of difference (unique features or benefits) and points of parity (similarities with competitors) in the product's positioning. Straddle positioning allows a product to occupy a unique space in consumers' minds while also being seen as competitive and relevant in multiple categories or segments.

Question 78
Your firm is attempting to divide up the total market to determine the best segments it can serve. Which is the correct order of doing so? (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)
  • A.market segmentation, target marketing, market positioning
  • B.target marketing, market positioning, market segmentation
  • C.market positioning, market segmentation, target marketing
  • D.mass marketing, demographic segmentation, psychographic segmentation
Correct Answer: market segmentation, target marketing, market positioning

The correct order of the process for dividing up the total market is (A) market segmentation, target marketing, market positioning.

 

Market Segmentation: The first step involves dividing the total market into distinct segments based on common characteristics, behaviors, or needs. This helps in identifying different groups of potential customers with similar traits.

 

Target Marketing: After segmenting the market, the next step is to select one or more specific segments (target markets) that the firm intends to focus its marketing efforts on. Target marketing involves choosing the most suitable customer groups for the company's products or services.

 

Market Positioning: Once the target market(s) have been identified, the firm works on creating a distinctive image or position for its product or brand in the minds of the selected target audience. Market positioning defines how the product is perceived relative to competitors and communicates its unique value.

Question 79
A company plans to create the largest possible total sales volume. It should use: (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Concentrated marketing
  • B.Differentiated marketing
  • C.Homogeneous marketing
  • D.Undifferentiated marketing
Correct Answer: Differentiated marketing

The correct answer is (B) Differentiated marketing.

 

Through segmentation, a firm divides the market into many segments. But all these segments need not form its target market. Target market signifies only those segments that it wants to adopt as its market. A selection is thus involved in it.

 

There are 5 patterns of target market selection, which was first put forward by D. F. Abell:

a) Single-segment concentration: The marketer decides to cater to a single segment only. Also referred to as "concentrated marketing". Example: Rolex watches. The advantages of single-segment concentration are lower costs of production, distribution and promotion. But here sales volume will not be maximum as we are not catering to whole market.

 

b) Selective specialization or Multi-segment: The marketer caters to two or a few segments with different marketing mixes. Examples: Maruti Suzuki cars, soaps and detergents from Procter and Gamble, Tata Group of Hotels. The advantages of selective specialization are that when the marketer caters to different segments, he can expand and achieve economies of scale and operation and gain out of existing synergies between production, operations and marketing functions. Still, not good for highest sales volume.

 

c) Product specialization: Here, the marketer deals with varying products in the same product line; it adapts the product to sell to several different market segments. Example: Gillette. The advantage of this pattern is that when the marketer caters to different segments, with a single product or varying forms of the same product, he can develop specialization and reputation in that product line.

 

d) Market Specialization: The marketer deals with one specific market only; he tries to meet many needs of a particular customer group. Example: The various Ordinance Factories in India exist to cater to meet the various needs of the Defense forces only. The advantage of this pattern is that in case of a monopolistic situation, the marketer has lot of potential to grow; he would exist to serve the need and wants of the segment.

 

e) Full market coverage: Here the marketer caters to the entire market. A full market coverage could assume two forms, differentiated and undifferentiated. In the differentiated form, the marketer would operate in the whole market and offer different products for the various segments. Thus, capturing highest sales volume as they have something to everyone. Example: IBM, HP. The undifferentiated form is also known as mass marketing. Here, the marketer offers a single product to every segment. This may not generate the highest volume as segments with different needs will not buy the same product.

Question 80
Consider the following Statements(UGC NET Management Dec 2014)1. The ultimate level of market segmentation leads to “one-to-one” marketing.2. Any attempt to target marketing to children or minorities is discriminatory and unethical.3. The internet as a medium of adverting has high selectivity and cost.4. A ‘Push’ strategy is better suited for directing the marketing effort towards final consumers.Indicate the correct answer:
  • A.Statements 1 and 4 are true and others are not.
  • B.Statements 1 and 2 are true and others are not.
  • C.Statement 1 is true and other are not.
  • D.All Statements are false.
Correct Answer: Statements 1 and 4 are true and others are not.

The correct answer is (A) Statements 1 and 4 are true, and others are not.

 

The ultimate level of market segmentation leads to “one-to-one” marketing

This statement is true. The ultimate level of market segmentation aims at creating highly personalized marketing efforts where products or services are tailored to individual customers. This is often referred to as "one-to-one" marketing, where each customer's unique preferences and needs are taken into account.

 

Any attempt to target marketing to children or minorities is discriminatory and unethical

This statement is not universally true. While ethical considerations are essential in marketing, targeting specific demographic groups, including children or minorities, is not inherently discriminatory or unethical. The ethicality of such targeting depends on factors like the context, the nature of the products or services, and how the marketing is conducted.

 

The internet as a medium of advertising has high selectivity and cost

This statement is not necessarily true. The internet as an advertising medium can offer high selectivity, allowing advertisers to reach specific target audiences effectively. However, the cost of advertising on the internet can vary widely depending on factors such as the chosen platform, advertising methods, and competition.

 

A ‘Push’ strategy is better suited for directing the marketing effort towards final consumers

This statement is true. A "Push" marketing strategy involves actively pushing a product or service directly to the end consumer through various promotional tactics. It is often used when the target audience is the final consumer, and the goal is to create demand at the point of purchase.

Question 81
Which of the following condition is true about determinants and strengths of Positioning strategy? (UGC NET Management Sep 2013)
  • A.There should be competition warranting positioning.
  • B.The market segment to be served should be sizeable and profitable.
  • C.The market segment should be able to effectively receive communication messages transmitted by the company.
  • D.All of these.
Correct Answer: All of these.

The correct answer is (D) All of these.

 

1. Design creative product proposition: Product proposition means the benefits accruing from the use of the product. The proposition to be perceived by the consumers is one that is desired by the firm proposing. The results of positioning are increased satisfaction to the users and profits to the sellers through increased sales. The product proposal should be creative, impressing and appealing than those of competitors.

 

2. Existence of warranted competition: The positioning strategy is likely to be victorious in case there is competition warranting product positioning. Product positioning or repositioning is always done in response to the product positioning or repositioning done by competitors. So, if there is no competition then there is no need for positioning.

 

3. Sizeable and profitable market segment: Market segments must be large enough to make it profitable for a manufacturer or marketer to concentrate his resources on such as market.

 

4. Sensitive market segment: A sensitive market segment is one that receives the communication message transmitted by the company and reacts to it. That is, a segment should make differential response to the marketing efforts put in by the company.

 

5. Adequate consumer behaviour information: Product positioning presupposes the availability of adequate, detailed and up-to-date information regarding the consumers, especially their behaviour.

Question 82
Assertion “A”:A company’s Positioning and Differentiation strategy must change over the Product life cycle.Reason “R”:A company’s product, market and competitors change over the Product life cycle.
  • A.A is correct, but R is incorrect.
  • B.A is incorrect but R is correct.
  • C.Both A and R are correct, but R is not the right explanation of A
  • D.Both A and R are correct, and R is the right explanation of A
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct, and R is the right explanation of A

The correct answer is (D) Both A and R are correct, and R is the right explanation of A.

 

Assertion (A) states that a company's positioning and differentiation strategy must change over the product life cycle. This is correct because as a product moves through its life cycle stages (introduction, growth, maturity, and decline), the market dynamics, customer preferences, and competitive landscape change. Therefore, adapting the positioning and differentiation strategy is necessary to remain competitive and meet evolving customer needs.

 

Reason (R) states that a company's product, market, and competitors change over the product life cycle. This is also correct because as a product matures, market conditions change, new competitors may enter, and customer preferences may shift. These changes require adjustments to the company's strategy.

Question 83
The Coca Cola Company markets a wide range of different beverage products including bottled water, soft-drinks, juices and sports drinks. Each product appeals to a different segment. This is an example of which type of market offering?
  • A.Differentiated marketing
  • B.Target marketing
  • C.Undifferentiated marketing
  • D.Intensified marketing
Correct Answer: Differentiated marketing

The correct answer is (A) Differentiated marketing.

 

Differentiated Marketing- If a firm decides to target several or all segments of the market, it is engaging in a differentiated marketing strategy. Under a differentiated marketing strategy, a firm will develop products and services with separate marketing mix strategies for each of the segments chosen by the firm.

 

Other types of marketing are given below:

Undifferentiated or Mass Marketing- Undifferentiated marketing is marketing that does not target a particular segment of the market. Instead the firm adopts one marketing strategy and hopes that it will appeal to as many people as possible. For instance, Coca Cola's original marketing strategy was based on this format when they offered one product. However now that Coca Cola has introduced other products and has changed its marketing strategy to differentiated marketing.

 

Concentrated or Niche Marketing- Concentrated marketing occurs when a business concentrates its marketing effort on large share of one/few segments of the market. The firm will develop a product that caters for the needs of that particular group. For example, Rolls Royce cars and the Harrods Group target the premium segment of the market.

Question 84
Before a company decides to target a particular market segment, which important factors are to be examined against organization’s objectives and resources?
  • A.Market size
  • B.Growth rate
  • C.Structural attractiveness
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The correct answer is (D) All of the above.

 

Before a company decides to target a particular market segment, it is essential to examine various important factors against the organization's objectives and resources. These factors include:

 

Market Size- Market size is the number of individuals in a certain market segment who are potential buyers. Companies should determine market size before launching a new product or service.

 

Growth Rate- Market Growth rate is defined as the rise in sales or market size within a given customer base over a specific period of time. When a business analyses its market it requires interpreting its market growth rate. The sales growth is compared with the market growth rate.

 

Structural Attractiveness- Porter's five forces defined whether an industry is attractive or unattractive from the perspective of a company competing in that industry. Porter's 5 forces of competition provide an excellent method to consider an industry before entrance. An attractive industry is one which offers the potential for profitability.

Question 85
What is the term used if a market is divided into distinct groups of buyers who might require separate products or marketing mixes? (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Market Targeting
  • B.Market Positioning
  • C.Market Segmentation
  • D.Market Co-ordination
Correct Answer: Market Segmentation

The correct answer is (C) Market Segmentation.

 

Market segmentation is the process of dividing a market into distinct groups of buyers who share similar characteristics, needs, or behaviors. This segmentation allows businesses to tailor their marketing strategies and offerings to better meet the specific needs and preferences of each segment, ultimately improving their chances of success in the market.

Question 86
A Positioning strategy should include the following strategies except: (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Product strategy
  • B.Personnel strategy
  • C.Promotion strategy
  • D.Advertising strategy
Correct Answer: Personnel strategy

The correct answer is (B) Personnel strategy.

 

Positioning strategy primarily focuses on creating a distinct image and perception of a product or brand in the minds of the target audience. It involves aspects such as product features and benefits (Product strategy), how the product is promoted (Promotion strategy), and how it's communicated to the audience (Advertising strategy). However, it typically does not include personnel strategy, which deals with human resource management and development within an organization.

Question 87
Which of the variables is NOT used by marketers for demographic segmentation? (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Age
  • B.Income
  • C.Gender
  • D.Poverty
Correct Answer: Poverty

The correct answer is (D) Poverty.

 

In demographic segmentation, marketers use various demographic variables to divide the market into segments based on specific characteristics of the population. These variables include age, income, gender, education level, occupation, marital status, family size, and more. However, "poverty" is not typically used as a demographic variable for market segmentation. It is an economic and social condition rather than a specific demographic characteristic.

Question 88
Which segmentation approach is the most compatible with the spirit of the marketing concept? (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Benefit sought
  • B.Income
  • C.Social class
  • D.Family size
Correct Answer: Benefit sought

The correct answer is (A) Benefit sought.

 

The segmentation approach that is most compatible with the spirit of the marketing concept is "Benefit sought." This approach focuses on understanding and categorizing consumers based on the specific benefits or value they seek from a product or service. It aligns well with the marketing concept, which emphasizes understanding and fulfilling customer needs and preferences to provide value and satisfaction. By identifying the benefits that different segments of consumers seek, marketers can tailor their marketing strategies and offerings to meet those specific needs effectively.

Question 89
Product Positioning is the process by which marketers try to create?
  • A.the identity of the product
  • B.the image of the product
  • C.both A and B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: both A and B

The correct answer is (C) Both A and B.

 

Product positioning is the process in which marketers aim to create and establish the identity and image of a product in the minds of the target audience. It involves shaping how consumers perceive the product, its unique features, benefits, and overall value. Therefore, both (A) the identity of the product and (B) the image of the product are accurate descriptions of what marketers try to create through product positioning.

Question 90
Statement I:The firm should “stick to its niching” but not necessarily to its niche. (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)Statement II:Multiple niching is not preferable to single niching.Codes:
  • A.Both the Statements are true.
  • B.Both the Statements are false.
  • C.Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement II is true, but Statement I is false
Correct Answer: Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.

The correct answer is (C) Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.

 

Statement I: "The firm should 'stick to its niching' but not necessarily to its niche."

This statement suggests that a firm should adhere to the strategy of focusing on a niche market, but it is not necessary to limit itself to a single niche. This is true as a firm can have variations or expansions within a broader niche strategy to adapt to changing market dynamics and consumer needs.

 

Statement II: "Multiple niching is not preferable to single niching."

This statement implies that having multiple niches is not preferable and that it's better to focus on a single niche. This is false as having multiple niches can diversify a firm's market presence, reduce risk associated with a single niche, and allow for growth opportunities in different market segments.

Question 91
When a company treats each single customer as a separate segment, this is called: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.Niche Marketing
  • B.Nano Marketing
  • C.Single Marketing
  • D.Micro Marketing
Correct Answer: Micro Marketing

The correct answer is (D) Micro Marketing.

 

Micro Marketing is the practice of tailoring products and marketing programs according to the needs and wants of specific individuals or local customer groups. It includes Local Marketing and Individual Marketing. Individual marketing is also called One to One Marketing or Customized Marketing.

 

Niche Marketing: Niche is a more narrowly defined group, typically a small market whose needs are not being well served. Marketers usually identify niches by dividing a segment into sub-segments or by defining a group seeking a distinctive mix of benefits.

 

Single marketing, also known as concentrated strategy, involves concentrating all your efforts in a single segment with a single marketing mix. Such a strategy is usually chosen by small companies which have limited resources in order to avoid confrontation with larger companies. They find a niche in the market and devote their energies to serving that market.

 

Question 92
International markets can be segmented on the basis of which factors?
  • A.Geographic
  • B.Economical
  • C.Cultural
  • D.All
Correct Answer: All

International markets can be segmented based on following factors:

(i) Geographical: grouping countries by regions such as Western Europe, the Pacific Rim, the Middle East, or Africa.

(ii) Economical: Countries might be grouped by population income levels or by their overall level of economic development.

(iii) Cultural: grouping markets according to common languages, religions, values and attitudes, customs, and behavioural patterns.

(iv) Political and legal: grouping based on the type and stability of government, receptivity to foreign firms, monetary regulations, and amount of bureaucracy.

Question 93
Marketers often prepare __________ that show consumer perceptions of their brands versus competing products on important buying dimensions.
  • A.Perpetual positioning maps
  • B.Perceptual positioning maps
  • C.Performance positioning maps
  • D.Brand positioning maps
Correct Answer: Perceptual positioning maps

The correct answer is (B) Perceptual positioning maps.

 

Perceptual positioning maps, also known as perceptual maps, are graphical representations that marketers use to illustrate and visualize consumer perceptions of their brands and competing products on various important buying dimensions. These maps help in understanding how consumers perceive different brands in relation to each other and identify the positioning of brands in the minds of consumers based on specific attributes or criteria.

Question 94
When a firm has diversified in unrelated products, it is called(UGC NET Management Sep 2013)
  • A.Scramble diversification
  • B.Related diversification
  • C.Product mix
  • D.Product line simplification
Correct Answer: Scramble diversification

The correct answer is (A) Scramble diversification. A situation that occurs when a retail business offers a mix of unrelated products that do not reflect the company's original focus. Scrambled merchandising often reflects a scattered product management approach and can make a negative impression on consumers since they might not be sure what sort of products the retailer offers.

 

Related Diversification - A process that takes place when a business expands its activities into product lines that are similar to those it currently offers. For example, a manufacturer of computers might begin making calculators as a form of related diversification of its existing business.

 

Product Mix- Product mix, also known as product assortment, refers to the total number of product lines that a company offers to its customers. For example, a small company may sell multiple lines of products. Sometimes, these product lines are fairly similar, such as dish washing liquid and bar soap, which are used for cleaning and use similar technologies. Other times, the product lines are vastly different, such as diapers and razors. The four dimensions to a company's product mix include width, length, depth and consistency.

 

Product line simplification- Product simplification is achieved by product elimination or termination. Product simplification and product diversification are opposite to each other. Product diversification is done in two ways – by adding a product to an existing product line and by creating an additional product line.

Question 95
A positioning error referring to too narrow a picture of the company, its product or a brand being communicated to target customers is known as:
  • A.Under positioning
  • B.Over positioning
  • C.Implausible positioning
  • D.Confused positioning
Correct Answer: Over positioning

The correct answer is (B) Over positioning.

 

Over Positioning- A positioning error referring to too narrow a picture of the company, its product or a brand being communicated to target customers.

 

Under Positioning- A positioning error referring to failure to position a company, its product or brand.

 

Confused Positioning- A positioning error that leaves consumers with a confused image of the company, its product or a brand.

 

Implausible Positioning- Making claims that stretch the perception of the buyers too far to be believed.

Question 96
___________ consists of group of customers who share a similar set of needs and wants.
  • A.Customer Segment
  • B.Market Segment
  • C.Target Market
  • D.Target Customers
Correct Answer: Market Segment

The correct answer is (B) Market Segment.

 

A market segment consists of a group of customers who share a similar set of needs, wants, preferences, or characteristics. These similarities enable businesses to create targeted marketing strategies and offerings to effectively meet the specific demands and requirements of that particular group, enhancing their chances of success in the market.

 

Question 97
Which of the following is NOT a major segmentation variable?(i) Geographic Segmentation(ii) Psychographic Segmentation(iii) Physiographic Segmentation(iv) Behavioral Segmentation(v) Demographic SegmentationSelect the correct option:
  • A.(ii)
  • B.(iii)
  • C.(iv)
  • D.(i)
Correct Answer: (iii)

The correct answer is (B) (iii) Physiographic Segmentation.

 

Physiographic segmentation is not a standard and recognized segmentation variable in marketing. The typical major segmentation variables used in marketing are:

(i) Geographic Segmentation

(ii) Psychographic Segmentation

(iii) Behavioral Segmentation

(iv) Demographic Segmentation

Question 98
The segmentation in which market is divided into units such as nation, states, regions, cities or neighborhoods in known as
  • A.Demographic segmentation
  • B.Area segmentation
  • C.Geographic segmentation
  • D.Topographic segmentation
Correct Answer: Geographic segmentation

The correct answer is (C) Geographic segmentation.

 

Geographic segmentation is the segmentation strategy in which a market is divided into units such as nations, states, regions, cities, or neighborhoods based on geographical factors. This type of segmentation recognizes that consumer needs, preferences, and buying behaviors can vary based on their location or geographic location. Marketers use geographic segmentation to tailor their marketing strategies to the specific characteristics and demands of consumers in different geographical areas.

 

Question 99
_________ is a type of marketing in which the marketing activities concentrate on getting as close and personally relevant to individual customers as possible
  • A.Fundamental marketing
  • B.Essential marketing
  • C.Relationship marketing
  • D.Grassroots marketing
Correct Answer: Grassroots marketing

The correct answer is (D) Grassroots marketing.

 

Grassroots marketing is a type of marketing where the focus of marketing activities is on getting as close and personally relevant to individual customers as possible. It involves establishing a direct and personalized connection with customers, often at a local or individual level, to build relationships and enhance the effectiveness of marketing efforts. This approach aims to engage customers in a meaningful way, tailoring marketing strategies to meet their specific needs and preferences.

Question 100
Nielsen Claritas has developed a geoclustering approach called PRIZM, which stands for:
  • A.Potential Rating Index for Zip Markets
  • B.Probability Rating Index for Zonal Markets
  • C.Personal Rating Index for Zip Markets
  • D.Plausible Rating Index for Zonal Markets
Correct Answer: Potential Rating Index for Zip Markets

PRIZM stands for Potential Rating Index for Zip Markets, and is built around geographic neighborhood data obtained through the United States Census.

 

It assumes that similar households in the same neighbourhood share similar characteristics such as demographic data (age, race, education level, marital status, etc., and variables such as lifestyle, attitudes, and behaviors. PRIZM works by assigning all households in each neighbourhood to a neighbourhood group. Households are grouped into one of 68 demographic and behavioral segments. Here are a few examples:

(a) Group 01: Upper Crust - Wealthy, mature without kids

(b) Group 68: Bedrock America - Low-income middle age, mostly without kids

 

Census data helps to form these PRIZM groups using neighborhood types, social rank, household composition, mobility, ethnicity, urbanization, and housing. The system assumes that people with similar cultural backgrounds, needs and ideas gravitate toward one another, and live in neighborhoods that offer affordable advantages and compatible lifestyles. By understanding and grouping households in this manner, marketers are able to take advantage of the data to identify and implement marketing opportunities and strategies.

 

Question 101
Which of the following is NOT a variable for Demographic Segmentation?
  • A.Generation
  • B.Nationality
  • C.Nation
  • D.Family life cycle
Correct Answer: Nation

The correct answer is (C) Nation.

 

Demographic segmentation typically includes variables related to characteristics such as age, gender, income, education, occupation, family size, and family life cycle. "Nation" is not a standard demographic variable used in segmentation because it refers to the country or geographic location of individuals, which is typically considered separately under geographic segmentation. Demographic segmentation focuses on individual and household characteristics rather than the broader geographic context.

 

Question 102
Consumer wants and abilities change with age and to deal with such changes, marketers use which variable for demographic segmentation?
  • A.Race and culture
  • B.Generation
  • C.Income
  • D.Age and life cycle
Correct Answer: Age and life cycle

The correct answer is (D) Age and life cycle.

 

Consumer wants and abilities often change with age, and to address these changes, marketers frequently use the variable of "Age and life cycle" for demographic segmentation. This approach recognizes that different age groups have varying needs, preferences, and purchasing behaviors, and it helps marketers tailor their strategies and offerings accordingly.

Question 103
Statement I:Income does not always predict the best customers for a given product.Statement II:Marketers are deliberately going after lower-income groups, in some cases discovering fewer competitive pressures or greater consumer loyalty.Select the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (A) Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: "Income does not always predict the best customers for a given product."

This statement is accurate because although income is a crucial factor in understanding consumer behavior and purchasing power, it's not the sole determinant of who the best customers for a particular product are. Consumers' preferences, needs, values, lifestyle, demographics, and psychographics are also vital considerations. For example, two individuals with similar incomes might have different preferences for products or brands based on their personal tastes or lifestyle choices.

 

Statement II: "Marketers are deliberately going after lower-income groups, in some cases discovering fewer competitive pressures or greater consumer loyalty."

This statement is correct. Marketers often target lower-income groups strategically for various reasons. In some cases, there might be less competition in these segments compared to higher-income segments, providing marketers with an opportunity to capture a larger market share. Additionally, lower-income consumers may exhibit greater loyalty to certain brands or products, making them an attractive target for marketers aiming to build long-term customer relationships. Hence, marketers carefully consider different market segments, including lower-income groups, based on their specific marketing objectives and the competitive landscape.

Question 104
Match the following. (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)List I(a) Gen Y(b) Gen X(c) Baby Boomers(d) Silent GenerationList II(i) largely in the prime of their consumption cycle, they embrace products and lifestyles that allow them to turn back the hands of time.(ii) Raised with relative affluence, tech savvy and concerned with the environment and social issues.(iii) Defy their advancing age, they maintain active lives and products and marketing that help them to achieve that.(iv) Bridge the technological savvy of Gen Y with the adult realities of the baby boomers.Choose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)

Market can also be segmented between Generation. Each generation or cohort is profoundly influenced by the times in which it grows up—the music, movies, politics, and defining events of that period. Members share the same major cultural, political, and economic experiences and have similar outlooks and values. Marketers often advertise to a cohort by using the icons and images prominent in its experiences.

 

Millennials (or Gen Y): Born between 1979 and 1994. Also known as, the Echo Boomers, these consumers are tech savvy almost from birth. They have a sense of entitlement and abundance from growing up during the economic boom. Yet they are highly socially conscious and concerned about environmental issues. They are selective, confident, and impatient. Because Gen Y members are often turned off by overt branding practices and “hard sell,” marketers have tried many different approaches to reach and persuade them, like creating online buzz, promoting unconventional sports, organizing cool events etc.

 

Gen X: Gen X consumers were born between 1964 and 1978. They were raised in more challenging times, when corporate downsizing led to the threat of layoffs and economic uncertainty. Although Gen Xers created new norms in educational achievement, they were also the first generation to find surpassing their parents’ standard of living a serious challenge. Technology is an enabler for them, not a barrier. As consumers, they are wary of hype and pitches that seem inauthentic or patronizing. Direct appeals where value is clear often works best, especially as Gen Xers become parents raising families. They bridge the technological savvy of Gen Y with the adult realities of the baby boomers.

 

Baby Boomers: They were born between 1946 and 1964. Though they represent a wealthy target, marketers often overlook them. In network television circles, because advertisers are primarily interested in 18 to 49 year-olds, viewers over 50 are referred to as “undesirables.” Contrary to conventional marketing wisdom that brand preferences of consumers over 50 are fixed, one study found 52 percent of boomers are willing to change brands, in line with the total population. Largely in the prime of their consumption cycle, they embrace products and lifestyles that allow them to turn back the hands of time.

 

Silent Generation: Those born between 1925 and 1945—the “Silent Generation”—are redefining what old age means. To start with, many people whose chronological age puts them in this category don’t see themselves as old. Emphasizing their roles as grandparents is universally well-received. Many older consumers not only happily spend time with their grandkids, they often provide for their basic needs or at least occasional gifts. For example, the founders of eBeanstalk.com, which sells children’s learning toys online, thought their business would be largely driven by young consumers starting families. They were surprised to find that up to 40 percent of their customers were older consumers, mainly grandparents. These customers are very demanding, but also more willing to pay full price than their younger counterparts. Defy their advancing age, they maintain active lives and products and marketing that help them to achieve that.

Question 105
An approach to marketing that recognizes that different ethnic and cultural segments have sufficiently different needs and wants is called
  • A.Demographic marketing
  • B.Multicultural marketing
  • C.Behavioral marketing
  • D.Regional marketing
Correct Answer: Multicultural marketing

The correct answer is (B) Multicultural marketing.

 

Multicultural marketing is an approach that recognizes and acknowledges that different ethnic and cultural segments have distinct and diverse needs, preferences, and wants. It involves tailoring marketing strategies and messages to effectively target and engage specific ethnic or cultural groups, considering their unique characteristics and behaviors. This approach helps in creating marketing campaigns that resonate with the diverse audiences in a culturally sensitive and relevant manner.

Question 106
The VALS Framework is used in which type of market segmentation?
  • A.Demographic segmentation
  • B.Multicultural segmentation
  • C.Psychographic segmentation
  • D.Behavioral segmentation
Correct Answer: Psychographic segmentation

The correct answer is (C) Psychographic segmentation.

 

The VALS Framework (Values, Attitudes, and Lifestyles) is a tool used in psychographic segmentation. Psychographic segmentation involves categorizing individuals based on their psychological and behavioral characteristics, including their values, beliefs, lifestyles, and attitudes towards products or services. VALS is a popular psychographic segmentation tool that identifies distinct consumer segments based on their psychological traits and helps in understanding consumer behavior and preferences more deeply, enabling targeted marketing strategies.

Question 107
Which of the following resource group, under the VALS framework for psychographic segmentation is matched wrongly?
  • A.Innovators – higher resource
  • B.Strivers – lower resource
  • C.Achievers – higher resource
  • D.Makers – higher resource
Correct Answer: Makers – higher resource

The main dimensions of the VALS segmentation framework are consumer motivation (the horizontal dimension) and consumer resources (the vertical dimension). Consumers are inspired by one of three primary motivations: ideals, achievement, and self-expression. Different levels of resources enhance or constrain a person’s expression of his or her primary motivation.

 

Given figure: VALS Segmentation System: An Eight Part Typology

 

The 4 groups with higher resources are:

(i) Innovators — Successful, sophisticated, active, “take-charge” people with high self-esteem. Purchases often reflect cultivated tastes for relatively upscale, niche-oriented products and services.

(ii) Thinkers — Mature, satisfied, and reflective people motivated by ideals and who value order, knowledge, and responsibility. They seek durability, functionality, and value in products.

(iii) Achievers — Successful, goal-oriented people who focus on career and family. They favor premium products that demonstrate success to their peers.

(iv) Experiencers — Young, enthusiastic, impulsive people who seek variety and excitement. They spend a comparatively high proportion of income on fashion, entertainment, and socializing.

 

The 4 groups with lower resources are:

(i) Believers — Conservative, conventional, and traditional people with concrete beliefs. They prefer familiar, native products and are loyal to established brands.

(ii) Strivers — Trendy and fun-loving people who are resource-constrained. They favor stylish products that emulate the purchases of those with greater material wealth.

(iii) Makers — Practical, down-to-earth, self-sufficient people who like to work with their hands. They seek U.S.-made products with a practical or functional purpose.

(iv) Survivors — Elderly, passive people concerned about change and loyal to their favorite brands.

 

Psychographic segmentation schemes are often customized by culture. The Japanese version of VALS divides society into 10 consumer segments on the basis of two key concepts: life orientation (traditional ways, occupations, innovation, and self-expression) and attitudes to social change (sustaining, pragmatic, adapting, and innovating).

 

Question 108
Match the following.List I(a) Enthusiast(b) Savvy Shoppers(c) Traditionalist(d) Image SeekersList II(i) like to buy brands they have heard of and from stores they purchase often.(ii) luxury enthusiasts who skew more male with a higher income.(iii) use premium products as a way to say who they are, and willing to pay more to make sure they’re getting the right product.(iv) love to shop and believe they don’t have to spend a lot to get a good product.Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)

The correct matching is (B) (ii), (iv), (i), (iii).

 

(a) Enthusiast - (ii) Luxury enthusiasts who skew more male with a higher income.

Enthusiasts are individuals who have a strong interest in luxury products and are willing to spend more on them. They often have higher incomes and are more likely to be male.

 

(b) Savvy Shoppers - (iv) Love to shop and believe they don’t have to spend a lot to get a good product.

Savvy Shoppers are value-conscious consumers who enjoy shopping and believe that they can find good products without having to spend a significant amount of money.

 

(c) Traditionalist - (i) Like to buy brands they have heard of and from stores they purchase often.

Traditionalists are consumers who prefer to stick with well-known brands and frequently shop at stores they are familiar with. They value brand recognition and consistency.

 

(d) Image Seekers - (iii) Use premium products as a way to say who they are, and willing to pay more to make sure they’re getting the right product.

Image Seekers are individuals who use premium or high-end products to express their identity and self-image. They are willing to pay extra to ensure they are associated with the right products that reflect their personal image.

Question 109
Which of the following is a variable related to various aspects of users or their usage?
  • A.Occasions
  • B.User Status
  • C.Usage Rate
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The correct answer is (D) All of the above.

 

Many marketers believe variables related to various aspects of users or their usage—occasions, user status, usage rate, buyer-readiness stage, and loyalty status—are good starting points for constructing market segments.

(i) Occasions - Occasions mark a time of day, week, month, year, or other well-defined temporal aspects of a consumer’s life. We can distinguish buyers according to the occasions when they develop a need, purchase a product, or use a product. Occasion segmentation can help expand product usage. For example, Saregama Carvaan is in high demand during Diwali season, since it used as a gifting item.

 

(ii) User Status - Every product has its nonusers, ex-users, potential users, first-time users, and regular users. For instance, Blood Banks cannot rely only on regular donors to supply blood; they must also recruit new first-time donors and contact ex-donors, each with a different marketing strategy.

 

(iii) Usage Rate - We can segment markets into light, medium, and heavy product users. Heavy users are often a small slice but account for a high percentage of total consumption. Marketers would rather attract one heavy user than several light users. A potential problem, however, is that heavy users are often either extremely loyal to one brand or never loyal to any brand and always looking for the lowest price. They also may have less room to expand their purchase and consumption.

 

(iv) Buyer-Readiness Stage - Some people are unaware of the product, some are aware, some are informed, some are interested, some desire the product, and some intend to buy. To help characterize how many people are at different stages and how well they have converted people from one stage to another, marketers can employ a marketing funnel to break down the market into different buyer-readiness stages.

 

(v) Loyalty Status - A company can learn a great deal by analyzing degrees of brand loyalty. One caution: What appear to be brand-loyal purchase patterns may reflect habit, indifference, a low price, a high switching cost, or the unavailability of other brands.

Question 110
Statement I:We cannot segment business markets with any of the same variables we use in consumer markets.Statement II:Business marketers generally identify segments through a sequential process.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (D) Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: "We cannot segment business markets with any of the same variables we use in consumer markets."

This statement is incorrect. In fact, many of the variables used for segmenting consumer markets can also be applied to segment business markets. Variables like demographics (size of the company, industry type, location), firmographics (industry, company size, revenue), behavioral patterns (buying behaviors, product usage), needs, preferences, and geographical location are some examples. While there are differences in the application and emphasis of these variables in business markets compared to consumer markets, they are still valuable for segmentation.

 

Statement II: "Business marketers generally identify segments through a sequential process."

This statement is correct. Business marketers often follow a sequential process to segment the business market effectively. This process involves steps such as identifying different criteria for segmentation (e.g., industry type, company size, geographic location), evaluating the attractiveness of each segment, selecting the most viable segments, and then developing targeted marketing strategies for each chosen segment. The process ensures that the segmentation aligns with the objectives and resources of the business.

Question 111
A flexible market offering consists of 2 parts: a ________ containing the product and service elements that all segment members value, and _______ that some segment members value.
  • A.naked solution; discretionary options
  • B.open solutions; voluntary options
  • C.bare solutions; unrestricted options
  • D.plain solutions; arbitrary options
Correct Answer: naked solution; discretionary options

The correct answer is (A) naked solution; discretionary options.

 

Naked Solution: This component represents the basic, essential elements of the product or service that are valued and required by all members within a particular market segment. It's the fundamental package or core offering that addresses the common needs and requirements of the customers in that segment.

 

Discretionary Options: These are additional features, benefits, or add-ons that are provided as options and may not be needed or valued by all segment members. Instead, they are valued by specific or select segment members who may have unique or additional needs. These options are not necessary for the basic functionality of the product or service but are offered to enhance the offering's appeal and cater to a broader range of preferences.

 

So, a "flexible market offering" combines the essential, universally valued elements (naked solution) that are common across the entire market segment, along with the optional, value-added features (discretionary options) that cater to specific preferences or requirements of certain segment members. This approach allows businesses to meet the diverse needs of a market while providing a base offering that addresses the core demands of the majority.

 

Question 112
Arrange the steps involved in the Segmentation process in correct order.(i) Segment Identification(ii) Segment “Acid Test”(iii) Segment Profitability(iv) Needs-Based Segmentation(v) Marketing-Mix Strategy(vi) Segment Positioning(vii) Segment AttractivenessSelect the correct option:Codes
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v), (vi), (vii)
  • B.(vii), (vi), (v), (iv), (iii), (ii), (i)
  • C.(iv), (i), (vii), (iii), (vi), (ii), (v)
  • D.(ii), (i), (iv), (vii), (v), (vi), (iii)
Correct Answer: (iv), (i), (vii), (iii), (vi), (ii), (v)

There are many statistical techniques for developing market segments. Once the firm has identified its market-segment opportunities, it must decide how many and which ones to target. Marketers are increasingly combining several variables in an effort to identify smaller, better-defined target groups. Some market researchers advocate a needs-based market segmentation approach. Roger Best proposed the seven-step approach for need-based market segmentation:

 

(i) Needs-Based Segmentation: Group customers into segments based on similar needs and benefits sought by customers in solving a particular consumption problem

(ii) Segment Identification: For each needs-based segment, determine which demographics, lifestyles, and usage behaviors make the segment distinct and identifiable (actionable)

(iii) Segment Attractiveness: Using predetermined segment attractiveness criteria (such as market growth, competitive intensity, and market access), determine the overall attractiveness of each segment

(iv) Segment Profitability: Determine segment profitability.

(v) Segment Positioning: For each segment, create a “value proposition” and product-price positioning strategy based on that segment’s unique customer needs and characteristics.

(vi) Segment “Acid Test”: Create “segment storyboard” to test the attractiveness of each segment’s positioning strategy

(vii) Marketing-Mix Strategy: Expand segment positioning strategy to include all aspects of the marketing mix: product, price, promotion, and place.

Question 113
To be useful, market segments must rate favorably on which of the following 5 key criteria?(i) Substantial(ii) Measurable(iii) Perceptible(iv) Accessible(v) Differentiable(vi) Surveyable(vii) ActionableCodes
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v)
  • B.(ii), (iii), (iv), (v), (vi)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iv), (v), (vii)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iv), (v), (vii)

Not all segmentation schemes are useful. To be useful, market segments must rate favorably on 5 key criteria:

(i) Measurable - The size, purchasing power, and characteristics of the segments can be measured.

(ii) Substantial - The segments are large and profitable enough to serve. A segment should be the largest possible homogeneous group worth going after with a tailored marketing program.

(iii) Accessible - The segments can be effectively reached and served.

(iv) Differentiable - The segments are conceptually distinguishable and respond differently to different marketing-mix elements and programs. If married and unmarried women respond similarly to a sale on perfume, they do not constitute separate segments.

(v) Actionable - Effective programs can be formulated for attracting and serving the segments.

Question 114
________ is a set of segments sharing some exploitable similarity.
  • A.Super segment
  • B.Sub segment
  • C.High segment
  • D.Untouched segment
Correct Answer: Super segment

Keeping synergies in mind, companies can try to operate in super-segments rather than in isolated segments. A super-segment is a set of segments sharing some exploitable similarity.

Multiple segment specialization: With selective specialization, a firm selects a subset of all the possible segments, each objectively attractive and appropriate. There may be little or no synergy among the segments, but each promise to be a moneymaker. The multi-segment strategy also has the advantage of diversifying the firm’s risk.

 

A firm can also attempt to achieve some synergy with product or market specialization:

With product specialization, the firm sells a certain product to several different market segments. A microscope manufacturer, for instance, sells to university, government, and commercial laboratories, making different instruments for each and building a strong reputation in the specific product area.

 

With market specialization, the firm concentrates on serving many needs of a particular customer group, such as by selling an assortment of products only to university laboratories. The firm gains a strong reputation among this customer group and becomes a channel for additional products its members can use.

Question 115
Statement I:With single-segment concentration, the firm markets to only one particular segment.Statement II:A niche is a more narrowly defined customer group seeking a distinctive mix of benefits within a segment.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (A) Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: With single-segment concentration, the firm markets to only one particular segment.

This statement is correct. Single-segment concentration, also known as concentrated marketing, occurs when a company focuses its marketing efforts on targeting and serving a single specific market segment. This allows the company to understand the unique needs, preferences, and behaviors of that particular segment and tailor its marketing strategies accordingly.

 

Statement II: A niche is a more narrowly defined customer group seeking a distinctive mix of benefits within a segment.

This statement is also correct. A niche refers to a narrowly defined subset or segment within a broader market. Niche marketing involves targeting this specific group of consumers who seek a distinct set of benefits or characteristics within a larger segment. Niche marketing allows businesses to specialize and serve the unique needs and preferences of this specialized audience, often resulting in a competitive advantage.

Question 116
__________ combines operationally driven mass customization with customized marketing in a way that empowers consumers to design the product and service offering of their choice.
  • A.Tailor-make
  • B.Personalization
  • C.Customization
  • D.Customerization
Correct Answer: Customerization

The correct answer is (D) Customerization.

 

Customerization is a marketing approach that combines operationally driven mass customization with customized marketing. It empowers consumers to design the product and service offering of their choice, tailoring it to their individual preferences and needs. This approach aims to provide a highly personalized and interactive experience for customers, allowing them to actively participate in shaping the products or services they receive. Customerization reflects a deeper level of personalization and involvement compared to traditional mass customization or standard marketing strategies.

Question 117
Statement I:Marketers must target carefully to avoid consumer backlash.Statement II:Market targeting can generate public controversy when marketers take unfair advantage of vulnerable groups.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (A) Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: Marketers must target carefully to avoid consumer backlash.

This statement is correct. Effective market targeting requires careful consideration to ensure that marketing efforts are directed at the right audience, with appropriate messaging and methods. Failure to do so can result in consumer backlash, where consumers may reject or react negatively to the marketing efforts if they feel they are being targeted inappropriately.

 

Statement II: Market targeting can generate public controversy when marketers take unfair advantage of vulnerable groups.

This statement is also correct. Market targeting can indeed lead to public controversy, especially if marketers are perceived to take unfair advantage of vulnerable or disadvantaged groups. Ethical considerations are crucial in market targeting to ensure that marketing practices are fair, transparent, and do not exploit or harm vulnerable individuals or communities.

Question 118
Identify correct statement.Statement I: Firms uses undifferentiated marketing for targeting customers on a broader level.Statement II: Firms uses micro-marketing for targeting customers at narrower level.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (A) Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: Firms use undifferentiated marketing for targeting customers on a broader level.

This statement is correct. Undifferentiated marketing, also known as mass marketing, involves creating a single marketing strategy and applying it to the entire market without segmenting it into different groups. It's a broader approach aimed at reaching a wide audience with the same message and offer.

 

Statement II: Firms use micro-marketing for targeting customers at a narrower level.

This statement is also correct. Micro-marketing, also known as niche marketing, involves tailoring marketing strategies to cater to specific segments or niches within the broader market. It's a narrower approach that focuses on specific customer groups with distinct needs, preferences, and characteristics.

Quiz Attempt #119601

Total Questions: 52
Question 1
An attacking strategy which involves introducing new products or technologies that rewrite the rules of competition in the market and avoid direct conflict with a rival is known as(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023
  • A.Flanking
  • B.Bypass
  • C.Encirclement
  • D.Guerrilla
Correct Answer: Bypass

Correct answer is option B - Bypass.

 

The attacking strategy that involves introducing new products or technologies to rewrite the rules of competition in the market and avoid direct conflict with a rival is known as "Bypass" strategy.

Question 2
Which one of the following is the report of the company’s strengths and weaknesses relative to various competitors? (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.Competitor value analysis
  • B.Customer value analysis
  • C.Customer profitability analysis
  • D.Customer perceived value
Correct Answer: Customer value analysis

Customer value analysis is a tool used to evaluate a company's performance in relation to its competitors by assessing the benefits that target customers value. This analysis helps the company understand how customers perceive the relative value of its offerings compared to those of competitors. The process involves identifying the key attributes that customers value and their significance in influencing purchase decisions.

 

In a customer value analysis, a company gathers insights from customers to determine the attributes they consider important and how they perceive the performance of different brands, including the company's own and its competitors'. By analyzing this information, the company can identify its strengths and weaknesses in meeting customer preferences and can strategize to enhance its competitive position.

 

This analysis provides valuable insights for a company to make informed decisions about its marketing strategies, product development, and overall business approach. By focusing on the attributes that matter most to customers and addressing areas of weakness, a company can work towards delivering superior value and gaining a competitive advantage in the marketplace.

Question 3
Companies that attack other firms including market leader in an attempt to build market share are called (UGC NET Management Dec 2009)
  • A.Market followers
  • B.Market challengers
  • C.Market penetrators
  • D.MarketNichers
Correct Answer: Market challengers

Companies that actively compete against other firms, including the market leader, in an effort to gain a larger market share are known as "market challengers." These challengers aim to disrupt the existing market dynamics and establish themselves as significant players in the industry. On the other hand, companies that do not take aggressive actions and simply follow the market trends without challenging the status quo are referred to as "market followers."

Question 4
Which of the following is NOT the characteristic of “Hyper Competition”? (UGC NET Management Dec 2019)
  • A.Competitions get bold,aggressiveand hostile with dynamic movements
  • B.Shorter Product and design life cycles
  • C.Uncertainty in business environment increases along with heterogenicity
  • D.Financing cost becomes high
Correct Answer: Financing cost becomes high

The characteristic of "Hyper Competition" that is NOT true is (D) Financing cost becomes high.

 

Hyper competition refers to a highly intense and rapidly changing competitive environment where businesses engage in aggressive and dynamic strategies to gain a competitive edge. The other characteristics listed – bold and aggressive competition, shorter product and design life cycles, and increased uncertainty and heterogeneity in the business environment – are consistent with the concept of hyper competition.

 

However, the financing cost becoming high is not typically considered a characteristic of hyper competition. In fact, in hypercompetitive markets, businesses often strive to reduce costs, including financing costs, to remain competitive.

Question 5
Match the items of List I with the items of List II and choose the correct answer from the code given below. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)List I(a) Mobiledefense(b) Contractiondefense(c) PositiondefenseList II(i) Occupying the most desirable position in consumer’s minds, making the brand almost impregnable.(ii) The leader stretches its domain over new territories through market broadening and market diversification.(iii) Large companies give up weaker markets and reassign resources to stronger ones.Code:
  • A.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii)
  • D.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)

The correct answer is (B) (a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i).

 

(a) Mobile defense - The leader stretches its domain over new territories through market broadening and market diversification.

Mobile Defense Strategy: It is a kind of defense strategy chosen by a firm to prevent competition from the competitors.
