It requires constantly changing position and business such that it becomes difficult for competitors to compete. Firms get into Market broadening and market diversification to increase its coverage into new territories. Businesses are able to do so by introducing new products, making modification in existing products, entering new markets, changing market segment, changing target market or changing promotional focus. For example: A petroleum industry getting involved in producing coal, hydroelectric or nuclear industry, or companies like Philips entering into food industry.

 

(b) Contraction defense - Large companies give up weaker markets and reassign resources to stronger ones.

Contraction defense strategy: This technique is often used by the market leader and is often times seen as the last resort strategy as it involves giving up some portion of the business to maintain leadership. In this the market leader withdraws from one segment of the market where it is not strong or profitable enough in order that the resources used in that segment may be withdrawn and be put to better use in a segment where chances of success are higher owing to greater strength of the leader. This could happen when there is extreme competition and leading to continuous bleeding or when there is not enough expertise in the leader to handle this business. This is also known as strategic withdrawal and frees up resources that the company can then put to use in areas where it has the critical mass and capability to succeed.

 

(c) Position defense - Occupying the most desirable position in consumer’s minds, making the brand almost impregnable.

Position defense: It is one of the marketing warfare strategies wherein the brand or company occupies the most desirable space in the minds of the customer and in no case intends to divert from that position thus making the brand impregnable. It is like maintaining the status of superior brand and erecting fortification around the brand, making it extremely difficult for other competitive brands to impeach upon your space. This strategy is normally followed by brands where the defender is a market leader or enjoys a high position in the minds of its customers and the contender brand is a rising brand aiming to displace the defender form its position. In such cases, the defender maintains its position of market leader by reminding customers about the status of the brand, setting up entry barriers, coming up with exclusive distribution contracts, getting patents, or establishing monopoly like situation.

Question 6
The strategies of flankingdefense, pre-emptivedefense, mobiledefense, contractordefenseand counter offensivedefenseare used by which market player? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. Market challengerII. Market leaderIII. Market followerIV. MarketnicherV. Startup MarketerChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.I only
  • B.II only
  • C.III only
  • D.II, V only
Correct Answer: II only

The correct answer is (B) II only.

 

The strategies of flanking defense, pre-emptive defense, mobile defense, contractor defense, and counter-offensive defense are typically used by market leaders. Market leaders employ these defensive and offensive strategies to maintain or strengthen their dominant position in the market and respond to challenges from competitors. Market challengers, market followers, market nichers, and startup marketers may use different strategies depending on their specific positions and goals in the market, but these defensive strategies are most associated with market leaders.

Question 7
“If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles.”The above statement of Sun Tzu corresponds to which one of the following components of Porter’s Five ForcesModel?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Threat of substitutes.
  • B.Threat of Competitor.
  • C.Bargain Power of Supplier.
  • D.Threat of New Entrants.
Correct Answer: Threat of Competitor.

The statement by Sun Tzu, "If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles," corresponds to the component of Porter's Five Forces Model known as (B) Threat of Competitor.

 

Understanding your competitors and your own strengths and weaknesses is crucial in competitive strategy. Sun Tzu's statement emphasizes the importance of knowing your enemy (competitors) and knowing yourself to be well-prepared for battles or competition. This aligns with the idea of assessing the threat posed by existing competitors, which is one of the aspects covered by the "Threat of Competitor" in Porter's Five Forces Model.

Question 8
Michael Porter has identified five forces that determine the intrinsic long-term attractiveness of a market. According to the model, which of the following are true? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)(a) A segment is unattractive if it already contains numerous aggressive competitors.(b) A segment is unattractive if it is stable or declining.(c) A segment is unattractive if it has high entry barriers and low exit barriers.(d) A segment is unattractive if the company's suppliers are able to raise prices.(e) A segment is unattractive when there are actual or potent substitutes for the product.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a and b only.
  • B.b and c only.
  • C.a,cand d only.
  • D.a, b,dand e only.
Correct Answer: a, b,dand e only.

According to Michael Porter's Five Forces model, the following statements are true:

 

(a) A segment is unattractive if it already contains numerous aggressive competitors.

(b) A segment is unattractive if it is stable or declining.

(d) A segment is unattractive if the company's suppliers are able to raise prices.

(e) A segment is unattractive when there are actual or potent substitutes for the product.

 

These factors, as mentioned in the model, determine the intrinsic long-term attractiveness of a market. So, the correct answer is (D) a, b, d, and e only.

Question 9
Assertion ‘A’:Buyers, for several industries, are potential competitors-they may integrate backwards.Reasoning ‘R’:They have different degrees of bargaining power.Codes:(UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.A and R arecorrectand R is the correct reasoning of A.
  • B.A and R arecorrectbut R is not the correct reasoning of A.
  • C.A is incorrect while R is a correct statement.
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect.
Correct Answer: A and R arecorrectand R is the correct reasoning of A.

Both Assertion (A) and Reasoning (R) are correct, and Reasoning (R) provides a valid explanation for Assertion (A). The correct code is (A).

 

Assertion (A) is correct. In various industries, buyers can indeed become potential competitors by integrating backward. This means buyers, who were initially purchasing products or services from the industry, may decide to start producing these products or services themselves. This can happen when buyers have the resources and capabilities to enter the production side of the industry.

 

Reasoning (R) is also correct. The level of bargaining power a buyer has can influence their decision to integrate backward. If buyers have strong bargaining power, they may feel more confident in their ability to successfully compete in the market by producing the product or service themselves. Conversely, if they lack bargaining power, integrating backward may not be a viable option.

Question 10
Statement- I: Pricing at par with the market price of the existing brandsis considered to bethe most reasonable pricing strategy for a product which is being sold in a strongly competitive market.Statement- II:Pricing below the market price has been found to be more successful when a seller intends to achieve a prestigious position among the sellers in the locality for selling prestigious goods of much superior quality.Codes:(UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.Both the statements are correct.
  • B.Both the statements are incorrect.
  • C.Statement- I is correct while Statement- II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement- I is incorrect while Statement- II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement- I is correct while Statement- II is incorrect.

The correct code is (C) where Statement I is correct, but Statement II is incorrect.

 

Statement I: Pricing at par with the market price of existing brands is considered to be the most reasonable pricing strategy for a product being sold in a strongly competitive market.

This statement is generally true. Pricing a product in line with existing market prices is a common strategy to remain competitive, especially in a highly competitive market. It helps avoid overpricing or underpricing the product, ensuring that it is perceived as reasonable by customers.

 

Statement II: Pricing below the market price has been found to be more successful when a seller intends to achieve a prestigious position among the sellers in the locality for selling prestigious goods of much superior quality.

This statement is incorrect. Pricing below the market price is typically associated with budget or discount pricing strategies, not achieving a prestigious position. If a seller intends to establish a prestigious position by selling superior-quality goods, they often use premium pricing strategies, setting prices higher than the market average to reflect the product's quality and exclusivity.

Question 11
Which of the following is not a reason for a firm to lose its market share to competitors? (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.A product/model is perceived by the target customer group as satisfying needs.
  • B.Customers not being covered by the company’s sales force and distribution outlets.
  • C.Customers may have been lost to competitors due to poor service by the firm or its sales personnel or product becoming obsolete or more expensive.
  • D.All the above are correct reasons for given condition.
Correct Answer: A product/model is perceived by the target customer group as satisfying needs.

The correct answer is (A) "A product/model is perceived by the target customer group as satisfying needs."

 

This statement suggests that if a product or model is perceived by the target customer group as satisfying their needs, it is not a reason for a firm to lose its market share to competitors. In fact, meeting customer needs and preferences is one of the key strategies for retaining and growing market share.

 

Option (B) and (C) both provide valid reasons for a firm to lose market share:

(B) Customers not being covered by the company’s sales force and distribution outlets can lead to the loss of potential customers who are not reached by the company's sales efforts.

(C) Customers may have been lost to competitors due to poor service by the firm or its sales personnel, or because the product has become obsolete or more expensive. These factors can all contribute to customers switching to competitors.

So, the correct choice is (A) because it is not a reason for a firm to lose market share; it's actually a reason for retaining or gaining market share by satisfying customer needs.

Question 12
In order to maintain its market share, a market follower can employ: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Counterfeitingstrategy.
  • B.Specialization strategy.
  • C.Counter offensive strategy.
  • D.Preemptivestrategy.
Correct Answer: Counterfeitingstrategy.

The correct answer is (A) Counter feiting strategy.

 

In order to maintain its market share, a market follower can employ a Counterfeiting strategy. Counterfeiting strategy involves the production, distribution, and sale of imitation or fake products, usually to deceive consumers into believing that they are purchasing genuine goods. This strategy is characterized by unethical and illegal practices, as it infringes upon intellectual property rights, trademarks, and copyrights held by the original manufacturers.

Question 13
Arrange the sequential steps to plan effective competitive marketing strategies in a market which a company uses to compare its products,pricesand channels with that of existing competitor.a) Selecting competitors to attack and avoidb) Determining competitors’ objectives.c) Identifying the company’s competitorsd) Estimating competitors’ reaction patterne) Assessing Competitors’ strengths and weaknessesf) Identifying competitors’ strategiesCodes
  • A.a b c d e f
  • B.a d c b e f
  • C.b c a d e f
  • D.c b f e d a
Correct Answer: c b f e d a

To plan effective marketing strategies, a company needs to find out all it can about its competitors. It must constantly compare its marketing strategies, products, prices, channels, and promotions with those of close competitors. In this way, the company can find areas of potential competitive advantage and disadvantage.

 

1. Identifying Competitors

Normally, identifying competitors would seem to be a simple task. At the narrowest level, a company can define its competitors as other companies offering similar products and services to the same customers at similar prices.

 

2. Determining Competitors’ Objectives

Each competitor has a mix of objectives. Knowing a competitor’s mix of objectives reveals whether the competitor is satisfied with its current situation and how it might react to different competitive actions.

 

3. Identifying Competitors’ Strategies

The more one firm’s strategy resembles another firm’s strategy, the more the two firms compete. In most industries, the competitors can be sorted into groups that pursue different strategies. A strategic group is a group of firms in an industry following the same or a similar strategy in a given target market. For example, in the auto industry, Ford and Toyota belong to the same strategic group.

 

4. Assessing Competitors’ Strengths and Weaknesses

Marketers need to carefully assess each competitor’s strengths and weaknesses to answer a critical question: What can our competitors do? As a first step, companies can gather data on each competitor’s goals, strategies, and performance over the past few years. Admittedly, some of this information will be hard to obtain. Companies normally learn about their competitors’ strengths and weaknesses through secondary data, personal experience, and word of mouth. They can also conduct primary marketing research with customers, suppliers, and dealers. They can check competitors’ online and social media sites. Or they can try benchmarking themselves against other firms, comparing the company’s products and processes to those of competitors or leading firms in other industries to identify best practices and find ways to improve quality and performance.

 

5. Estimating Competitors’ Reactions

Marketing managers need a deep understanding of a competitor’s mentality if they want to anticipate how that competitor will act or react. Each competitor reacts differently. Some do not react quickly or strongly to a competitor’s move. They may feel their customers are loyal, they may be slow in noticing the move, or they may lack the funds to react. Some competitors react only to certain types of moves and not to others. Other competitors react swiftly and strongly to any action.

 

6. Selecting Competitors to Attack and Avoid

A company can focus on one of several classes of competitors. Most companies prefer to compete against weak competitors. This requires fewer resources and less time. But in the process, the firm may gain little. You could argue that a firm also should compete with strong competitors to sharpen its abilities. And sometimes, a company can’t avoid its largest competitors. But even strong competitors have some weaknesses, and succeeding against them often provides greater returns.

A useful tool for assessing competitor strengths and weaknesses is customer value analysis. The aim of customer value analysis is to determine the benefits that target customers value and how customers rate the relative value of various competitors’ offers. In conducting a customer value analysis, the company first identifies the major attributes that customers value and the importance customers place on these attributes. Next, it assesses its performance against competitors on those valued attributes. The key to gaining competitive advantage is to examine how a company’s offer compares to that of its major competitors in each customer segment.

Question 14
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Managers should estimate competitors’ costs and performances as benchmarks against which to compare their own.Statement II:We can identify best-practice companies byanalyzingtheir sales revenue and market share.
  • A.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect

The correct answer is (C) Statement I is correct, and Statement II is incorrect.

 

Statement I is accurate because it emphasizes the importance of managers using competitors' costs and performances as benchmarks for assessing their own operations. In practice, this benchmarking process allows organizations to identify areas where they can improve and optimize their strategies.

 

Statement II is not correct. The identification of best-practice companies is a more comprehensive process than merely analyzing sales revenue and market share. It involves gathering insights from various sources, such as customers, suppliers, distributors, financial analysts, trade associations, and industry publications, to determine which companies are recognized as excelling in their respective fields. This broader approach provides a more holistic view of a company's best practices and performance beyond financial metrics.

 

For example, companies like GE actively engage in benchmarking to enhance their innovation efforts. They not only compare themselves to competitors but also seek inspiration from industry leaders like P&G while developing their own best practices.

Question 15
Firms pursuing the same strategy directed to the same target market called
  • A.Strategic group
  • B.Strategic intent
  • C.Strategic Path
  • D.Strategic Intervention
Correct Answer: Strategic group

Strategy is a company’s game plan for achieving its goals. 

According to Michael Porter, firms directing the same strategy to the same target market constitute a strategic group The firm that carries out that strategy best will make the most profits.

Michael Porter has proposed 3 generic strategies that provide a good starting point for strategic thinking: overall cost leadership, differentiation, and focus

Question 16
Match the following. (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)List I (Competitive Positions)(a) Market Leader(b) Market Challenger(c) Market Follower(d) MarketNicherList II (Description)(i) Wants to hold its market share in an industry without rocking the boat.(ii) largest market share.(iii) Fighting hard to increase its market share.(iv) Serves a small segment that the other firms in an industry overlook.Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)

Firms competing in a given target market, at any point in time, differ in their objectives and resources, as well as their competitive positions in the target market. Various competitive positions are:

Market leader: the firm in an industry with the largest market share.

Market challenger: a runner-up firm that is fighting hard to increase its market share in an industry.

Market follower: a runner-up firm that wants to hold its market share in an industry without rocking the boat.

Market nicher: serves a small segment that the other firms in an industry overlook or ignore.

 

These classifications often do not apply to a whole company, but rather to its position in a specific industry. Most industries contain any knowledge market leader. The leader has the largest market share and usually leads other firms in price changes, and new product introductions, distribution coverage, and promotion spending. The leader may or may not be admired or respected, but the other firms concede its dominance. Competitors focus on leader as a company to challenge, imitate, or avoid.

Question 17
Which among the following is/are the factors a Market Leader should consider before using strategy for increasing market share?
  • A.Economic cost
  • B.The danger of pursuing the wrong marketing activities
  • C.The effect of increased market share on actual and perceived quality
  • D.All of the Above
Correct Answer: All of the Above

Increasing Market Share for Market Leaders

Gaining increased market share does not automatically produce higher profits and much depends on the company’s strategy. It can be the case that cost of buying higher market share through acquisition may far exceed its revenue value. Hence, for increasing market share, a firm should consider 4 factors:

 

(i) The possibility of provoking anti-trust action: When a market leader tries to increase market share, it might happen that competitors accused it of "monopoly” and seek legal action. For example, Microsoft and Intel have had to fend off numerous lawsuits and legal challenges around the world as a result of what some feel are inappropriate or illegal business practices and abuse of market power. 

 

(ii) Economic cost: The cost of gaining further market share (higher than its optimal market share) might exceed the value if holdout customers dislike the company, are loyal to competitors, have unique needs, or prefer dealing with smaller firms. Also the costs of legal work, public relations, and lobbying rise with market share. Pushing for higher share is less justifiable when there are unattractive market segments, buyers who want multiple sources of supply, high exit barriers, and few scale or experience economies. Even some market leaders have even increased profitability by selectively decreasing market share in weaker areas.

 

(iii) The danger of pursuing the wrong marketing activities: Companies successfully gaining share typically outperform competitors in three areas: new-product activity, relative product quality, and marketing expenditures. Companies that attempt to increase market share by cutting prices (for instance) more deeply than competitors typically don’t achieve significant gains, because rivals meet the price cuts or offer other values so buyers don’t switch.

 

(iv) The effect of increased market share on actual and perceived quality: Too many customers can put a strain on the firm’s resources, hurting product value and service delivery.

Question 18
Match the following.List I (Defensive Strategy)(a) FlankDefense(b) MobileDefense(c) ContractionDefense(d) PositionDefenseList II (Description)(i) Leaders give up weaker markets and reassign resources to stronger ones.(ii) Leader occupies the most desirable market space in consumers’ mind.(iii) Leader erect outposts to protect a weak front.(iv) Leader stretches its domain over new territories through market broadening and market diversification.Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)

Defensive Marketing

The aim of defensive strategy is to reduce the probability of attack, divert attacks to less-threatened areas, and lessen their intensity. Speed of response can make an important difference to profit.

 

A Market Leader/Dominant Firm can use the 6 defense strategies: 

(i) Position Defense: It means occupying the most desirable market space in consumers’ minds, making the brand almost impregnable, as Procter & Gamble has done with Pampers diapers for dryness.

 

(ii) Flank Defense: The market leader should erect outposts to protect a weak front or support a possible counterattack.

 

(iii) Preemptive Defense: A more aggressive maneuver is to attack first, perhaps with guerrilla action across the market by hitting one competitor here, another there and keeping everyone off balance. Another is to achieve broad market envelopment that signals competitors not to attack. For example, if Microsoft announces plans for a new-product development, smaller firms may choose to concentrate their development efforts in other directions to avoid head-to-head competition. Even some high-tech firms have been accused of selling “vaporware”—announcing products that miss delivery dates or are never introduced.

 

(iv) Counter-offensive Defense: In a counter-offensive, the market leader can meet the attacker frontally and hit its flank, or launch a pincer movement so it will have to pull back to defend itself. Another common form of counteroffensive is the exercise of economic or political clout. The leader may try to crush a competitor by subsidizing lower prices for the vulnerable product with revenue from its more profitable products, or it may prematurely announce a product upgrade to prevent customers from buying the competitor’s product. 

 

(v) Mobile Defense: In mobile defense, the leader stretches its domain over new territories through market broadening and market diversification. 

(a) Market broadening shifts the company’s focus from the current product to the underlying generic need. Thus, “petroleum” companies such as BP sought to recast themselves as “energy” companies. This change required them to research the oil, coal, nuclear, hydroelectric, and chemical industries. 

(b) Market diversification shifts the company’s focus into unrelated industries. For example, when U.S. tobacco companies such as Reynolds and Philip Morris acknowledged the growing curbs on cigarette smoking, instead of defending their market position or looking for cigarette substitutes, they moved quickly into new industries such as beer, liquor, soft drinks, and frozen foods. 

 

(vi) Contraction Defense: Sometimes large companies can no longer defend all their territory. In planned contraction (also called strategic withdrawal), they give up weaker markets and reassign resources to stronger ones.

 

Question 19
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Flanks Attack attempts to capture a wide slice of territory and makes sense when the challenger commands superior resources.Statement II:Encirclement Attack is particularly attractive to a challenger with fewer resources.
  • A.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (D) Statement I is incorrect, and Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: "Flanks Attack attempts to capture a wide slice of territory and makes sense when the challenger commands superior resources." - This statement is incorrect. Flank attack strategy is more attractive to challengers with fewer resources, not those with superior resources. It involves identifying shifts in the market and filling gaps, which can be a more viable approach for resource-constrained challengers.

 

Statement II: "Encirclement Attack is particularly attractive to a challenger with fewer resources." - This statement is correct. Encirclement attack is a strategy that makes sense when the challenger has superior resources, as it involves launching a grand offensive on several fronts to capture a wide slice of territory.

Question 20
Match the following.List I (Market Follower)(a) Counterfeiter(b) Cloner(c) Imitator(d) AdapterList II (Description)(i) Copies some things from the product but differentiates on packaging, advertising, pricing, or location.(ii) Emulates the products, name, and packaging, with slight variations.(iii) Takes the product and improves it.(iv) Duplicates the product and packages and sells it on the black market.Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)

Market followers are runner-up firms in an industry that aim to maintain their market share without engaging in disruptive tactics. In industries where products are highly similar and differentiation is challenging, market followers often employ strategies that involve imitating or adapting to the market leader's approach. There are four broad strategies for market followers:

 

(i) Counterfeiter: This strategy involves duplicating the leader's product and packaging and selling it through unauthorized channels, such as the black market. Counterfeiters create replicas of the leader's product without proper authorization, leading to brand reputation issues and legal challenges. Examples include counterfeit Apple products or fake Rolex watches, which are commonly found, especially in certain regions like Asia.

 

(ii) Cloner: Cloners emulate the leader's products, brand name, and packaging with minor variations. They closely mimic the leader's offerings, often in an attempt to benefit from the leader's established market presence.

 

(iii) Imitator: Imitators copy certain elements from the leader's product but differentiate themselves in areas such as packaging, advertising, pricing, or location. This strategy allows imitators to offer a similar product while still presenting some distinct features to attract customers. Importantly, leaders often tolerate imitators as long as they don't aggressively challenge the leader's position.

 

(iv) Adapter: Adapters take the leader's products and adapt or improve upon them. They may choose to sell to different markets or enhance the product's features or quality. Adapters can eventually grow into future challengers by continually improving products initially developed elsewhere. Japanese firms, for example, have often employed this strategy after initially adapting and enhancing products from other regions.

 

The correct match for the given question is (A) a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iii).

Counterfeiter (a) aligns with (iv).

Cloner (b) aligns with (ii).

Imitator (c) aligns with (i).

Adapter (d) aligns with (iii).

Question 21
Given below are 2 statements - one islabeledas Assertion and the other islabeledas Reason.Assertion “A”:Thenicherachieves high margin, whereas the mass marketer achieves high volume.Reason “R”:The marketnicherknows the target customers so well, it meets their needs better than other firms selling to them casually.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R arecorrectand R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A

The concept being discussed here is the strategy of niching, where a company targets a small, specialized market segment.

 

The provided explanation states that nichers achieve high margins because they have an in-depth understanding of their target customers' needs, allowing them to offer tailored products or services. This aligns with Assertion (A), which states that nichers achieve high margins.

 

Reason (R) provides an explanation for Assertion (A), emphasizing that the nicher's deep understanding of their customers enables them to better meet their needs compared to firms selling to them casually. This explanation supports Assertion (A) and is therefore the correct explanation for it.

 

Given this alignment between Assertion (A) and Reason (R), the correct answer is (A) - Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A, as per the provided explanation.

Question 22
Identify correct statement.Statement I:A company in an attractive industry that possesses competitive strength should consider shrinking selectively.Statement II:A company in an unattractive industry that has competitive strength should consider strengthening its investment.
  • A.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is incorrect

Op Marketing Strategies: Decline Stage 

Sales decline for a number of reasons, including technological advances, shifts in consumer tastes, and increased domestic and foreign competition. All can lead to overcapacity, increased price cutting, and profit erosion. As sales and profits decline over a long period of time, some firms withdraw. Those remaining may reduce the number of products they offer, withdrawing from smaller segments and weaker trade channels, cutting marketing budgets, and reducing prices further. Unless strong reasons for retention exist, carrying a weak product is often very costly.

Besides being unprofitable, weak products consume a disproportionate amount of management’s time, require frequent price and inventory adjustments, incur expensive setup for short production runs, draw advertising and sales force attention better used to make healthy products more profitable, and cast a negative shadow on company image. Failing to eliminate them also delays the aggressive search for replacement products.

Unfortunately, most companies have not developed a policy for handling aging products. The first task is to establish a system for identifying them. Many companies appoint a product-review committee with representatives from marketing, R&D, manufacturing, and finance who, based on all available information, makes a recommendation for each product—leave it alone, modify its marketing strategy, or drop it. Procter & Gamble stayed in the declining liquid-soap business and improved its profits as others withdrew. 

The appropriate strategy also depends on the industry’s relative attractiveness and the company’s competitive strength in it. A company in an unattractive industry that possesses competitive strength should consider shrinking selectively. A company in an attractive industry that has competitive strength should consider strengthening its investment. Companies that successfully restage or rejuvenate a mature product often do so by adding value to it.

Therefore, both Statements are incorrect.

 

Strategies in Economic Recession:

In a recession, marketers must explore the upside of possibly increasing investments, get closer to customers, review budget allocations, put forth the most compelling value proposition, and fine-tune brand and product offerings.

Question 23
Which of the following is/are the strategies a firm can use to stay Market Leader?
  • A.Expanding Total Market Demand
  • B.Protecting Market Share
  • C.Increasing Market Share
  • D.All of the Above
Correct Answer: All of the Above

The correct answer is (D) All of the Above.

 

A firm can use the strategies of expanding total market demand, protecting market share, and increasing market share to maintain its position as a market leader.

 

(A) Expanding Total Market Demand: This strategy involves working to grow the overall market for the products or services a firm offers. By creating new demand and increasing the customer base, the market leader can maintain its position and potentially capture a larger share of the expanded market.

 

(B) Protecting Market Share: Protecting market share involves strategies aimed at maintaining the current portion of the market that the firm holds. This can include defensive measures to retain customers, enhance customer loyalty, and respond effectively to competitors to prevent them from gaining market share at the leader's expense.

 

(C) Increasing Market Share: Actively working to increase market share involves strategic efforts to capture a larger portion of the market compared to competitors. This can be achieved through various means, such as offering better products or services, competitive pricing, effective marketing, innovation, acquisitions, or partnerships.

Question 24
Match the following.List I(a) Competitor Advantage(b) Competitor Marketing Strategies(c) Competitor AnalysisList II(i) Gained by offering consumers greater value than competitors do.(ii) Strongly position the company against competitors.(iii) Selecting which competitors to attack or avoid.Codes
  • A.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii)
  • B.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)
  • D.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii)

The correct answer is (B) a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii).

 

Competitor Advantage (a) - Gained by offering consumers greater value than competitors do (i)

Competitor Advantage is the competitive edge a company has over its rivals, achieved by providing customers with greater value through its products, services, or overall customer experience. This is denoted by (i) in List II because gaining an advantage by offering superior value to consumers is a fundamental aspect of Competitor Advantage.

 

Competitor Marketing Strategies (b) - Strongly position the company against competitors (ii)

Competitor Marketing Strategies involve tactics and actions taken by a company to position itself effectively against its competitors in the market. It's about creating a unique and strong position in the minds of consumers relative to competitors. This corresponds to (ii) in List II as it emphasizes positioning the company strongly against competitors.

 

Competitor Analysis (c) - Selecting which competitors to attack or avoid (iii)

Competitor Analysis is the process of assessing and evaluating the strengths, weaknesses, strategies, and performance of competitors in the market. It involves understanding the competitive landscape to make informed decisions about which competitors to target (attack) or avoid. Hence, (iii) in List II aligns with Competitor Analysis.

Question 25
Given below are 2 statements - one islabeledas Assertion and the other islabeledas Reason.Assertion “A”:A useful tool for assessing competitor’s strengths and weaknesses is the Customer Value Analysis.Reason “R”:Customer Value Analysis is an analysis conducted to determine what benefits target customer’s value and how they rate the relative value of various competitors’ offers.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R arecorrectand R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A

Competitor analysis is the process of identifying key competitors, assessing their objectives, strategies, strengths and weaknesses and reaction patterns, and selecting which competitors to attack or avoid. It consists of three steps:

 

(i) Identifying competitors: This might seem easy, but companies face a lot more competitors than can be identified at first sight. Competitors can be identified from an industry point or a market point of view. 

 

(ii) Assessing competitors: When doing so, firms need to look at the competitor’s objectives and identify competitor’s strategies. It is also important to assess the strengths and weakness of competitors. This way, the firm can benchmark. Benchmarking is the process of comparing one company’s products and processes to those of competitors or leading firms in other industries to identify best practices and find ways to improve quality and performance. Finally, the firm can estimate how competitors will react to changes and anticipate their moves. 

 

(iii) Selecting which competitors to attack and avoid: A useful tool for assessing competitor’s strengths and weaknesses is the customer value analysis: an analysis conducted to determine what benefits target customer’s value and how they rate the relative value of various competitors’ offers. The key to gaining competitive advantage is to take each segment and examine how the company’s offer compares to that of competitors. Most companies compete with close competitors, but they will also have distant competitors. Firms also benefit from having competitors as they share the costs of market development and competitors may increase total demand.

 

This information must be collected, interpreted, distributed, and used. Gathering competitive intelligence can cost much money and time, so the company must design a cost-effective competitive intelligence system.

Question 26
Arrange the following Marketing Strategy for Competitive Advantage in correct order.(i) Entrepreneurial marketing(ii) Formulated marketing(iii) Intrapreneurial marketingCodes
  • A.(ii), (i), (iii)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii)
  • C.(i), (iii), (ii)
  • D.(iii), (ii), (i)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii)

The correct order for the Marketing Strategy for Competitive Advantage is (B) (i), (ii), (iii).

 

Competitor analysis is the process of identifying key competitors, assessing their objectives, strategies, strengths and weaknesses and reaction patterns, and selecting which competitors to attack or avoid. 

 

Approaches to Marketing Strategy

When the competitors are identified and evaluated, the firm must design a competitive strategy. No one strategy is best for all companies. Each company must determine what makes the most sense given its position in the industry and its objectives, opportunities, and resources. Even, within a company, different strategies may be required for different businesses or products.

Approaches to marketing strategy often pass through 3 stages: entrepreneurial marketing, formulated marketing and intrepreneurial marketing. 

 

(i) Entrepreneurial marketing typically comes first in the sequence. It involves the creative and innovative marketing strategies used by startups and entrepreneurial ventures to establish themselves in the market.

 

(ii) Formulated marketing follows entrepreneurial marketing. Once a business has established itself and grown, it often transitions to more structured and formulated marketing strategies. These strategies are based on careful planning and analysis.

 

(iii) Intrapreneurial marketing usually comes last. It refers to the marketing efforts within a larger established organization that emulate the characteristics of entrepreneurial marketing. Intrapreneurial marketing aims to infuse entrepreneurial spirit and innovation into the marketing strategies of a mature company.

Question 27
Who suggested 4 basic competitive positioning strategies that companies can follow among them there were 3 winning strategies and 1 losing one?
  • A.Adam Smith
  • B.Phillip Kotler
  • C.Seth Godin
  • D.Michael Porter
Correct Answer: Michael Porter

Michael Porter suggested four basic competitive positioning strategies that companies can follow—three winning strategies and one losing one. The 3 winning strategies are as follows:

 

(i) Overall cost leadership strategy: Here the company works hard to achieve the lowest production and distribution costs. Low costs let the company price lower than its competitors and win a large market share. Texas Instruments, Walmart, and JetBlue Airways are leading practitioners of this strategy.

 

(ii) Differentiation Strategy: The company concentrates on creating a highly differentiated product line and marketing program so that it comes across as the class leader in the industry. Most customers would prefer to own this brand if its price is not too high.

 

(iii) Focus: Here the company focuses its effort on serving a few market segments well rather than going after the whole market. For example, Ritz-Carlton focuses on the top 5 percent of corporate and leisure travelers.

Companies that pursue a clear strategy – one of the above – will likely perform well. The firm that carries out that strategy best will make the most profits. But firms that do not pursue a clear strategy—middle-of-the-roaders—do the worst. For example, Sears and Holiday Inn encountered difficult times because they did not stand out as the lowest in cost, highest in perceived value, or best in serving some market segment. Middle-of-the-roaders try to be good on all strategic counts but end up being not very good at anything.

Question 28
Match the following.List I (Competitive Marketing Strategy)(a) Operational Excellence(b) Customer Intimacy(c) Product LeadershipList II (Description)(i) Company serves customers who want good-quality products but want them cheaply.(ii) Leading-edge products(iii) Tailoring Product to match the needs of target customers.Codes
  • A.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii)
  • B.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)
  • D.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii)

Marketing consultants, Michael Treacy and Fred Wiersema, offer a customer-centered classification of competitive marketing strategies. They suggested that companies gain leadership positions by delivering superior value to their customers. Company can pursue any of the 3 strategies - called value disciplines - for delivering superior customer value:

 

(i) Operational Excellence: excellence means a company serves customers who want reliable, good-quality products or services but want them cheaply and easily. Example - Walmart.

(ii) Customer Intimacy: The company provides superior value by precisely segmenting its markets and tailoring its products or services to exactly match the needs of targeted customers.

(iii) Product Leadership: The company provides superior value by offering a continuous stream of leading-edge products or services. It aims to make its own and competing products obsolete. One example of Product leader is Tesla Motors.

Question 29
A firm in an industry that specially serves small segments that the other firms overlook or ignore is called as:
  • A.MarketNicher
  • B.Market Follower
  • C.Market Leader
  • D.Market Challenger
Correct Answer: MarketNicher

The correct answer is (A) Market Nicher.

 

A firm that targets and serves small, specialized segments in the market that are often overlooked or ignored by other firms is referred to as a Market Nicher. Market nichers focus on catering to the unique needs, preferences, or requirements of these specialized segments, often allowing them to achieve high profitability and a strong market position within their chosen niche.

Question 30
_________isan advantage over competitors gained byoffering greater customer value, either byhaving lower prices or providing morebenefits that justify higher prices.
  • A.Comparative advantage
  • B.Competitive advantage
  • C.Value innovation
  • D.Differentiated marketing
Correct Answer: Competitive advantage

The correct answer is (B) Competitive advantage.

 

Competitive advantage is the edge a business has over its competitors, which it achieves by delivering superior customer value. This value can manifest in various ways, including offering lower prices or providing more benefits that make higher prices justifiable. In essence, competitive advantage is a key driver of a company's success as it helps it stand out in the market and attract and retain customers.

Question 31
To remain dominant, a Market leader looks for: (UGC NET Management Dec 2013)
  • A.Ways to expand total market demand
  • B.Attempting to protect its current share
  • C.Increasing its market share
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

There are different strategies for different firms according to the position they are currently holding in the industry. A firm can be on following positions:

1. Market Leader

2. Market Challenger

3. Market Follower

4. Market Nicher

 

Question 32
Match the items of List - I with items of List - II and select the correct code of matching:List - I(a) Market Leader(b) Market Challenger(c) Market Follower(d) MarketNicherList - II(i) Avoid hostile attacks on rivals(ii) Attack the market leader(iii) Provide high level of specialization(iv) Attack the marketCodes:
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(iii) d-(i)
  • C.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(i) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)

To arrive at the correct code of matching, we need to understand each of these market dominance strategies:

 

Market Leader: The market leader is the firm with the largest market share. Market leaders can take actions such as expanding total market demand, protecting their current market share through defensive and offensive actions, or trying to expand their market share further.

 

Market Challenger: A market challenger is a runner-up firm that aggressively seeks to gain market share. This can involve attacking the market leader directly or exploiting weaknesses or gaps in the leader's market coverage.

 

Market Follower: Market followers are firms that often learn from the market leader's experience and may copy or improve on the leader's products and programs with fewer resources.

 

Market Nicher (Specialist): These firms specialize in serving market niches, focusing on sub-segments rather than the whole market.

 

The correct matching code is therefore (A) a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii).

(a) Market Leader matches with (iv) Attack the market

(b) Market Challenger matches with (ii) Attack the market leader

(c) Market Follower matches with (i) Avoid hostile attacks on rivals

(d) Market Nicher matches with (iii) Provide a high level of specialization

Question 33
A strategy practiced in high-tech industries where the challenger patiently researches and develops the next technology and launches an attack, shifting the battleground to its territory, where it has an advantage is which type of market Challengers Strategies?
  • A.Bypass attack
  • B.Guerilla attack
  • C.Flank attack
  • D.Frontal attack
Correct Answer: Bypass attack

We can distinguish five attack strategies used by Market Challengers: 

1. Frontal Attack: In a pure frontal attack, the attacker matches its opponent's product, advertising, price, and distribution. 

2. Flank Attack: An enemy's weak spots are natural targets. A flank attack can be directed along two strategic dimensions— geographic and segmental. 

3. Encirclement Attack: The encirclement maneuver is an attempt to capture a wide slice of the enemy's territory through number of attacks. It involves launching a grand offensive on several fronts. Encirclement makes sense when the challenger commands superior resources and believes a swift encirclement will break the opponent's will. 

4. Bypass Attack: Technological leapfrogging is a bypass strategy practiced in high-tech industries. The challenger patiently researches and develops the next technology and launches an attack, shifting the battleground to its territory, where it has an advantage. 

5. Guerilla Attacks: Small, intermittent attacks to harass and demoralize the opponent.

Question 34
Match the following items of List-I (sources of competition) with List-II (examples for these sources of competition) and indicate the code of correct matching.List – Ia. Directly similar productsb. Available substitutesc. Unrelated productsList – IIi. OLA Taxi and Metro Railii. Mercedes and BMWiii. PVR and Amusement ParkCodes:
  • A.a-iii, b-ii, c-i
  • B.a-i, b-iii, c-ii
  • C.a-i, b-ii, c-iii
  • D.a-ii, b-i, c-iii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-i, c-iii

Directly similar products- directly similar products are the products which serves same purpose, have exactly same attributes and appearance is almost same. Mercedes and BMW cars are elite premium cars, comes under same category the features in both may vary a little.

 

Available substitutes- available substitutes are the products which in which the absence of one product is compensated by another substitute product, there is also a possibility that a person is having a choice between both the substitutes. OLA taxi and Metro rail are both public transport options available for traveling, though they may vary in features and price.

 

Unrelated products- unrelated products are the set of products which serves different purposes and not provide similar services. Like in case of PVR and Amusement Park, the PVR is a multiplex for watching movies on big screen and enjoying snacks while an amusement park provides recreational fun activities and games.

Question 35
Match the following: (UGC NET Management Sep 2013)List – I (Statements)a. Attacking the weak spots of thecompetitorb. Avoiding the main competitor and attacking easier ones.c. Attacking the leader on several areas.d. Attacking the leader on its strong area.List – II (Terms)1. Flank attack2. Frontal attack3. Encirclement attack4.By PassattackCodes:
  • A.a-1 b-4 c-3 d-2
  • B.a-1 b-3 c-2 d-4
  • C.a-2 b-3 c-1 d-4
  • D.a-3 b-1 c-2 d-4
Correct Answer: a-1 b-4 c-3 d-2

1. Frontal Attack: In a pure frontal attack, the attacker matches its opponent's product, advertising, price, and distribution.

 

2. Flank Attack: An enemy's weak spots are natural targets. A flank attack can be directed along two strategic dimensions— geographic and segmental.

 

3. Encirclement Attack: The encirclement maneuver is an attempt to capture a wide slice of the enemy's territory through number of attacks. It involves launching a grand offensive on several fronts. Encirclement makes sense when the challenger commands superior resources and believes a swift encirclement will break the opponent's will.

 

4. Bypass Attack: Technological leapfrogging is a bypass strategy practiced in high-tech industries. The challenger patiently researches and develops the next technology and launches an attack, shifting the battleground to its territory, where it has an advantage.

Question 36
When the total market expands, the _________ usually gains the most. (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.Market challenger
  • B.Market leader
  • C.Market follower
  • D.Marketnicher
Correct Answer: Market follower

The correct answer is (C) Market follower.

 

When the total market expands, it's typically the market followers who stand to gain the most. Market followers benefit from the growth of the overall market because they can capture a portion of the increased demand without having to be as aggressive as market challengers or market leaders. They often learn from the market leader's experience and can copy or improve on the leader's products and programs with fewer resources. This allows them to enjoy increased sales and profitability as the market expands.

Question 37
In this attack strategy, the marketer must back it with a stronger attack to beat the opponent. Identify the strategy. (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Encirclement
  • B.Flank
  • C.Frontal
  • D.Guerrilla
Correct Answer: Guerrilla

The correct answer is (D) Guerrilla.

 

Guerilla Attacks: Small, intermittent attacks to harass and demoralize the opponent.

 

Frontal Attack: In a pure frontal attack, the attacker matches its opponent's product, advertising, price, and distribution. 

 

Flank Attack: An enemy's weak spots are natural targets. A flank attack can be directed along two strategic dimensions- geographic and segmental. 

 

Encirclement Attack: The encirclement manoeuvre is an attempt to capture a wide slice of the enemy's territory through number of attacks. It involves launching a grand offensive on several fronts. Encirclement makes sense when the challenger commands superior resources and believes a swift encirclement will break the opponent's will. 

 

Bypass Attack: Technological leapfrogging is a bypass strategy practiced in high-tech industries. The challenger patiently researches and develops the next technology and launches an attack, shifting the battleground to its territory, where it has an advantage.

Question 38
Michael Porter has identified five forces that determine the intrinsic long-run attractiveness of a market or market segment. Which of the following is NOT a force?(i) Threat of intense segment rivalry(ii) Threat of new entrants(iii) Threat of substitute products(iv) Threat of buyers’ growing bargaining power(v) Threat of suppliers’ growing bargaining powerCodes
  • A.(i) only
  • B.(i) and (v) only
  • C.(v) only
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

Michael Porter has identified 5 forces that determine the intrinsic long-run attractiveness of a market or market segment. The threats these forces pose are as follows:

 

(i) Threat of intense segment rivalry: A segment is unattractive if it already contains numerous, strong, or aggressive competitors. These conditions will lead to frequent price wars, advertising battles, and new-product introductions and will make it expensive to compete.

 

(ii) Threat of new entrants: The most attractive segment is one in which entry barriers are high and exit barriers are low. Few new firms can enter the industry, and poorly performing firms can easily exit. When both entry and exit barriers are high, profit potential is high, but firms face more risk because poorer-performing firms stay in and fight it out. When both entry and exit barriers are low, firms easily enter and leave the industry, and returns are stable but low. The worst case is when entry barriers are low and exit barriers are high: Here firms enter during good times but find it hard to leave during bad times. The result is chronic overcapacity and depressed earnings for all.

 

(iii) Threat of substitute products: A segment is unattractive when there are actual or potential substitutes for the product. Substitutes place a limit on prices and on profits. If technology advances or competition increases in these substitute industries, prices and profits are likely to fall.

 

(iv) Threat of buyers’ growing bargaining power: A segment is unattractive if buyers possess strong or growing bargaining power. Buyers’ bargaining power grows when they become more concentrated or organized, when the product represents a significant fraction of their costs, when the product is undifferentiated, when buyers’ switching costs are low, when buyers are price-sensitive because of low profits, or when they can integrate upstream.

 

(v) Threat of suppliers’ growing bargaining power: A segment is unattractive if the company’s suppliers are able to raise prices or reduce quantity supplied. Suppliers tend to be powerful when they are concentrated or organized, when they can integrate downstream, when there are few substitutes, when the supplied product is an important input, and when the costs of switching suppliers are high. The best defenses are to build win-win relationships with suppliers or use multiple supply sources.

Question 39
Marketers classify industries according to(i) Number of sellers(ii) Degree of product differentiation(iii) Entry or exit barriers(iv) Degree of vertical integration(v) Degree of vertical globalizationChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii) and (v)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii) and (v)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iv) and (v)
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Marketers classify industries based on several key factors to understand their dynamics and competitive landscape:

 

Number of sellers: This factor looks at how many companies are actively competing in a particular industry. It helps determine the level of competition and market structure.

 

Degree of product differentiation: This refers to how similar or distinct products or services within an industry are from each other. It affects a company's competitive positioning and strategy.

 

Entry or exit barriers: Entry barriers are obstacles that make it hard for new companies to enter an industry, while exit barriers make it challenging for existing companies to leave. Understanding these barriers is vital for assessing the potential for new competition.

 

Degree of vertical integration: This relates to how much control a company has over different stages of its supply chain, from raw materials to distribution. It can impact market dynamics and competitive advantages.

 

Degree of vertical globalization: This assesses how extensively a company operates internationally, especially in terms of sourcing materials and serving global markets. Globalization is a crucial aspect in today's interconnected business world.

 

Marketers use these criteria to categorize industries, helping them gain insights into competition, opportunities, and challenges within each sector. These classifications aid in strategic decision-making and understanding the unique characteristics of various markets.

Question 40
Seeking head-to-head battles with competitors based largely on incremental improvements in cost, quality, or both is known as _________. Creating products and services for which there are no direct competitors is known as _______.
  • A.Black-ocean strategy; Green-ocean strategy
  • B.Red-ocean strategy; Green-ocean strategy
  • C.Red-ocean strategy; Blue-ocean strategy
  • D.Black-ocean strategy; Blue-ocean strategy
Correct Answer: Red-ocean strategy; Blue-ocean strategy

The correct answer is (C) Red-ocean strategy; Blue-ocean strategy.

 

Red-ocean strategy: This refers to seeking head-to-head battles with competitors in existing markets. It typically involves competing on factors like cost, quality, and incremental improvements. Red oceans represent competitive and often saturated market spaces where companies vie for the same customers and market share. The "red" symbolizes the fierce competition, often resulting in reduced profits.

 

Blue-ocean strategy: This involves creating products or services for which there are no direct competitors. It's about exploring untapped market spaces or creating new demand, rather than competing in crowded, red oceans. Blue oceans represent new and uncontested market areas where companies can enjoy higher profits and growth without intense rivalry.

Question 41
Which of the following is NOT a variable that needs to be considered whenanalyzingpotential threats posed by competitors?
  • A.Share of hands
  • B.Share of mind
  • C.Share of market
  • D.Share of heart
Correct Answer: Share of hands

The correct answer is (A) Share of hands.

 

When analyzing potential threats posed by competitors, "Share of hands" is not typically considered as a variable. The other options, "Share of mind," "Share of market," and "Share of heart," are commonly used terms in marketing and competitive analysis:

  • Share of mind: Refers to how much space a brand or product occupies in the minds of consumers. It is related to brand awareness and perception.
  • Share of market: Indicates a company's or brand's portion of the total market sales, often expressed as a percentage.
  • Share of heart: Represents the emotional connection and loyalty that consumers have toward a brand or company.
Question 42
Hamel and Prahalad suggest core competencies are the basis of competitive advantage. What is a 'core competence'?
  • A.An ability to do something which all organizations must possess (i.e.it is 'core' to that business) in order to satisfy customer needs
  • B.The basic skills set that an employee needs to function effectively in a given role
  • C.The basic organizational strengths that relate to the core business rather than other areas of business the organization is developing
  • D.A group of production skills and technologies that enable an organization to provide a particular benefit to customers
Correct Answer: A group of production skills and technologies that enable an organization to provide a particular benefit to customers

Core Competencies are those capabilities that are critical to a business achieving competitive advantage. The concept in management theory was originally advocated by CK Prahalad, and Gary Hamel. In their view, a core competency is a specific factor that a business sees as being central to the way it, or its employees, works. It fulfills three key criteria:

 

1. Provide access to a wide variety of markets

2. Contribute significantly to the end-product benefits

3. Be difficult for competitors to imitate

 

Core competencies are what make your organization unique. They are the skills your organization possesses that set it apart from its peers. They are the sources of competitive advantage. They are the building blocks to future opportunities.

Question 43
Which of the following alternatives represents the Five - Forces Model of Competition developed by Michael Porter?
  • A.Suppliers, buyers, competitive rivalry among firms in industry, product substitutes and potential entrants.
  • B.Employees, buyers, competitive rivalry among firms in industry, product substitutes and potential entrants.
  • C.Suppliers, buyers, employees, product substitutes and potential entrants.
  • D.Buyers, employees, suppliers, product substitutes and potential entrants
Correct Answer: Suppliers, buyers, competitive rivalry among firms in industry, product substitutes and potential entrants.

The correct answer is (A) Suppliers, buyers, competitive rivalry among firms in the industry, product substitutes, and potential entrants.

 

The Five Forces Model of Competition, developed by Michael Porter, is a framework used to analyze the competitive forces within an industry. These five forces are:

  • Suppliers: This force assesses the power suppliers have in the industry. Suppliers can influence pricing and the availability of key inputs.
  • Buyers: This force examines the power of buyers (customers) in the industry. Strong buyer power can lead to price pressure and demands for better quality and service.
  • Competitive rivalry among firms in the industry: This force considers the intensity of competition within the industry. High rivalry often leads to price wars and increased marketing efforts.
  • Product substitutes: This force looks at the availability and attractiveness of substitute products or services that could potentially draw customers away from the industry.
  • Potential entrants: This force evaluates the threat of new competitors entering the industry. A high threat of entry can intensify competition.
Question 44
Which of the following is not one of Porter’s 5 Forces Model?
  • A.Threat of New Entrants
  • B.Threat of Substitutes
  • C.Threat of Technology
  • D.Intensity of Rivalry
Correct Answer: Threat of Technology

The correct answer is (C) Threat of Technology.

 

Porter's Five Forces Model focuses on analyzing the competitive forces within an industry. The five forces in the model are:

  • Threat of New Entrants
  • Threat of Substitutes
  • Bargaining Power of Suppliers
  • Bargaining Power of Buyers
  • Intensity of Rivalry

 

"Threat of Technology" is not one of the five forces in Porter's model. The model primarily considers factors related to competition and the industry's structure, rather than technological threats.

Question 45
Which of the following best describes a strategy of differentiation, according to Porter's generic strategies model?
  • A.When an organization has a competency that distinguishes it from other organization in its industry
  • B.When the products are perceived to offer greater satisfaction and for which customers are, consequently, prepared to pay premium price
  • C.When an organization has a widely recognized brand name
  • D.When an organization's products or services offer features that are not offered by competitors' offerings
Correct Answer: When the products are perceived to offer greater satisfaction and for which customers are, consequently, prepared to pay premium price

Porter's Generic Strategies are a set of three competitive strategies proposed by Michael Porter that companies can adopt to gain a competitive advantage in their industry. These strategies focus on creating a unique market position and target a specific customer segment.

 

The three generic strategies are:

 

Cost Leadership Strategy

In this strategy, the company aims to become the lowest-cost producer in its industry. By minimizing production costs and operating efficiently, the company can offer products or services at a lower price than its competitors, attracting price-sensitive customers. The key to success with this strategy is achieving economies of scale, tight cost control, and efficient supply chain management. Walmart is a prime example of a company employing the cost leadership strategy. It has a massive global presence, leverages its purchasing power to negotiate low prices from suppliers, and operates with thin profit margins, allowing it to offer products at competitive prices.

 

Differentiation Strategy

With the differentiation strategy, the company seeks to create a unique and distinctive product or service that stands out in the market. The emphasis is on adding value and offering features or attributes that customers perceive as superior or unique. Differentiation allows the company to charge a premium price for its products or services, attracting customers who value the unique features. Apple Inc. is renowned for its differentiation strategy. The company's products, such as iPhones and MacBooks, stand out for their sleek design, user-friendly interface, and integration of software and hardware, creating a premium brand image and commanding higher prices compared to competitors.

 

Focus Strategy

The focus strategy concentrates on targeting a specific niche market or a narrow customer segment. Rather than trying to appeal to a broad market, the company focuses on understanding the unique needs and preferences of a specific group of customers and tailors its products or services to meet their demands. Rolex is a company that successfully employs the focus strategy. It caters to a specific segment of luxury watch buyers who value prestige, craftsmanship, and exclusivity. By focusing on this high-end niche market, Rolex has built a strong brand image and maintains premium pricing despite strong competition in the luxury watch industry.

 

Stuck in the middle is a situation where a company fails to pursue a clear generic strategy and lacks a competitive advantage. It tries to simultaneously achieve low costs and differentiation without excelling in either, resulting in a lack of clear positioning in the market. Being stuck in the middle can lead to ineffective resource allocation and an inability to compete effectively with firms that focus on a specific strategy.

Question 46
In Porter's 5 forces model, what is meant by the term 'substitute'?
  • A.A substitute is an alternative product or service that performs the same function for the consumer
  • B.A substitute refers to an alternative manufacturing process
  • C.A substitute is something else consumers would rather spend their money on
  • D.A substitute is a rival firm offering the same products
Correct Answer: A substitute is an alternative product or service that performs the same function for the consumer

Porter’s 5 forces model is a tool for analyzing the competition of a business based on five forces:

1. Threat of new entrants

2. Threat of substitutes

3.Bargaining power of customers

4.Bargaining power of suppliers

5.Competitive rivalry

Question 47
Which of the following is NOT included in the 5 forces of competition? (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Bargaining power of suppliers
  • B.Bargaining power of consumers
  • C.Threat of substitutes
  • D.Strategic planning
Correct Answer: Strategic planning

The correct answer is (D) Strategic planning.

 

The Five Forces of Competition, as defined by Michael Porter, focus on the factors that influence competition within an industry. These factors are:

  • Bargaining power of suppliers
  • Bargaining power of consumers (buyers)
  • Threat of substitutes
  • Threat of new entrants
  • Intensity of competitive rivalry

 

"Strategic planning" is not one of the five forces; rather, it is a process or approach that organizations use to develop strategies in response to the competitive forces identified by the Five Forces model.

Question 48
‘Blue Ocean Strategy’ means
  • A.to make competition relevant
  • B.to increase market share
  • C.engaging with competition head on
  • D.making competition irrelevant through value innovation
Correct Answer: making competition irrelevant through value innovation

The correct answer is (D) making competition irrelevant through value innovation.

 

Blue Ocean Strategy is a business strategy framework that emphasizes creating new market spaces with uncontested market space, making competition irrelevant. This is achieved through value innovation, which means offering a product or service that is both unique and has high value to customers. Rather than competing head-on in existing markets (Red Oceans), the goal of Blue Ocean Strategy is to find new, untapped market segments or create entirely new markets where competition is limited or non-existent.

Question 49
Which one of the following is a false statement? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.The most attractive market segment is one in which entry barriers are low and exit barriers are high.
  • B.A market segment is unattractive when there are actual or potential substitutes for the product.
  • C.A market segment is unattractive if buyers possess strong or growing bargaining power.
  • D.A segment is unattractive if the company’s suppliers are concentrated or organized.
Correct Answer: The most attractive market segment is one in which entry barriers are low and exit barriers are high.

Michael Porter has identified 5 forces that determine the intrinsic long-run attractiveness of a market or market segment:

 

1.Segment rivalry: A segment is unattractive if it already contains numerous, strong, or aggressive competitors. It's even more unattractive if it's stable or declining, or if competitors have high stakes in staying in the segment. 

 

2. New entrants: The most attractive segment is one in which entry barriers are high and exit barriers are low. (Few new firms can enter the industry, and poorly performing firms can easily exit) When both entry and exit barriers are high, profit potential is high, but firms face more risk because poorer-performing firms stay in and fight it out. When both entry and exit barriers are low, firms easily enter and leave the industry and the returns are stable and low. The worst case is when entry barriers are low and exit barriers are high (Here firms enter during good times but find it hard to leave during bad times) the result is chronic overcapacity and depressed earnings for all. 

 

3. Substitute products: A segment is unattractive when there are actual or potential substitutes for the product. Substitutes place a limit on prices and on profits. 

 

4. Bargaining power of buyers: A segment is unattractive if buyers possess strong or growing bargaining power. 

 

5. Bargaining power of suppliers: A segment is unattractive if the company's suppliers are able to raise prices or reduce quantity supplied.

Question 50
When a firm improves the quality and increases the price of a product in relation to a competitor making a price reduction, the firm is ___________. (UGC NET ManagementJul2016)
  • A.moving its brand into a higher price-value position
  • B.changing its target market
  • C.moving its brand into a less competitive position
  • D.adversely positioning its product
Correct Answer: moving its brand into a higher price-value position

When a firm improves the quality and increase the price of a product in relation to a competitor making a price reduction, the firm is moving its brand into a higher price-value position as the quality is enhanced and price rises the already established brand is accepted more readily in market.

Question 51
An industry characterized by irregular patterns of stability, rapid technological change, highuncertaintyand global competition can be described as:
  • A.Hypercompetitive
  • B.Hyperactive
  • C.Atypical
  • D.Co-optetive
Correct Answer: Hypercompetitive

In the context of industries characterized by irregular stability, rapid technological advancements, high uncertainty, and intense global competition, they are typically termed as "hypercompetitive" This term, coined by D'Aveni, signifies that in such environments, the business landscape is in a constant state of flux, making it challenging to rely on traditional, long-term strategic planning. Instead, organizations in hypercompetitive industries often need to adopt agile and opportunistic approaches to adapt swiftly to changing conditions. This term emphasizes the exceptionally fast pace and cutthroat nature of competition in these industries, where staying ahead requires constant innovation and adaptability.

Question 52
Michael Porter’s Five Forces Model includes which one of the following combinations? (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)(a) Threat of new potential entrants(b) Threat of substitute product / service(c) Bargaining power of suppliers(d) Bargaining power of buyers(e) Rivalry among current competitors(f) Rivalry among prospective competitorsCodes:
  • A.(a), (c), (d), (e) and (f)
  • B.(a), (b), (d), (e) and (f)
  • C.(a), (b), (c), (e) and (f)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d) and (e)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c), (d) and (e)

The combination (D) includes all the correct factors of Michael Porter's Five Forces Model. Each factor represents a significant aspect of the competitive landscape that affects an industry's attractiveness and potential profitability.

 

(i) Threat of New Entrants: This factor represents the potential of new companies entering the market and increasing competition. High barriers to entry can deter new entrants, making the industry more attractive to incumbents.

 

(ii) Threat of Substitute Product / Service: This factor highlights the possibility of customers switching to alternative products or services that fulfill similar needs. The threat of substitutes can impact an industry's attractiveness.

 

(iii) Bargaining Power of Suppliers: Suppliers can exert power by influencing the availability and cost of inputs. High supplier bargaining power can affect industry profitability by increasing costs.

 

(iv) Bargaining Power of Buyers: Buyers' bargaining power depends on their ability to influence prices and terms. Strong buyer power can affect industry profitability by limiting price levels.

 

(v) Rivalry Among Current Competitors: Intense competition among existing competitors can negatively affect industry profitability. High rivalry often leads to price wars and reduced profits.

Quiz Attempt #119602

Total Questions: 127
Question 1
The concept of Product Life Cycle is based on which of the following key assumptions?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)a. Profits remain stable at different stages of product life cycleb. Products have an unlimited lifec. Product sales pass through distinct stages, each posing different challenges, opportunities and problems to the sellerd. Products require different marketing, financial, manufacturing, purchasing and human resource strategies in each of the life cycle stagese. Products have a limited lifeChoose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.b, c and d only
  • B.a, b and c only
  • C.a, c and d only
  • D.c, d and e only
Correct Answer: c, d and e only

The concept of the Product Life Cycle (PLC) is based on several key assumptions about how products evolve over time. Let’s evaluate each statement:

a. Profits remain stable at different stages of the product life cycle: This is not accurate.
