Material and Parts (A): This category includes raw materials, components, and sub-assemblies that manufacturers use to produce finished products. These materials and parts are often further categorized based on their specific use and characteristics.

 

Capital Items (B): Capital items are long-term investments made by organizations to facilitate their production or operational processes. They include machinery, equipment, buildings, and other assets that are used in the production or operation of goods and services. Capital items are typically significant investments and have a longer lifespan.

 

Supplies and Business Services (D): Supplies and business services encompass a wide range of items and services that are essential for the day-to-day operations of businesses and organizations. This category includes office supplies, maintenance and repair services, office equipment, and other consumables needed to support business activities.

 

"Specialty items" is not a standard classification of Industrial Goods, and it does not represent a distinct category within industrial product classification. Instead, industrial goods are typically classified based on their use (material and parts, capital items), and how they support business operations (supplies and business services).

 

Question 113
Match the followingList I (Industrial Goods)(a) Farm product(b) Component material(c) Natural product(d) Component partList II (Examples)(i) Crude Oil(ii) Cement(iii) Livestock(iv) TiresSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)

The correct matching of Industrial Goods (List I) with their examples (List II) is as follows:

 

Farm product (a) matches with Livestock (iii).

Component material (b) matches with Cement (ii).

Natural product (c) matches with Crude Oil (i).

Component part (d) matches with Tires (iv).

 

So, the correct answer is (C) a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv).

Question 114
Which of the following are categories of Capital Items?
  • A.Component materials and Component parts
  • B.Maintenance items and Operating supplies
  • C.Repair services and Advisory services
  • D.Installations and Equipment
Correct Answer: Installations and Equipment

Option (D) is correct: "Installations and Equipment" are categories of Capital Items. Capital Items are indeed categorized into "Installations" and "Equipment." Installations refer to major infrastructure or facilities required for business operations, while equipment includes machinery and tools used in production or operations. These are significant, long-term investments for organizations.

 

(A) Component materials and Component parts: These are not categories of Capital Items. Component materials and component parts are typically categorized under "Material and Parts" within the classification of industrial goods.

 

(B) Maintenance items and Operating supplies: These items are usually considered as part of "Supplies and Business Services" in the classification of industrial goods, rather than Capital Items.

 

(C) Repair services and Advisory services: These services are not typically classified as Capital Items. Instead, they are generally categorized under "Supplies and Business Services" or "Business Services" in the industrial goods classification.

Question 115
Statement I:Supplies are of 2 kinds, maintenance and repair items and operating supplies.Statement II:Business services include maintenance and repair services and business advisory services.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (A) Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

 

Statement I: Supplies are of 2 kinds, maintenance and repair items and operating supplies.

This statement is correct. Supplies can indeed be categorized into two main types: maintenance and repair items, which are used to keep equipment and machinery in working condition, and operating supplies, which are consumables used in day-to-day operations.

 

Statement II: Business services include maintenance and repair services and business advisory services.

This statement is also correct. Business services encompass a wide range of services that support business operations. Among these services are maintenance and repair services, which help maintain equipment and machinery, and business advisory services, which provide guidance and expertise to organizations in various aspects of their operations.

 

Question 116
Which of the following is NOT a basis for Product Differentiation?
  • A.Customization
  • B.Durability
  • C.Customer training
  • D.Conformance quality
Correct Answer: Customer training

Product differentiation is a marketing strategy that aims to distinguish a product or service from others in the market. It involves highlighting unique attributes or features that make the product stand out and appear more appealing to customers. Product differentiation can be based on various factors, and it plays a crucial role in a company's competitive advantage and branding efforts.

 

Here are some common bases for product differentiation:

Form: This refers to the physical appearance or structure of the product. Different shapes, sizes, colors, or designs can set a product apart. For example, consider the various forms of smartphones available, each with its unique design and screen size.

 

Features: Products can be differentiated by the additional features they offer beyond their core functionality. These features provide extra benefits to customers. For instance, a high-end camera may offer advanced features like image stabilization and multiple shooting modes.

 

Customization: Customization allows customers to tailor a product to their specific preferences or needs. Companies offering customization options create a unique and personal experience for each customer. An example is a car manufacturer that lets buyers choose colors, interiors, and accessories.

 

Performance Quality: Performance quality relates to how well a product performs its intended function. Products can be positioned as high-performance or superior in terms of speed, accuracy, or effectiveness.

 

Conformance Quality: Conformance quality refers to the consistency of a product in meeting established standards and specifications. Customers expect products to reliably meet these standards, and companies that consistently deliver on quality gain a competitive edge.

 

Durability: Durability measures the expected lifespan of a product, especially under various conditions of use. Products with superior durability are often preferred, particularly for items like appliances and machinery.

 

Reliability: Reliability assesses the likelihood of a product malfunctioning or failing within a specified period. Products with a reputation for reliability can build trust and loyalty among customers.

 

Reparability: Reparability evaluates how easily a product can be repaired if it malfunctions. Products that are designed for easy repair may be more attractive to customers concerned about maintenance costs.

 

Style: Style encompasses the aesthetics and visual appeal of a product. It reflects the overall design, look, and feel, which can create a unique identity and attract customers based on aesthetics.

 

Question 117
Statement I:When the physical product cannot easily be differentiated, the key to competitive success may lie in adding valued services.Statement II:Customer consulting is a service differentiation strategy.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (A) Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

 

Statement I is correct because in some industries or markets, physical products may have reached a level of standardization or similarity among competitors. When this happens, it becomes challenging to differentiate products solely based on their physical attributes. In such cases, companies often turn to providing additional services that add value to the customer experience. These services can include things like excellent customer support, warranties, maintenance, or post-purchase assistance. By offering valuable services, companies can set themselves apart from competitors even when the core product is similar.

 

Statement II is also correct because customer consulting is indeed a strategy for differentiating through services. Customer consulting involves providing expert guidance and advice to customers, helping them make informed decisions, solve problems, or optimize their use of the product or service. Companies that offer consulting services demonstrate their commitment to customer success and satisfaction. This can be especially effective in industries where customers may require guidance or have complex needs, such as technology, healthcare, or financial services.

Question 118
_________ returns result from problems or errors by the seller or customer. _______ returns result from the need for customers to actually see, try, or experience products in person to determine suitability.
  • A.Uncontrollable returns; Controllable returns
  • B.Controllable returns; Uncontrollable returns
  • C.Easy returns; Difficult returns
  • D.Difficult returns; Easy returns
Correct Answer: Controllable returns; Uncontrollable returns

The correct answer is (B) Controllable returns; Uncontrollable returns.

 

Controllable returns refer to returns that result from problems or errors that the seller or customer can influence or control. These returns may occur due to issues like product defects, shipping errors, or customer dissatisfaction that can potentially be addressed or resolved through improved processes, quality control, or customer service.

 

Uncontrollable returns, on the other hand, refer to returns that are beyond the direct control of the seller or customer. These returns result from factors such as customers needing to physically see, try, or experience products in person before determining their suitability. This aspect of returns is influenced by customer preferences or circumstances that may vary from one individual to another and are more challenging to manage or predict.

 

Question 119
The Totality of Features that affect how a product looks, feels, and functions to a consumer is known as
  • A.Feature
  • B.Design
  • C.Style
  • D.Blueprint
Correct Answer: Design

The correct answer is (B) Design.

 

The totality of features that affect how a product looks, feels, and functions to a consumer is known as "design." Design encompasses various aspects, including the product's aesthetics, usability, functionality, and overall appearance. It plays a crucial role in shaping a consumer's perception of a product and can greatly influence purchasing decisions. Design goes beyond individual features and considers the holistic experience of using and interacting with a product.

Question 120
Assertion “A”:Design is exerting a stronger influence in categories where it once played a smaller role.Reason “R”:Holistic marketers recognize the emotional power of design and the importance to consumers of how things look and feel as well as work.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

The correct option is (A) Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion (Statement A): Design is exerting a stronger influence in categories where it once played a smaller role.

This assertion suggests that design, which includes the aesthetics, appearance, and overall user experience of products, is becoming increasingly significant in product categories where it previously held less importance. In other words, companies are now placing a higher emphasis on how their products look, feel, and function.

 

Reason (Statement R): Holistic marketers recognize the emotional power of design and the importance to consumers of how things look and feel as well as work.

This reason provides an explanation for the assertion. It states that holistic marketers, which are marketers with a comprehensive approach to understanding consumer behavior, have recognized the emotional impact of design. They understand that consumers not only consider the functionality of a product but also its visual and tactile aspects. Therefore, they prioritize creating products that not only work well but also appeal to consumers on an emotional level.

Question 121
Design thinking is a very data-driven approach with 3 phases that are
  • A.Inspiration, Research and Ideation
  • B.Preparation, Incubation and Evaluation
  • C.Observation, Ideation, and Implementation
  • D.Illumination, Evaluation and Implementation
Correct Answer: Observation, Ideation, and Implementation

Design thinking is indeed a creative and problem-solving approach that typically involves several phases. The correct phases of design thinking are (C) Observation, Ideation, and Implementation.

 

These phases help individuals and teams approach complex problems with empathy, creativity, and a focus on practical solutions.

 

Observation (or empathize): In this phase, designers seek to understand the problem from the perspective of the end-users or customers. They gather insights, conduct interviews, and observe user behavior to empathize with the people they are designing for. This phase helps in defining the real issues and needs.

 

Ideation: During the ideation phase, designers brainstorm and generate a wide range of creative ideas and potential solutions to the identified problem. The goal is to encourage innovative thinking without judgment.

 

Implementation (or Prototype and Test): In the implementation phase, designers create prototypes or models of their ideas. These prototypes are then tested and refined based on feedback from users. The iterative testing process helps in refining and improving the solution.

 

Question 122
Arrange the Product Hierarchy in the correct order from bottom to top.(i) Product family(ii) Item(iii) Product line(iv) Need family(v) Product type(vi) Product classChoose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v), (vi)
  • B.(iv), (ii), (vi), (v), (iii), (i)
  • C.(iv), (i), (vi), (iii), (v), (ii)
  • D.(i), (iii), (ii), (v), (vi), (iv)
Correct Answer: (iv), (i), (vi), (iii), (v), (ii)

The product hierarchy stretches from basic needs to particular items that satisfy those needs.

We can identify 6 levels of the product hierarchy, using life insurance as an example:

(i) Need family — The core need that underlies the existence of a product family. Example: security.

(ii) Product family — All the product classes that can satisfy a core need with reasonable effectiveness. Example: savings and income.

(iii) Product class — A group of products within the product family recognized as having a certain functional coherence, also known as a product category. Example: financial instruments.

(iv) Product line — A group of products within a product class that are closely related because they perform a similar function, are sold to the same customer groups, are marketed through the same outlets or channels, or fall within given price ranges. A product line may consist of different brands, or a single family brand, or individual brand that has been line extended. Example: life insurance.

(v) Product type — A group of items within a product line that share one of several possible forms of the product. Example: Term Life Insurance.

(vi) Item (also called stock-keeping unit or product variant) — A distinct unit within a brand or product line distinguishable by size, price, appearance, or some other attribute. Example: Prudential renewable term life insurance.

 

 

Question 123
A Product _______ is a group of diverse but related items that function in a compatible manner and Product _____ is the set of all products and items a particular seller offers for sale.
  • A.Assortment; System
  • B.System; Assortment
  • C.Line; Class
  • D.Family; Assortment
Correct Answer: System; Assortment

The correct answer is (B) System; Assortment.

 

A Product System refers to a group of diverse but related items that function in a compatible manner. These items often work together or complement each other in some way. For example, a company that sells smartphones, tablets, and laptops might consider these products as part of its "electronics product system."

 

A Product Assortment refers to the set of all products and items a particular seller offers for sale. It represents the range of products available from that seller.

Question 124
Match the following.List I (Dimension)(a) Product mix width(b) Product mix length(c) Product mix depth(d) Product mix consistencyList II (Description)(i) The total number of items in the mix.(ii) The number of different product lines the company carries.(iii) The number of variants are offered of each product in the line.(iv) How closely related the various product lines are in end use.Choose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)

A company’s Product mix has certain dimensions as mentioned below:

 

(i) Width of a product mix refers to how many different product lines the company carries.

 

(ii) Length of a product mix refers to the total number of items in the mix. The average length of a line is obtained by dividing the total length by the number of lines. For example, P&G’s product mix width is 5 (detergents, toothpastes, bar soap, disposable diapers and tissue papers) and the its product line length is 20 (8 types of soaps, 2 types of toothpaste, 5 types of bar soaps, 2 types of diapers and 3 types of tissue papers). Therefore, the average length of P&G’s product mix shall be 4, i.e. (20/5).

 

(iii) Depth of a product mix refers to how many variants are offered of each product in the line. For example, if Tide came in 2 scents (Rose and Lemon), 2 formulations (bar and powder), and 2 additives (with or without bleach), it would have a depth of 8 because there are 8 distinct variants (2 scent x 2 formulations x 2 additives = depth of 8)

 

(iv) Consistency of the product mix describes how closely related the various product lines are in end use, production requirements, distribution channels, or some other way. P&G’s product lines are consistent in that they are consumer goods that go through the same distribution channels.

Question 125
The 4 Product mix dimension (width, length, depth and consistency) allows a company to expands its business in different ways. Which of the following is NOT an expansion way?(i) Add new product lines(ii) Lengthen each product line(iii) Add more product variants(iv) Pursue more product line consistency(v) Pursue global market of existing productsChoose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(iii)
  • B.(iv)
  • C.(v)
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: (v)

The 4 Product mix dimensions (width, length, depth and consistency) permit the company to expand its business in 4 ways:

(i) It can add new product lines, thus widening its product mix.

(ii) It can lengthen each product line.

(iii) It can add more product variants to each product and deepen its product mix.

(iv) It can pursue more product line consistency.

 

Dimensions of Product Mix:

(i) Width of a product mix refers to how many different product lines the company carries.

 

(ii) Length of a product mix refers to the total number of items in the mix. The average length of a line is obtained by dividing the total length by the number of lines. For example, P&G’s product mix width is 5 (detergents, toothpastes, bar soap, disposable diapers and tissue papers) and the its product line length is 20 (8 types of soaps, 2 types of toothpaste, 5 types of bar soaps, 2 types of diapers and 3 types of tissue papers). Therefore, the average length of P&G’s product mix shall be 4, i.e- (20/5).

 

(iii) Depth of a product mix refers to how many variants are offered of each product in the line. For example, if Tide came in 2 scents (Rose and Lemon), 2 formulations (bar and powder), and 2 additives (with or without bleach), it would have a depth of 8 because there are 8 distinct variants (2 scent × 2 formulations × 2 additives = depth of 8)

 

(iv) Consistency of the product mix describes how closely related the various product lines are in end use, production requirements, distribution channels, or some other way. P&G’s product lines are consistent in that they are consumer goods that go through the same distribution channels.

Question 126
Product Line Analysis includes
  • A.Sales and Profit report
  • B.Market Profile
  • C.Product Map
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Product Line Analysis typically includes all of the following:

 

Sales and Profit Reports: These reports provide information on the sales and profitability of each product within the product line. They help in identifying which products are performing well and which may need adjustments or discontinuation.

 

Market Profile: This involves understanding the characteristics of the target market for the product line, including demographics, preferences, and behavior. It helps in tailoring marketing strategies.

 

Product Map: A product map is a visual representation of the product line, showing how different products relate to each other in terms of features, pricing, and positioning. It helps in visualizing the product portfolio and identifying gaps or overlaps.

 

So, the correct answer is indeed (D) All of the above.

 

Question 127
Assertion “A”:Product lines tend to lengthen over time.Reason “R”:Excess manufacturing capacity puts pressure on the product line manager to develop new items.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

Both the assertion (A) and the reason (R) are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion "A" is correct. Over time, product lines often tend to lengthen. This means that companies typically introduce new products or product variations to their existing lines. This expansion of the product line can be driven by various factors, including changing customer preferences, increased competition, and the need to capture additional market segments.

 

Reason "R" provides a valid explanation for Assertion "A." Excess manufacturing capacity is a situation where a company's production capabilities exceed its current production needs. In such cases, there is a financial incentive to utilize the excess capacity efficiently. One way to do this is by developing new products or variations of existing products to fill the capacity gap. Product line managers may feel pressure to introduce new items to make the most of available resources and maintain or increase profitability.

Quiz Attempt #119603

Total Questions: 80
Question 1
Which of the following is not the stage of new product development? (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Idea Generation
  • B.Business Analysis
  • C.Test Marketing
  • D.Market Segmentation
Correct Answer: Market Segmentation

The correct answer is (D) Market Segmentation.

 

New product development is a systematic process that involves several stages to bring a new product to the market successfully. The stages include:

 

Idea Generation: This is the initial stage where a company searches for new-product ideas. These ideas can come from various sources, such as customers, competitors, distributors, and suppliers. The goal is to generate a multitude of ideas, even though only a few will be selected for further development.

 

Idea Screening: In this stage, the company evaluates the generated ideas to identify the most promising ones and eliminate poor ideas. The objective is to reduce the number of ideas and focus on those that hold potential for profitability.

 

Concept Development and Testing: The selected ideas are developed into detailed product concepts, which are presented to potential customers for feedback. This stage helps in refining the product concepts based on customer reactions and preferences.

 

Marketing Strategy Development: Once the product concepts are tested with the target market, the next step is to design the marketing strategy. This involves creating an initial marketing plan that outlines how, when, where, and to whom the product will be introduced.

 

Business Analysis: In this stage, the company conducts a comprehensive review of sales, costs, and profit projections to determine the viability of the proposed product. The analysis ensures that the product aligns with the company's objectives.

 

Product Development: If the product concept passes the business analysis stage, it moves into product development. This phase involves turning the concept into a tangible product through research and development (R&D) or engineering.

 

Test Marketing: Once the product has been developed, it undergoes test marketing in realistic market settings. This allows the company to gain insights into how the product and its marketing strategies perform before a full launch.

 

Commercialization: The final stage is commercialization, where the product is fully introduced to the market. This phase requires substantial investments in advertising and promotion to generate awareness and sales.

Question 2
Which one of the following is a consumer-goods market testing method in which consumers who initially try the product at no cost are reoffered it, or a competitors’ product at slightly reduced price? (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)
  • A.Simulated Test Marketing
  • B.Controlled Test Marketing
  • C.Test Markets
  • D.Sales-Wave Research
Correct Answer: Sales-Wave Research

The market testing method described in the question is "Sales-Wave Research."

 

After successfully passing the concept and product tests, the next phase is test marketing, which involves introducing the product and its marketing strategies into actual market conditions. Test marketing serves as a valuable trial run before the full product launch, allowing companies to gather insights and refine their approach.

 

It is a way for companies to gain hands-on experience with their product and marketing efforts without committing to a full-scale launch.

 

Different Approaches to Test Marketing:

  • Sales-Wave Research: Customers who initially tried the product are offered it again at slightly reduced prices over several instances (sales waves). This method provides insights into customer preferences and satisfaction levels.
  • Simulated Test Marketing: A small group of qualified consumers are exposed to various advertisements, including one for the new product, and their responses are measured. This method helps gauge advertising effectiveness and trial rates.
  • Controlled Test Marketing: The company selects specific stores and geographic locations for testing. A research firm controls factors like shelf position and pricing, while electronic scanners track sales. This approach provides insights into consumer behavior and product performance.
  • Full Test Markets: The product is launched in a select number of representative cities with a comprehensive marketing campaign. This method provides a comprehensive understanding of the product's market performance, including sales and customer reactions.
Question 3
Before performing the business analysis for developing a new product, a company should be engaged in (UGC NET Management Dec 2013)
  • A.Idea screening
  • B.Product development
  • C.Marketing strategy development
  • D.Product positioning
Correct Answer: Marketing strategy development

The correct answer is (C) Marketing strategy development.

 

New product development is a systematic process that involves several stages to bring a new product to the market successfully. The stages include:

 

Idea Generation: This is the initial stage where a company searches for new-product ideas. These ideas can come from various sources, such as customers, competitors, distributors, and suppliers. The goal is to generate a multitude of ideas, even though only a few will be selected for further development.

 

Idea Screening: In this stage, the company evaluates the generated ideas to identify the most promising ones and eliminate poor ideas. The objective is to reduce the number of ideas and focus on those that hold potential for profitability.

 

Concept Development and Testing: The selected ideas are developed into detailed product concepts, which are presented to potential customers for feedback. This stage helps in refining the product concepts based on customer reactions and preferences.

 

Marketing Strategy Development: Once the product concepts are tested with the target market, the next step is to design the marketing strategy. This involves creating an initial marketing plan that outlines how, when, where, and to whom the product will be introduced.

 

Business Analysis: In this stage, the company conducts a comprehensive review of sales, costs, and profit projections to determine the viability of the proposed product. The analysis ensures that the product aligns with the company's objectives.

 

Product Development: If the product concept passes the business analysis stage, it moves into product development. This phase involves turning the concept into a tangible product through research and development (R&D) or engineering.

 

Test Marketing: Once the product has been developed, it undergoes test marketing in realistic market settings. This allows the company to gain insights into how the product and its marketing strategies perform before a full launch.

 

Commercialization: The final stage is commercialization, where the product is fully introduced to the market. This phase requires substantial investments in advertising and promotion to generate awareness and sales.

Question 4
Which one of the following is a consumer goods market testing method in which the company chooses a few representative cities and puts on a full marketing communications campaign, and the sales force tries to sell the trade on carrying the product and giving it good shelf exposure? (UGC NET Management Aug 2016)
  • A.Test markets
  • B.Simulated test marketing
  • C.Sales-wave research
  • D.Controlled test marketing
Correct Answer: Test markets

The correct answer is (A) Test markets.

 

In a test markets approach, a company selects a few representative cities or regions to launch a full marketing communications campaign and test the market response. The sales force works to persuade retailers and trade partners to carry the product and give it prominent shelf exposure. This approach helps the company gauge the actual market response and gather valuable data before a full-scale launch.

Question 5
The step after ‘concept testing’ in the new product development process is (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.Business analysis
  • B.Marketing strategy development
  • C.Product development
  • D.Test marketing
Correct Answer: Marketing strategy development

New Product Development process include following stages:

 

1. Idea Generation – the systematic search for new product ideas.

2. Idea Screening – screening new product ideas to spot good ones and drop poor ones as soon as possible.

3. Concept development and testing – an attractive idea must then be converted into a product concept. Product concept is a detailed version of the idea stated in meaningful consumer terms. Concept testing calls for testing new product concepts with a group of target consumers to find out if the concepts have strong consumer appeal.

4. Marketing strategy development – Designing an initial marketing strategy for a new product based on the product concept. The marketing strategy statement consists of 3 parts. The first part describes the target market, the planned value proposition, and the sales, market-share, and profit goals for the first few years. The second part of the marketing strategy outlines the product’s planned price, distribution, and marketing budget for the first year. The third part describes the planned long-run sales, profit goals, and marketing mix strategy.

5. Business Analysis – a review of sales, costs, and profit projections for a new product to find out whether these factors satisfy the company’s objectives.

6. Product Development – developing the product concept into a physical product to ensure that the product idea can be turned into a workable market offering.

7. Test Marketing – the stage of new product development in which the product and its proposed marketing programs are tested in realistic market settings.

8. Commercialization – introducing a new product into the market.

Question 6
Which of the following is not a stage in the new product development? (UGC NET Management Jun 2010)
  • A.Generation of ideas
  • B.Business analysis
  • C.Market segmentation
  • D.Test marketing
Correct Answer: Market segmentation

The stage that is not typically considered a part of the new product development process is: (C) Market segmentation.

 

While market segmentation is an important concept in marketing, it is not a specific stage in the new product development process. The typical stages in new product development include idea generation, idea screening, concept development and testing, business analysis, product development, test marketing, and commercialization. Market segmentation may be considered during the marketing planning and positioning stages that follow the development of the new product.

Question 7
At which stage of the new product development, the launching of new product will take place (UGC NET Management Dec 2010)
  • A.Business Analysis
  • B.Test Marketing
  • C.Commercialization
  • D.Marketing strategy Development
Correct Answer: Commercialization

The "Commercialization" stage is the culmination of the entire new product development process. It's where all the planning, development, and testing come together to bring the product to market. This is when the product is made available to customers, and marketing efforts are at their peak to create awareness, generate interest, and drive sales.

 

Steps in New Product Development Process

 

Idea Generation: In this stage, ideas for new products are generated from various sources, including market research, customer feedback, and brainstorming sessions.

 

Idea Screening: The generated ideas are evaluated, and the most promising ones are selected for further development.

 

Concept Development and Testing: The selected ideas are turned into product concepts. These concepts are then tested with potential customers to gather feedback and refine the product concepts.

 

Business Analysis: During this stage, a detailed analysis is conducted to assess the potential profitability of the new product. Factors such as production costs, pricing, market size, and expected sales are considered.

 

Product Development: Once the concept is deemed feasible, the product is developed. This involves designing and building the physical product, developing prototypes, and conducting product testing.

 

Test Marketing: Before a full-scale launch, some companies choose to conduct test marketing in specific regions or with a select group of customers. This helps gather real-world feedback and identify potential issues.

 

Commercialization: This is the final stage where the new product is officially launched into the market. It involves a coordinated effort to make the product available to customers, including distribution, marketing campaigns, sales efforts, and ensuring that all necessary resources are in place for a successful launch.

Question 8
At which stage of new product development process, the launching of new product will take place: (UGC NET Management Jun 2009)
  • A.Concept development
  • B.Marketing strategy development
  • C.Test marketing
  • D.Commercialization
Correct Answer: Commercialization

The "Commercialization" stage is the culmination of the entire new product development process. It's where all the planning, development, and testing come together to bring the product to market. This is when the product is made available to customers, and marketing efforts are at their peak to create awareness, generate interest, and drive sales.

 

Steps in New Product Development Process

 

Idea Generation: In this stage, ideas for new products are generated from various sources, including market research, customer feedback, and brainstorming sessions.

 

Idea Screening: The generated ideas are evaluated, and the most promising ones are selected for further development.

 

Concept Development and Testing: The selected ideas are turned into product concepts. These concepts are then tested with potential customers to gather feedback and refine the product concepts.

 

Business Analysis: During this stage, a detailed analysis is conducted to assess the potential profitability of the new product. Factors such as production costs, pricing, market size, and expected sales are considered.

 

Product Development: Once the concept is deemed feasible, the product is developed. This involves designing and building the physical product, developing prototypes, and conducting product testing.

 

Test Marketing: Before a full-scale launch, some companies choose to conduct test marketing in specific regions or with a select group of customers. This helps gather real-world feedback and identify potential issues.

 

Commercialization: This is the final stage where the new product is officially launched into the market. It involves a coordinated effort to make the product available to customers, including distribution, marketing campaigns, sales efforts, and ensuring that all necessary resources are in place for a successful launch.

Question 9
Concept testing, test marketing and product testing are parts of which of the following? (UGC NET Management Dec 2019)
  • A.Innovation- Diffusion process
  • B.Product life cycle
  • C.New Product development
  • D.Market development
Correct Answer: New Product development

New Product Development process include following stages:

1. Idea Generation – the systematic search for new product ideas.

2. Idea Screening – screening new product ideas to spot good ones and drop poor ones as soon as possible.

3. Concept development and testing – an attractive idea must then be converted into a product concept. Product concept is a detailed version of the idea stated in meaningful consumer terms. Concept testing calls for testing new product concepts with a group of target consumers to find out if the concepts have strong consumer appeal.

4. Marketing strategy development – Designing an initial marketing strategy for a new product based on the product concept. The marketing strategy statement consists of 3 parts. The first part describes the target market, the planned value proposition, and the sales, market-share, and profit goals for the first few years. The second part of the marketing strategy outlines the product’s planned price, distribution and marketing budget for the first year. The third part describes the planned long-run sales, profit goals, and marketing mix strategy.

5. Business Analysis – a review of sales, costs and profit projections for a new product to find out whether these factors satisfy the company’s objectives.

6. Product Development – developing the product concept into a physical product to ensure that the product idea can be turned into a workable market offering.

7. Test Marketing – the stage of new product development in which the product and its proposed marketing programs are tested in realistic market settings.

8. Commercialization – introducing a new product into the market.

Question 10
Which one of the following categories of customers are opinion leaders who carefully search for new technologies that might give them a dramatic competitive advantage? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Early Adopters
  • B.Innovators
  • C.The early majority
  • D.The late majority
Correct Answer: Early Adopters

The category of customers who are opinion leaders and carefully search for new technologies that might give them a dramatic competitive advantage is typically (A) Early Adopters.

 

Early adopters are individuals or organizations that are quick to embrace and adopt new technologies or innovations. They are often seen as influencers and opinion leaders within their industries and communities. They are willing to take calculated risks to gain a competitive edge and are known for their openness to trying new products or services. As such, they play a crucial role in the diffusion of innovations.

Question 11
After concept testing, a firm would engage in which of the following stage in developing and marketing a new product? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Test marketing
  • B.Marketing strategy/development
  • C.Business analysis
  • D.Product development
Correct Answer: Marketing strategy/development

Eight stages are involved in the new product development process.

1. Idea generation

2. Idea screening

3. Concept development and testing

4. Marketing strategy development

5. Business analysis

6. Product development

7. Market testing

8. Commercialization

Question 12
Which one of the following customers are risk averse, technology shy, and price sensitive? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Early adopters
  • B.Early majority
  • C.Late majority
  • D.Laggards
Correct Answer: Late majority

The customers who are risk averse, technology shy, and price sensitive are typically (C) Late majority.

 

Late majority customers tend to adopt new products or technologies after the majority of the market has already embraced them. They are cautious, skeptical, and often wait until a product has become well-established and its price has decreased before making a purchase.

Question 13
Arrange the following stages in successive order of new product development process. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)a. Concept Development and Testing.b. Marketing Strategy Development.c. Idea Screening.d. Product Development.e. Test Marketing.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a. c, d, e, b
  • B.c, a, b, d, e
  • C.c, a, d, e, b
  • D.a, c, d, b, e
Correct Answer: c, a, b, d, e

The correct sequence of stages in the new product development process is as follows (B) c, a, b, d, e.

 

Idea Screening (c): This is the initial stage where potential product ideas are evaluated and screened to select the most viable ones.

 

Concept Development and Testing (a): Once the ideas are selected, concepts are developed, and testing is done to assess their feasibility.

 

Marketing Strategy Development (b): After testing, the marketing strategy is developed to plan how the product will be introduced and marketed.

 

Product Development (d): The actual development of the product takes place, including design, prototyping, and production.

 

Test Marketing (e): The product is introduced to a limited market to gather feedback and assess its performance.

Question 14
An elaborated version of the idea expressed in meaningful consumer term is called: (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Product image
  • B.Product idea
  • C.Product concept
  • D.Prototype
Correct Answer: Product concept

The correct answer is (C) "Product concept."

 

A product concept is an elaborated version of an idea expressed in meaningful consumer terms. It goes beyond just the basic idea of a product and encompasses how the product will meet consumer needs, what features it will have, and what benefits it will provide. It helps in conveying a clear and comprehensive understanding of the product to potential consumers and stakeholders.

Question 15
Mass media has the maximum impact at which stage of consumer adoption process: (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Adoption
  • B.Awareness
  • C.Evaluation
  • D.Trial
Correct Answer: Awareness

Mass media has the maximum impact at the "Awareness" stage of the consumer adoption process (Option B).

 

During the awareness stage, consumers become aware of the existence of a new product or innovation. Mass media, such as television, radio, newspapers, and digital advertising, play a crucial role in creating awareness by reaching a large audience and providing information about the product's features, benefits, and availability. This exposure in the media helps generate initial interest and curiosity among consumers, making them aware of the new offering and paving the way for further stages in the adoption process, such as evaluation, trial, and ultimately, adoption.

Question 16
Which is the step following the ‘test marketing’ in the process of new product development? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2009)
  • A.Idea Screening
  • B.Prototype Development
  • C.Business Analysis
  • D.Commercialisation
Correct Answer: Commercialisation

The step following "test marketing" in the process of new product development is (D) Commercialization.

 

After conducting test marketing and evaluating the product's performance and consumer feedback, the next step in the new product development process is commercialization. Commercialization involves the full-scale launch of the product into the market. This includes planning the marketing and distribution strategies, setting pricing, and making the product available to consumers on a broader scale.

Question 17
_________ is an approach to cost reduction that studies whether components can be redesigned or standardized or made by cheaper methods of production without adversely impacting product performance.
  • A.Production Analysis
  • B.Product Value Analysis
  • C.Cost Reduction Analysis
  • D.Product Redesign Analysis
Correct Answer: Product Value Analysis

The buyer determines the needed item’s general characteristics and required quantity. For standard items, this is simple. For complex items, the buyer will work with others—engineers, users—to define characteristics such as reliability, durability, or price. Business marketers can help by describing how their products meet or even exceed the buyer’s needs. The buying organization now develops the item’s technical specifications. Often, the company will assign a product-value-analysis engineering team to the project.

Product Value Analysis (PVA) is an approach to cost reduction that studies whether components can be redesigned or standardized or made by cheaper methods of production without adversely impacting product performance. The PVA team will identify over-designed components, for instance, that last longer than the product itself. Tightly written specifications allow the buyer to refuse components that are too expensive or that fail to meet specified standards.

Question 18
Based on Malcolm Gladwell’s research, Chip and Dan Heath, identified 6 traits that characterize all great ideas and used the acronym “SUCCES” to organize them. SUCCES stands for
  • A.Sophisticated, Unclear, Cohesive, Concrete, Extra, Success
  • B.Storage, Unpacking, Catchy, Conceptual, Expectation, Surreal
  • C.Simple, Unexpected, Concrete, Credibility, Emotion, Stories
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Simple, Unexpected, Concrete, Credibility, Emotion, Stories

Picking up on a concept first introduced by Malcolm Gladwell in his Tipping Point book, brothers Chip and Dan Heath set out to uncover what makes an idea sticky and catch on with an audience. They identified 6 traits that characterize all great ideas and used the acronym “SUCCES” to organize them:

(i) Simple: find the core of any idea. Take an idea and distill it down, whittling away everything that is not essential.

(ii) Unexpected: grab people’s attention by surprising them.

(iii) Concrete: make sure any idea can be easily grasped and remembered later.

(iv) Credibility: give an idea believability. Indian overnight delivery service.

(v) Emotion: help people see the importance of an idea.

(vi) Stories: empower people to use an idea through narrative

Question 19
Who gave the term "innovative imitation"?
  • A.Peter Drucker
  • B.Adam Smith
  • C.Seth Godin
  • D.Theodore Levitt
Correct Answer: Theodore Levitt

Theodore Levitt gave the term "innovative imitation". He argues that a strategy of product imitation might be as profitable as a strategy of product innovation. In “innovative imitation,” the innovator bears the expense of developing the new product, getting it into distribution, and informing and educating the market. The reward for all this work and risk is normally market leadership. However, another firm can come along and copy or improve on the new product. Although it probably will not overtake the leader, the follower can achieve high profits because it did not bear any of the innovation expense.

Question 20
Consider the following given statements and state what are some of the primary reasons for failure of a newly launched product?i) Fragmented Marketsii) The idea is good but market size is over estimatediii) Development costs are higher than expectediv) Considerable focus on product promotion in introduction stagev) Shorter product life cyclevi) social and governmental constraints
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • B.(vi), (v), (iv) and (iii)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii), (v) and (vi)
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii), (v) and (vi)

A new product may fail for many reasons. Most often, companies fail to offer a unique benefit or underestimate the competition. Specific reasons are:

 

1. A high-level executive pushes a favorite idea through in spite of negative market research findings.

2. The idea is good but the market size is over-estimated.

3. The product is not well designed.

4. The product is incorrectly positioned in the market, not advertised effectively or over-priced.

5. Development costs are higher than expected.

6. Competitors fight back harder than expected.

7. Shortage of important ideas in certain areas.

8. Fragmented markets

9. Social and governmental constraints.

10. Costliness of the development process.

11. Capital shortages

12. Faster required development time

13. Shorter product life cycle

Question 21
What are the techniques for stimulating creativity in individuals and groups for a New Product Development?
  • A.Mind Mapping
  • B.Attribute Listing
  • C.Morphological Analysis
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The correct answer is (D) All of the above.

 

Here is a list of techniques for stimulating creativity in individuals and groups:

Attribute listing: List the attributes of an object, such as a screwdriver. Then modify each attribute, such as replacing the wooden handle with plastic, providing torque power, adding different screw heads, and so on. 

 

Forced relationships: Lists several ideas and consider each one in relation to each other one. In designing new office furniture for example, consider a desk, bookcase, and filling cabinet as separate ideas. One can then imagine a desk with a built in bookcase or a desk with built in files or a, bookcase with built in files. 

 

Morphological analysis: Start with a problem such as “getting something from one place to another via a powered vehicle.” Now think of dimensions, such as the type of platform (cart, chair, sling, bed), the medium (air, water, oil, rails), and the power source (compressed air, electric motor, magnetic fields). By listing every possible combination, one can generate many new solutions. 

 

Reverse assumption analysis: List all the normal assumptions about an entity and then reverse them. Instead of assuming that a restaurant has menus, charges for food, and serves food, reverse each assumption. The new restaurant may decide to serve only what the chef bought that morning and cooked; may provide some food and charge only for how long the persons sits at the table; and may design an exotic atmosphere ad rent out the space to people who bring their own food and beverages. 

 

New contexts: Take familiar processes, such as people helping services, and put them into a new context. Imagine helping dogs and cats instead of people with day care service, stress reduction, psychotherapy, animal funerals, and so on. As another example, instead of hotel guests going to the front desk to check in, greet them at curbside and use wireless device to register them.

 

Mind mapping: Start with a thought such as a car, write it on a piece of paper, then think of the next though that comes up (say Mercedes), link it to car, then think of the next association (Germany) and do this with all associations that comes up with each new word. Perhaps a whole new idea will materialize.

Question 22
To speed up their product development cycles, many companies are now adopting a faster, more agile, team-oriented approach called:
  • A.Translational product development approach
  • B.Simultaneous product development approach
  • C.Alternate product development approach
  • D.Mass product development approach
Correct Answer: Simultaneous product development approach

The correct answer is (B) Simultaneous product development approach.

 

The "Simultaneous Product Development Approach" is a strategy used by companies to speed up product development cycles. In this approach, various stages of product development, such as design, engineering, and manufacturing, occur simultaneously rather than sequentially. This approach emphasizes cross-functional collaboration and concurrent work on different aspects of the product, allowing for faster and more efficient development.

Question 23
Which of the following is NOT a reason for the failure of New Products? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.Good idea but overestimated market size.
  • B.Correctly positioned new product, not promoted effectively or overpriced.
  • C.Development costs are lower than or equal to estimated or expected.
  • D.Competitors fight back harder than expected.
Correct Answer: Development costs are lower than or equal to estimated or expected.

If development costs are lower than or equal to estimated or expected then it is actually a good thing as it will help in launching the product in right time and at right price. A product may fail if competitors fight back harder than expected, correctly positioned new product, not promoted effectively or overpriced, good idea but overestimated market size.

Question 24
Which of the stages of New Product Development process can be skipped? (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Business analysis
  • B.Idea screening
  • C.Product testing
  • D.Test marketing
Correct Answer: Test marketing

In the New Product Development (NPD) process, there are several crucial stages that guide the creation and launch of a new product. These stages help evaluate the feasibility, viability, and market readiness of a product idea. Among these stages, the one that can be skipped is the "Test Marketing" stage.

 

The 8 stages of the NPD process are as follows:

 

Idea Generation: This is the initial stage where product ideas are generated from various sources.

 

Idea Screening: In this stage, the feasibility and compatibility of the product idea with company objectives are evaluated, and most unsuitable ideas are eliminated.

 

Concept Development and Testing: Potential product concepts are developed and tested with target consumers to assess their appeal and viability.

 

Marketing Strategy Development: A preliminary marketing strategy plan is created, outlining the target market, product positioning, pricing, distribution, and marketing budget.

 

Business Analysis: This stage involves evaluating the proposal's business attractiveness, assessing whether the product will meet profit goals, and preparing sales and cost projections.

 

Product Development: Physical product development or reengineering takes place, including prototype development and testing.

 

Market Testing: Market testing involves assessing consumer reactions and behavior when exposed to the new product. However, it is the stage that can be omitted, depending on factors such as product type, risk, and cost.

 

Commercialization: This final stage focuses on launching the product, including decisions about timing, geographic strategy, target markets, and introductory market strategies.

 

The "Test Marketing" stage, as described in the question, involves observing consumer behavior and reactions to the new product in a controlled market setting. It helps determine if the product is likely to succeed when fully launched. However, not all companies undertake this stage, especially if the product is low-risk, familiar to the market, or if there are budget constraints.

Question 25
After conducting the business analysis for developing a new product, a company must do: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Idea generation
  • B.Product positioning
  • C.Product development and testing
  • D.Test marketing
Correct Answer: Product development and testing

8 stages of new product development are:

1. Idea generation

2. Idea screening

3. Concept development and testing

4. Marketing strategy development

5. Business analysis

6. Product development

7. Test marketing

8. Commercialization

 

Here we can clearly see that after conducting the business analysis for developing a new product, a company must perform concept or product development and testing.

Question 26
The people to adopt a new product first are called: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Early adopters
  • B.First users
  • C.Initial adopters
  • D.Innovators
Correct Answer: Innovators

The people who adopt a new product first are called (D) Innovators.

 

Innovators are individuals who are typically among the earliest to adopt and embrace new products or technologies. They are known for their willingness to take risks and try out novel innovations before the broader population. This concept is often associated with the diffusion of innovations theory developed by Everett Rogers, which categorizes adopters into various groups, with innovators being at the forefront of adoption.

Question 27
Which one of the following is informal workplace, sometimes garage, where Intrepreneurial teams work to develop new products?
  • A.Garage teams
  • B.Venture teams
  • C.Skunk works
  • D.Communities of practice
Correct Answer: Skunk works

The term that describes an informal workplace, sometimes located in a garage, where entrepreneurial teams work to develop new products is (C) Skunk works. It is a commonly used term for a small, loosely structured group of individuals who engage in research and development projects focused on technological innovation. These teams often operate independently of a company's regular research and development operations and may have limited resources. Skunk works projects are sometimes kept secret, with the understanding that if the project succeeds, a product will be designed later using the standard development process.

 

Garage Teams are not a recognized term or concept related to entrepreneurial or innovation efforts.

 

Venture Teams typically refer to the group of founders, key employees, and advisers who work together to develop a new venture into a fully-functioning firm. They are essential for bringing a new business idea to life.

 

Communities of Practice are groups of individuals who share a common craft or profession and come together to learn from one another and share knowledge related to a specific field. They are not specifically focused on developing new products but rather on the exchange of expertise within a particular domain.

Question 28
In which stage of New Product Development Process, the product and marketing programs are tested in realistic market settings? (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Concept Development and Testing
  • B.Idea Screening
  • C.Test Marketing
  • D.Commercialization
Correct Answer: Test Marketing

In the New Product Development (NPD) process, the stage in which the product and marketing programs are tested in realistic market settings is (C) Test Marketing.

 

Test marketing is a critical stage in the NPD process where the new product is introduced to a limited market to gather real-world data and feedback. This helps in assessing how the product performs in terms of sales, consumer reactions, and overall market acceptance. It allows the company to make any necessary adjustments to the product or marketing strategies before a full-scale launch, reducing the risks associated with introducing a new product to a broader audience.

Question 29
The following are the statements relating to the new product development. Indicate the statements being correct or incorrect.Statement I:Most established companies do not focus on incremental innovation for New Product Development.Statement II:Most established companies enter new markets by tweaking products for new customers. (UGC NET Management July 2018)Codes:
  • A.Both the statements are correct.
  • B.Both the statements are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct while Statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.

The correct answer is (D) Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: "Most established companies do not focus on incremental innovation for New Product Development."

This statement is incorrect. Many established companies do focus on incremental innovation as part of their new product development efforts. Incremental innovation involves making small improvements or modifications to existing products or processes. It is a common approach to stay competitive, enhance product offerings, and address changing customer needs without completely reinventing the wheel. So, established companies often engage in incremental innovation alongside more radical innovations.

 

Statement II: "Most established companies enter new markets by tweaking products for new customers."

This statement is correct. Established companies often enter new markets by adapting or tweaking their existing products or services to cater to the needs and preferences of different customer segments in those new markets. This approach can help them leverage their existing capabilities and resources while expanding their market reach.

Question 30
In the model of consumer adoption of new products developed by Everitt M. Rogers, the first category of people to adopt a new product is called(UGC NET Management Jun 2014)
  • A.Early adopters
  • B.Initial adopters
  • C.First users
  • D.Innovators
Correct Answer: Innovators

Consumers can be grouped according to how quickly they adopt a new product. On the one extreme, some consumers adopt the product as soon as it becomes available. On the other extreme, some consumers are among the last to purchase a new product. The new product adoption process can be modelled in the form of a bell-shaped diffusion curve.

 

Innovators: Well-informed risk-takers who are willing to try an unproven product. Innovators represent the first 2.5% to adopt the product.

Early adopters: Based on the positive response of innovators, early adopters then begin to purchase the product. Early adopters tend to be educated opinion leaders and represent about 13.5% of consumers.

Early majority: Careful consumers who tend to avoid risk, the early majority adopts the product once it has been proven by the early adopters. They rely on recommendations from others who have experience with the product. The early majority represents 34% of consumers.

Late majority: somewhat skeptical consumers who acquire a product only after it has become commonplace. The late majority represents about 34% of consumers.

Laggards: those who avoid change and may not adopt a new product.

Question 31
Match the following. (UGC NET Management Aug 2016)List – I(a) Market testing(b) Business analysis(c) Product development(d) CommercializationList – II(i) Will this product meet our profit goal?(ii) Have we got a technically and commercially sound product?(iii) Have product sales met expectations?(iv) Are product sales meeting expectations?Codes
  • A.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(ii)
  • B.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iv)
  • D.a-(i) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iv)

The correct code is (C) a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iv).

 

(a) Market testing - (iii) Have product sales met expectations?

During the market testing stage, a company releases the new product to a limited market or audience to evaluate how it performs in terms of sales and customer reception. This question relates to assessing whether the product's sales align with the company's expectations for this initial market exposure.

 

(b) Business analysis - (i) Will this product meet our profit goal?

The business analysis stage involves a detailed evaluation of the proposed product's financial feasibility. This includes analyzing whether the product is likely to meet the company's profit goals, taking into consideration factors such as costs, pricing, and sales projections.

 

(c) Product development - (ii) Have we got a technically and commercially sound product?

In the product development stage, the focus is on creating the actual product, ensuring that it is not only technically feasible but also commercially viable. This question addresses whether the product is both technically and commercially sound, indicating that it meets quality and market requirements.

 

(d) Commercialization - (iv) Are product sales meeting expectations?

During the commercialization stage, the product is launched into the market on a larger scale. This question pertains to assessing whether the product's actual sales in the broader market are meeting the expectations set during earlier stages of development and testing.

Question 32
The principles of Deferment, Autonomy of object, use of Common place, Involvement/detachment and use of metaphor are used for _______. (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)
  • A.Attribute listing
  • B.Brainstorming
  • C.Synectics
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Synectics

The principles of Deferment, Autonomy of object, use of Common place, Involvement/detachment, and use of metaphor are used for Synectics.

 

Synectics is a creative problem-solving and brainstorming technique that involves thinking outside the box to generate innovative ideas and solutions. These principles are key components of the Synectics process, which encourages participants to approach problems and challenges from different perspectives and make unusual connections to spark creativity and innovation.

Question 33
At which stage of New Product Development Process, the launching of New Product will take place? (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Business Analysis
  • B.Commercialization
  • C.Test Marketing
  • D.Marketing Strategy Development
Correct Answer: Commercialization

The stage of the New Product Development (NPD) process at which the launching of a new product takes place is (B) Commercialization.

 

Commercialization is the stage where the new product is introduced to the market on a larger scale for full-scale production and distribution. It involves all the activities necessary to bring the product to market, including setting the timing, geographic strategy, target market prospects, and introductory marketing strategies. This is the stage where the product is made available to customers for purchase and consumption.

Question 34
_______________invites broad communities of people—customers, employees, independent scientists, and researchers, and even the public at large into the new-product innovation process.
  • A.Redesigning
  • B.Market Research
  • C.Value innovation
  • D.Crowdsourcing
Correct Answer: Crowdsourcing

The correct answer is (D) Crowdsourcing.

 

Crowdsourcing is a practice where organizations or individuals solicit ideas, information, or contributions from a large and diverse group of people, often from the general public or online communities, to help solve problems, generate ideas, or contribute to innovation and product development. It involves harnessing the collective intelligence and creativity of a wide range of participants to enhance the innovation process.

Question 35
Which one of the following is a consumer-goods market testing method in which consumers who initially try the product at no cost are reoffered it, or a competitors’ product at slightly reduced price?
  • A.Simulated Test Marketing
  • B.Controlled Test Marketing
  • C.Standard Test Markets
  • D.Sales-Wave Research
Correct Answer: Sales-Wave Research

The consumer-goods market testing method described in which consumers who initially try the product at no cost are reoffered it, or a competitors’ product at a slightly reduced price is (D) Sales-Wave Research.

 

Sales-Wave Research is a market testing method that involves offering consumers the opportunity to try a product for free or at a reduced cost initially and then assessing their response and purchasing behavior over time. This approach helps companies understand consumer reactions and purchasing patterns, providing valuable insights into the potential success of a product in the market.

Question 36
Which one of the following is a consumer goods market testing method in which the company chooses a few representative cities and puts on a full marketing communications campaign, and the sales force tries to sell the trade on carrying the product and giving it good shelf exposure?
  • A.Test markets
  • B.Simulated test marketing
  • C.Sales-wave research
  • D.Controlled test marketing
Correct Answer: Test markets

The Test marketing is a tool used by the companies to check the viability of their new product or a marketing campaign before it is being launched in the market on a large scale. The test marketing is generally carried out to ascertain the probable market success in terms of new product’s performance, the level of acceptance of the product, customer satisfaction, and the efficiency of the marketing campaign. In this, the firm chooses the representative cities where the full-fledged launch of the new product is done starting from the promotion campaign to the ultimate sales. Once it is successful, the firm goes for the national launch.

Question 37
The _________ are somewhat skeptical consumers who acquire a product only after it has become commonplace.
  • A.Innovators
  • B.Late Majority
  • C.Laggard
  • D.Early Adopter
Correct Answer: Late Majority

Consumers can be grouped according to how quickly they adopt a new product. The new product adoption process can be modeled in the form of a bell-shaped diffusion curve, as shown in the figure below:

 

Innovators: Well-informed risk-takers who are willing to try an unproven product. Innovators represent the first 2.5% to adopt the product.

Early adopters: Based on the positive response of innovators, early adopters then begin to purchase the product. Early adopters tend to be educated opinion leaders and represent about 13.5% of consumers.

Early majority: Careful consumers who tend to avoid risk, the early majority adopts the product once it has been proven by the early adopters. They rely on recommendations from others who have experience with the product. The early majority represents 34% of consumers.

Late majority - somewhat skeptical consumers who acquire a product only after it has become commonplace. The late majority represents about 34% of consumers.

Laggards - those who avoid change and may not adopt a new product until traditional alternatives no longer are available. Laggards represent about 16% of consumers.

Question 38
The __________ is the degree to which the innovation may be tried on a limited basis. The ____________ is the degree to which the innovation fits the values and experiences of potential consumers.
  • A.Divisibility, Compatibility
  • B.Compatibility, Divisibility
  • C.Scalability, Fitment
  • D.Fitment, Scalability
Correct Answer: Divisibility, Compatibility

People differ greatly in their readiness to try new products. In each product area, there are “consumption pioneers” and early adopters. Other individuals adopt new products much later. People can be classified into the adopter categories shown in Figure below:

 

Five characteristics are especially important in influencing an innovation’s rate of adoption. They are:

1. Relative advantage: The degree to which the innovation appears superior to existing products.

2. Compatibility: The degree to which the innovation fits the values and experiences of potential consumers.

3. Complexity: The degree to which the innovation is difficult to understand or use.

4. Divisibility: The degree to which the innovation may be tried on a limited basis.

5. Communicability: The degree to which the results of using the innovation can be observed or described to others.

 

Other characteristics influence the rate of adoption, such as initial and ongoing costs, risk and uncertainty, and social approval. The new-product marketer must research all these factors when developing the new product and its marketing program.

Question 39
The _______ are somewhat skeptical consumers who acquire a product only after it has become commonplace.
  • A.Innovators
  • B.Late Majority
  • C.Laggard
  • D.Early Adopter
Correct Answer: Late Majority

The somewhat skeptical consumers who acquire a product only after it has become commonplace are (B) Late Majority.

 

The Late Majority represents a segment of consumers in the diffusion of innovations theory who adopt new products or technologies after the majority of the market has already embraced them. They tend to be cautious and may adopt innovations only when they feel they have become standard or widely accepted.

Question 40
Personal influence is most important at the _____ stage of the Consumer Adoption Process. (UGC NET Management Jun 2014)
  • A.Adoption
  • B.Awareness
  • C.Evaluation
  • D.Trial
Correct Answer: Evaluation

Adopters of new products (consumers) have been observed to move through 5 stages:

 

1) Awareness: consumer becomes aware of new product but has no information about it.

2) Interest: consumer is stimulated to seek information about the innovation.

3) Evaluation: (consumer considers whether to try the innovation.

4) Trial: consumer tries the innovation to estimate its value.

5) Adoption: consumer decides to make full and regular use of new product.

Question 41
Consumers go through 5 stages in the process of adopting a new product:1. Interest2. Awareness3. Trial4. Evaluation5. AdoptionArrange in correct order
  • A.1,2,4,3,5
  • B.2,1,3,4,5
  • C.2,1,4,3,5
  • D.1,2,3,4,5
Correct Answer: 2,1,4,3,5

The consumers go through five stages in the process of adopting a new product:

1. Awareness. The consumer becomes aware of the new product, but lacks information about it.

2. Interest. The consumer seeks information about the new product.

3. Evaluation. The consumer considers whether trying the new product makes sense.

4. Trial. The consumer tries the new product on a small scale to improve his or her estimate of its value.

5. Adoption. The consumer decides to make full and regular use of the new product.

Question 42
34% of the customers who fall in one of the categories of diffusion process who are deliberate customers to accept an innovation just before the average adopter in a social system. Such customers who are above average in social and economic measures, rely quite a bit on advertisements and salesmen are known as: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.Early Adopters
  • B.Early Majority
  • C.Late Majority
  • D.Late Adopters
Correct Answer: Early Majority

The Diffusion of Innovation theory, developed by Everett Rogers, classifies consumers into different categories based on their willingness to adopt a new innovation or product. The categories include:

 

Innovators: These are the first individuals to adopt a new product or innovation. They are risk-takers, often have higher social status, and are willing to experiment with new ideas.

 

Early Adopters: Early adopters are the second group to embrace an innovation. They tend to be opinion leaders in their social circles and are more selective than innovators. They adopt new products before the majority but do so after observing the experiences of innovators.

 

Early Majority: The early majority represents the average consumer. They are cautious and adopt an innovation just before it becomes widely accepted. This group relies on information from early adopters' experiences, advertising, and salesmanship to make their decisions.

 

Late Majority: The late majority is typically skeptical about change and adopts innovations after most of society has already done so. They need substantial reassurance and evidence of an innovation's success before they embrace it.

 

Laggards: Laggards are the last to adopt a new product or innovation. They are resistant to change, often due to traditional values or limited resources. Laggards may only adopt an innovation when it becomes an absolute necessity.

 

In the given question, the customers described as accepting an innovation just before the average adopter and relying on advertisements and salesmen are the "Early Majority" because they fall into this category in the diffusion process. These individuals play a crucial role in the success of new products because their acceptance often marks the point at which an innovation becomes mainstream.

Question 43
Mass media has the maximum impact at which stage of Consumer Adoption Process.
  • A.Adoption
  • B.Awareness
  • C.Evaluation
  • D.Trial
Correct Answer: Awareness

Adopters of new products (consumers) have been observed to move through 5 stages:

(1) Awareness: consumer becomes aware of new product but has no information about it.

(2) Interest: consumer is stimulated to seek information about the innovation.

(3) Evaluation: (consumer considers whether to try the innovation.

(4) Trial: consumer tries the innovation to estimate its value.

(5) Adoption: consumer decides to make full and regular use of new product.

Question 44
Assertion “A”:Highly innovative firms are able to identify and quickly seize new market opportunities.Reason “R”:Highly innovative firms create a positive attitude toward innovation and risk taking.
