People: An essential ingredient to any service provision is the use of appropriate staff and people. Recruiting the right staff and training them appropriately in the delivery of their service is essential if the organisation wants to obtain a form of competitive advantage.

 

Process: Refers to the systems used to assist the organisation in delivering the service. Banks that send out Credit Cards automatically when their customers’ old one has expired again require an efficient process to identify expiry dates and renewal. An efficient service that replaces old credit cards will foster consumer loyalty and confidence in the company.

 

Physical Evidence: Where is the service being delivered? Physical Evidence is the element of the service mix which allows the consumer again to make judgments on the organisation. If you walk into a restaurant your expectations are of a clean, friendly environment.

Question 25
What do you understand by Internal Marketing in a service firm?
  • A.Training service employees in the fine art of interacting with customers to satisfy their needs.
  • B.Orienting and motivating customer contact employees and supporting service employees to work as a team to provide customer satisfaction.
  • C.The chain that links service firm profits with employee and customer satisfaction.
  • D.the action or business of promoting and selling services or products, including market research and advertising to clients and potential clients
Correct Answer: Orienting and motivating customer contact employees and supporting service employees to work as a team to provide customer satisfaction.

The correct answer is (B) Orienting and motivating customer contact employees and supporting service employees to work as a team to provide customer satisfaction.

 

Internal Marketing in a service firm involves activities aimed at orienting, motivating, and aligning employees, especially those who have direct contact with customers, to work cohesively as a team to provide exceptional customer satisfaction. It recognizes that employees are a critical part of the service delivery process and that their attitudes and behaviors can significantly impact customer experiences. Therefore, internal marketing focuses on creating a positive work environment, fostering teamwork, and ensuring that employees are motivated and trained to interact effectively with customers and meet their needs.

Question 26
Which service quality determinant focuses on the appearance of physical facilities?
  • A.Empathy
  • B.Responsiveness
  • C.Tangible
  • D.Reliability
Correct Answer: Tangible

One of the key determinants of service quality, as identified by Zeithaml, Parasuraman, and Berry, is "Tangible." This dimension of service quality focuses on the tangible aspects of the service encounter, particularly the appearance of physical facilities, equipment, personnel, and communication materials. In essence, it relates to the physical evidence that customers can see and touch when they interact with a service provider. Therefore, when evaluating service quality based on tangibles, customers assess how well the service provider's physical attributes and appearance align with their expectations and contribute to an overall positive perception of the service

Question 27
_________ happens when there is disparity between the customers’ needs/ expectations and what the marketers believe them to be.
  • A.Service Gap
  • B.Interpretation Gap
  • C.Standard Gap
  • D.Knowledge Gap
Correct Answer: Knowledge Gap

Gap Analysis for Services

An approach towards achieving conformance in services is to identify various gaps that occur during the service process. Zeithaml, Berry and Parasuraman came up with 4 such gaps that occur during service processing within the organization. They all lead to the most severe gap, that is, the gap between what the customers expected out of a service and what, according to the customers’ perceptions, was eventually delivered. Later market analysts modified this gap model and added 3 more gaps that can possibly occur during a service process.

 

1. Knowledge Gap: This gap may occur at the beginning of the service process, when marketers assess what the customers’ needs and expectations are from a particular service. The gap happens when there is disparity between the customers’ needs/ expectations and what the marketers believe them to be.

 

2. Standards Gap: The next step of the service process is management’s definition of what the target segment needs and expects. This translates into setting down standards to ensure that the service delivery meets those expectations. The gap occurs when there is a disparity between the management’s perceptions and the actual delivery standards that are established by the service provider.

 

3. Delivery Gap: The next step for the service provider is to strive to deliver the service according to its set delivery standards. The delivery gap takes place when the actual performance ability of the service provider does not match the standards set down for service delivery.

 

4. Internal Communications Gap: The next step is for the marketing team to formulate marketing and promotional campaigns. They promote the service on the basis of specific features, quality level and so on. The internal communication gap takes place when the campaigns overpromise. In other words, the promotional campaigns covey more in terms of features, quality, and performance than what the service provider can actually deliver.

 

5. Perceptions Gap: The next step entails the delivery of the service to the customers. The possible gap that may occur at this stage is in terms of what is actually delivered and how customers perceive what is delivered.

 

6. Interpretation Gap: In advance of delivery, the service providers try to communicate certain promises to the customers. The interpretation gap happens when what the service provider promises is interpreted differently by the customers.

 

7. Service Gap: It is the most severe gap that undermines the entire service process. In a way, it is a culmination of the other six kinds of gaps. When there is a disparity between what the customer expected from the service and how he or she perceived the eventual service delivery.

Question 28
Which of the following isNOTa characteristic of a Service that reflects the interconnection between the service firm and its customer?
  • A.Intangibility
  • B.Inseparability
  • C.Homogeneity
  • D.Perishability
Correct Answer: Homogeneity

The characteristic of "Homogeneity" is not a reflection of the interconnection between the service firm and its customer. In services marketing, homogeneity refers to the lack of uniformity or standardization in services, meaning that services can vary in quality and delivery from one provider to another. The other characteristics listed, such as intangibility, inseparability, and perishability, all highlight aspects of the close relationship and interaction between the service firm and its customers.

Question 29
Which of the following is NOT a measure for quality of service for consumer? (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Responsiveness
  • B.Competition
  • C.Empathy
  • D.Tangibility
Correct Answer: Competition

The measure of "Competition" is not one of the dimensions used to assess the quality of service for consumers according to the SERVQUAL framework. SERVQUAL focuses on five key dimensions that customers use to evaluate service quality, which include Responsiveness, Empathy, Tangibility, Assurance, and Reliability. These dimensions are essential for understanding and improving service quality from the consumer's perspective. Competition, while important in a business context, is not a direct measure of service quality as perceived by consumers.

Question 30
Which of the following is NOT a determinant of service quality? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.Reliability
  • B.Responsiveness
  • C.Sensitivity
  • D.Assurance
Correct Answer: Sensitivity

The five dimensions commonly used to assess service quality, as identified by Zeithaml, Parasuraman, and Berry in the SERVQUAL model, are Reliability, Responsiveness, Assurance, Empathy, and Tangibles. "Sensitivity" is not typically considered one of the determinants of service quality in this framework. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer as it is not a recognized dimension in the SERVQUAL model.

Question 31
Match the items of List-I with those of List-II and select the correct answer from the codes given below: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)List – I(a) Everitt M. Rogers(b) J.D. Power(c) Parasuraman, Zeithaml and Berry(d) GronroosList – II(i) Service Quality Model(ii) Three types of marketing for services(iii) Quality rating of automobiles(iv) Diffusion of innovationCodes:
  • A.a-(iii) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • B.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)

The correct match of the individuals in List-I with their contributions in List-II is as follows:

 

(a) Everitt M. Rogers - Diffusion of innovation

(b) J.D. Power - Quality rating of automobiles

(c) Parasuraman, Zeithaml, and Berry - Service Quality Model

(d) Gronroos - Three types of marketing for services

 

So, option (D) is the correct answer.

Question 32
Assertion“A”:Companies must manage service quality by understanding the effects of each service encounter.Reason“R”:Customer’s expectations play a critical role in their service experiences and evaluations.Select the correct codes:UGC NET Management Jan 2017)Codes:
  • A.Both A and R are correct, but R is not the right explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect.
  • D.R is correct but A is incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A

The correct answer is (B) Both A and R are correct, and R is the right explanation of A.

 

Assertion "A" states that companies must manage service quality by understanding the effects of each service encounter. This is correct because managing service quality involves ensuring that each interaction or service encounter with customers meets or exceeds their expectations.

 

Reason "R" states that customer's expectations play a critical role in their service experiences and evaluations. This is also correct because customers form expectations about the service they will receive, and these expectations influence how they perceive and evaluate the actual service encounters.

Question 33
The service marketing mix is an extended marketing mix and includes: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)(i) People(ii) Process(iii) Service(iv) Physical evidenceCodes
  • A.(ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • B.(i), (ii) and (iii)
  • C.(i), (ii) and (iv)
  • D.(i), (iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii) and (iv)

The correct answer is (C) (i), (ii), and (iv).

 

The service marketing mix, often referred to as the "7 Ps of services marketing," includes the following elements:

 

(i) People: People represent the service providers, including employees, staff, and other personnel who interact directly with customers. Their behavior, skills, and competence play a crucial role in delivering high-quality service.

 

(ii) Process: Process refers to the procedures, systems, and methods used to deliver the service. It encompasses the step-by-step processes involved in service delivery, customer interactions, and the overall service experience.

 

(iii) Service: This option is not typically considered a part of the service marketing mix, so it is not included in the traditional 7 Ps. Instead, service is a broader concept that encompasses the entire offering, including the core service, supplementary services, and other intangible aspects.

 

(iv) Physical evidence: Physical evidence refers to the tangible elements associated with the service, such as facilities, equipment, signage, brochures, and any other physical cues that customers encounter during their service experience.

Question 34
Which of the following is not a parameter for SERVQUAL Model given by Parasuraman, Zeithaml and Berry? (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)
  • A.Tangibles
  • B.Reliability
  • C.Empathy
  • D.Insurance
Correct Answer: Insurance

The correct answer is (D) Insurance.

 

The SERVQUAL Model, developed by Parasuraman, Zeithaml, and Berry, is a widely recognized model for measuring service quality. It consists of five dimensions that help evaluate and assess service quality:

 

Tangibles: This dimension assesses the physical appearance of service facilities, equipment, personnel, and communication materials.

 

Reliability: Reliability refers to the ability of the service provider to consistently deliver accurate, dependable, and promised services.

 

Responsiveness: Responsiveness measures the willingness of the service provider to help customers and provide prompt service.

 

Assurance: Assurance focuses on the knowledge, courtesy, and ability of employees to convey trust and confidence to customers.

 

Empathy: Empathy evaluates the caring, individualized attention, and understanding that the service provider provides to its customers.

Question 35
Match the items of List - I with those of List - II(UGC NET Management Dec 2015)List - I(a) Standards Gap(b) Knowledge Gap(c) Perception Gap(d) Interpretation GapList - II(i) Difference between what is, in fact, delivered and what customers perceive they have received(ii) Difference between what a service provider's communication efforts promise and what a customer thinks, was promised by these communications(iii) Difference between what service providers believe customers expect and customer's actual needs and expectations(iv) Difference between management's perception of customer expectations and the quality standards established for service deliveryCodes:
  • A.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(iii) d-(i)
  • C.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iv) d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)

An approach towards achieving conformance in services is to identify various gaps that occur during the service process.

 

Knowledge Gap: This gap may occur at the beginning of the service process, when marketers assess what the customers’ needs and expectations are from a particular service. The gap happens when there is disparity between the customers’ needs/ expectations and what the marketers believe them to be.

 

Standards Gap: The next step of the service process is management’s definition of what the target segment needs and expects. This translates into setting down standards to ensure that the service delivery meets those expectations. The gap occurs when there is a disparity between the management’s perceptions and the actual delivery standards that are established by the service provider.

 

Delivery Gap: The next step for the service provider is to strive to deliver the service according to its set delivery standards. The delivery gap takes place when the actual performance ability of the service provider does not match the standards set down for service delivery.

 

Internal Communications Gap: The next step is for the marketing team to formulate marketing and promotional campaigns. They promote the service on the basis of specific features, quality level and so on. The internal communication gap takes place when the campaigns overpromise. In other words, the promotional campaigns covey more in terms of features, quality, and performance than what the service provider can actually deliver.

 

Perceptions Gap: The next step entails the delivery of the service to the customers. The possible gap that may occur at this stage is in terms of what is actually delivered and how customers perceive what is delivered.

 

Interpretation Gap: In advance of delivery, the service providers try to communicate certain promises to the customers. The interpretation gap happens when what the service provider promises is interpreted differently by the customers.

 

Service Gap: It is the most severe gap that undermines the entire service process. In a way, it is a culmination of the other six kinds of gaps. When there is a disparity between what the customer expected from the service and how he or she perceived the eventual service delivery

Question 36
Service companies face three major marketing tasks: They want to increase their ______, _______ and ________.
  • A.service quality; service attention; service action
  • B.service productivity; service differentiation; service targeting
  • C.service differentiation; service quality; service productivity.
  • D.service management; service quality; service delivery
Correct Answer: service differentiation; service quality; service productivity.

The correct answer is (C) service differentiation; service quality; service productivity.

 

In the context of service marketing, service companies typically aim to achieve three major marketing tasks:

 

Service Differentiation: This involves making their services distinct and unique in some way compared to competitors. Service differentiation helps attract and retain customers by offering something that stands out, such as superior features, customization, convenience, or branding.

 

Service Quality: Ensuring high service quality is crucial for building and maintaining customer trust and satisfaction. Service quality includes meeting or exceeding customer expectations, delivering reliable and consistent service, and addressing any issues or concerns promptly.

 

Service Productivity: Service companies also strive to enhance their service productivity, which means achieving greater efficiency in delivering services while maintaining or improving quality. Improved productivity can lead to cost savings, better resource allocation, and potentially lower prices for customers.

Question 37
If a coaching institute provides some supporting study material along with teaching, then which one of the following service mix categories would it be? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.Hybrid offering
  • B.Major service with accompanying minor goods and services
  • C.Tangible good with accompanying services
  • D.Pure service
Correct Answer: Major service with accompanying minor goods and services

The correct answer is (B) Major service with accompanying minor goods and services.

 

In the context of service marketing, when a coaching institute provides supporting study material along with teaching, it falls into the category of "Major service with accompanying minor goods and services." This category represents a situation where the primary offering is a service (in this case, coaching or teaching), but it is accompanied by additional goods and services (the study material) to enhance the overall value and effectiveness of the service provided.

Question 38
Any act or performance, which one party can offer to another that is essentially intangible and does not result in the ownership of anything is called:
  • A.Satisfaction
  • B.Services
  • C.Outcome
  • D.Gratitude
Correct Answer: Services

The correct answer is (B) Services.

 

In the context of marketing and business, services refer to any act or performance that one party can offer to another. Services are essentially intangible, meaning they cannot be touched or owned like physical goods. Instead, services are activities or processes provided to meet the needs or desires of customers. Examples of services include education, healthcare, consulting, transportation, and many others.

Question 39
Match the following.List I(a) Pure tangible good(b) Tangible good with accompanying services(c) Hybrid offering(d) Pure ServiceList II(i) Restaurant meal(ii) Babysitting, Psychotherapy, or massage(iii) Car, computer or cell phone(iv) Soap, Toothpaste SaltCodes
  • A.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • C.a-(i) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)

The correct matching is:

(a) Pure tangible good - (iv) Soap, Toothpaste, Salt

(b) Tangible good with accompanying services - (iii) Car, computer, or cell phone

(c) Hybrid offering - (i) Restaurant meal

(d) Pure Service - (ii) Babysitting, Psychotherapy, or massage

 

ny offering can have a service component as a minor or major part of total offering. There are 5 categories of offerings based on service component:

 

(a) Pure tangible goods: a tangible good such as soap, toothpaste, or salt that does not requires any accompanying services.

(b) Tangible good with accompanying services: a tangible good, like a car, computer, or cell phone, accompanied by one or more services. Typically, the more technologically advanced the product, the greater the need for high-quality supporting services. 

(c) Hybrid: an offering of equal parts goods and services. For example, Restaurant services; People patronize restaurants for both the food and its preparation.

(d) Major service with accompanying minor goods and services: a major service, like air travel, with additional services or supporting goods such as snacks and drinks. This offering requires a capital-intensive good like an airplane, for its realization, but the primary item is a service. 

(e) Pure service: primarily an intangible service, such as babysitting, psychotherapy, or massage.

 

A Service is any act or performance one party can offer to another that is essentially intangible and does not result in the ownership of anything. Its production may or may not be tied to a physical product. 

 

So, the correct answer is (B).

Question 40
Match the following.List I (Evaluation of Service Quality)(a) Search qualities(b) Experience qualities(c) Credence qualitiesList II (Description)(i) Characteristics the buyer can evaluate after purchase.(ii) Characteristics the buyer finds hard to evaluate even after consumption.(iii) Characteristics the buyer evaluates before purchase.Codes
  • A.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii)

The correct matching is:

(a) Search qualities - (iii) Characteristics the buyer evaluates before purchase.

(b) Experience qualities - (i) Characteristics the buyer can evaluate after purchase.

(c) Credence qualities - (ii) Characteristics the buyer finds hard to evaluate even after consumption.

 

According to the difficulty of evaluation of characteristics, qualities of product and services are divided into 3 categories:

(i) Search Qualities: These are the characteristics the buyer can evaluate before purchase. For example, purchasing of clothes, jewelry or furniture.

(ii) Experience Qualities: These are characteristics the buyer can evaluate only after purchase. This include automobiles, restaurant meals or vacations which can only be evaluate only after use or consumption.

(iii) Credence Qualities: These are characteristics the buyer normally finds hard to evaluate even after consumption. It includes medical diagnosis, auto or TV repair or legal services.

Because services are generally high in experience and credence qualities, there is more risk in their purchase, with several consequences: 

 

(a) Service consumers generally rely on word of mouth rather than advertising. 

(b) They rely heavily on price, provider, and physical cues to judge quality.

(c) They are highly loyal to service providers who satisfy them.

(d) Since switching costs are high, consumer inertia can make it challenging to entice business away from a competitor.

 

So, the correct answer is (A).

Question 41
Match the following.List I – (Characteristics of Services)(a) Perishability(b) Variability(c) Inseparability(d) IntangibilityList II – (Description)(i) Services cannot be stored.(ii) Services cannot be sensed before they are bought.(iii) Quality of two service offerings are not similar.(iv) Services cannot be separated from their providers.Codes
  • A.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • C.a-(i) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(i) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(ii)

The correct matching is:

 

(a) Perishability - (i) Services cannot be stored.

(b) Variability - (iii) Quality of two service offerings are not similar.

(c) Inseparability - (iv) Services cannot be separated from their providers.

(d) Intangibility - (ii) Services cannot be sensed before they are bought.

 

So, the correct answer is (C).

Question 42
Given below are two statements - one is labeled as Assertion and the other is labeled as Reason.Assertion “A”:The service provider’s task is to “manage the evidence" to “tangibilize the intangible.”Reason “R”:Unlike physical products, services cannot be seen, tasted, felt, heard, or smelled before they are bought.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are true and R i s the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true but R is false
  • D.A is false but R is true
Correct Answer: Both A and R are true and R i s the correct explanation of A

The correct answer is (A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion (A): The service provider's task is to "manage the evidence" to "tangibilize the intangible."

This assertion suggests that service providers have a crucial role in making intangible services more tangible. In the context of services marketing, tangibility refers to the ability to perceive or sense something through physical cues. Services, unlike physical products, are intangible, meaning they cannot be seen, tasted, felt, heard, or smelled before a customer buys them. As a result, service providers need to create tangible evidence or cues that help customers understand, evaluate, and trust the service being offered. This might include aspects such as the appearance of facilities, the behavior of service personnel, or the quality of promotional materials—all of which contribute to making the service seem more real and reliable.

 

Reason (R): Unlike physical products, services cannot be seen, tasted, felt, heard, or smelled before they are bought.

This reason highlights the inherent nature of services—they lack the physical attributes that tangible products possess. Customers can't physically examine or experience a service before deciding to purchase it. Instead, they rely on other cues and information provided by the service provider to assess its quality and value.

 

Both the assertion and the reason are correct, and there is a logical relationship between them. The reason (R) explains why assertion (A) is valid. Since services are intangible and cannot be directly sensed or evaluated in advance, service providers must manage the evidence or tangible elements associated with the service to help customers understand and trust what they are purchasing. This relationship underscores the importance of tangibilizing the intangible in service marketing.

Question 43
Since the services are perishable, we have to manage their availability on both demand and supply sides. Which of the following example is NOT considered for managing Demand Side?
  • A.Hotels adopting IT reservation system for bookings
  • B.Amusement Park buying land for later development
  • C.Differential pricing of Movie tickets, as per days of week
  • D.ATM Machines in Bank Branches as Complementary Services.
Correct Answer: Amusement Park buying land for later development

The correct answer is (B) Amusement Park buying land for later development. This option is not related to demand-side management. Buying land for later development is more about expanding the physical infrastructure of the amusement park, which is a supply-side consideration, rather than managing existing demand.

 

The question is about managing the availability of services on the demand side. Demand-side management in services refers to strategies and practices that organizations implement to align service capacity with fluctuations in customer demand. In other words, it involves measures taken to ensure that services are available when and where customers want them.

 

(A) Hotels adopting IT reservation systems for bookings: This is a demand-side management technique as it allows hotels to manage their room availability based on customer demand. Customers can book rooms in advance, ensuring that they have a place to stay when they need it.

 

(C) Differential pricing of movie tickets as per days of the week: This is a demand-side strategy where movie theaters adjust ticket prices based on the days of the week to match customer demand. It encourages customers to choose less crowded days for movies.

 

(D) ATM machines in bank branches as complementary services: This is also related to demand-side management. Banks place ATMs in branches to make banking services available to customers when they need to withdraw cash, check balances, or perform other transactions.

Question 44
Match the following.List I(a) External Marketing(b) Internal Marketing(c) Interactive MarketingList II(i) Preparing, pricing, distributing and promoting the service to customers.(ii) Service is judged not only by its technical quality but also by its functional quality.(iii) Training and motivating employees.Codes
  • A.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii)
  • B.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)
  • D.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii)

Marketing excellence with services requires excellence in 3 broad areas: external, internal, and interactive marketing.

(a) External marketing describes the normal work of preparing, pricing, distributing, and promoting the service to customers.

(b) Internal marketing means orienting and motivating customer-contact employees and supporting service employees to work as a team to provide customer satisfaction. The most important task, marketing department have to do is to get everyone in the organization to practice marketing.

(c) Interactive marketing describes the employees’ skill in serving the client. Clients judge service not only by its technical quality, but also by its functional quality. For example, for doctors, surgery performed by him is technical quality of the service but the concern and confidence that they built in the patient is functional quality of the service

Question 45
Given below are two statements - one is labeled as Assertion and the other is labeled as Reason:Assertion “A”:Customers who view a service as fairly homogeneous care less about the provider than about the price.Reason “R”:Marketing excellence requires service marketers to continually differentiate their brands so they are not seen as a commodity.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true but R is false
  • D.A is false but R is true
Correct Answer: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

The correct answer is (A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion (A) states that customers who view a service as fairly homogeneous care less about the provider than about the price. This means that when customers perceive little differentiation between service providers, they are likely to make their decisions primarily based on price. In such cases, customers might choose the service that offers the lowest price, as there are no significant distinguishing factors between providers.

 

Reason (R) explains that marketing excellence requires service marketers to continually differentiate their brands so they are not seen as a commodity. This means that to succeed in a competitive market where services are seen as similar, service providers must work on creating a distinct brand identity and offering unique features or value propositions that set them apart from competitors. By doing so, they can avoid being perceived as generic or interchangeable service providers.

 

The relationship between (A) and (R) is that (A) highlights the behavior of customers when services are homogeneous, while (R) provides the strategic response that service marketers should undertake in such situations. When services lack differentiation, customers tend to focus on price, which is why service providers need to invest in differentiation strategies to maintain their competitiveness.

Question 46
Match the following.List I- (Determinants of service quality)(a) Reliability(b) Assurance(c) Responsiveness(d) TangiblesList II – (Description)(i) To help customers and provide prompt service.(ii) Ability to convey trust and confidence.(iii) The appearance of physical facilities.(iv) To perform the promised service dependably and accurately.Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)

The correct match between List I (Determinants of service quality) and List II (Description) is as follows:

 

(a) Reliability: To perform the promised service dependably and accurately.

(b) Assurance: Ability to convey trust and confidence.

(c) Responsiveness: To help customers and provide prompt service.

(d) Tangibles: The appearance of physical facilities.

 

So, the correct answer is (A) a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii).

Question 47
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Customer perceptions and expectations of service quality change over time, but at any one point they are a function of prior expectations.Statement II:Decreasing customer expectations of what the firm should deliver can also lead to improved perceptions of overall service quality.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

the correct answer is (A) Statement I is correct, and Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: Customer perceptions and expectations of service quality change over time, but at any one point they are a function of prior expectations.

This statement is correct because customers' perceptions and expectations of service quality can evolve over time, but they are influenced by their past experiences and expectations.

 

Statement II: Decreasing customer expectations of what the firm should deliver can also lead to improved perceptions of overall service quality.

This statement is also correct. When customers have lower expectations, they are more likely to be pleasantly surprised by the service they receive, leading to improved perceptions of service quality

Question 48
Match the following.List I- (Determinants of Service quality)(a) Reliability(b) Assurance(c) Responsiveness(d) EmpathyList II – (Description)(i) Giving customers individual attention(ii) Providing services at the promised time.(iii) Making customers feel safe in their transactions(iv) Willingness to help customersCodes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i)

List I- (Determinants of Service Quality) and List II – (Description) can be matched as follows:

 

(a) Reliability: Providing services at the promised time. (Matches with ii)

(b) Assurance: Making customers feel safe in their transactions. (Matches with iii)

(c) Responsiveness: Willingness to help customers. (Matches with iv)

(d) Empathy: Giving customers individual attention. (Matches with i)

 

So, the correct matching is (A) a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i).

Question 49
The perceived economic benefits in relationship to the economic costs is called:
  • A.Economic equity
  • B.Consumer equity
  • C.Payment equity
  • D.Perception equity
Correct Answer: Payment equity

Payment equity is the perceived fairness of the level of economic benefits derived from the service usage in relationship to the level economic costs. In other words, customer mentally evaluate the usage of services in terms of amount that he or she paid for it.

Question 50
Who defined Customer Service Interface as “any place at which a company seeks to manage a relationship with a customer, whether through people, technology, or some combination of the two”?
  • A.Al Ries and Fauzia Burke
  • B.Phillip Kotler and Joanna Penn
  • C.Peter Drucker and Seth Godin
  • D.Jeffrey Rayport and Bernie Jaworski
Correct Answer: Jeffrey Rayport and Bernie Jaworski

Jeffrey Rayport and Bernie Jaworski defined Customer Service Interface in the context of incorporating Self-Service Technologies, as any place at which a company seeks to manage a relationship with a customer, whether through people, technology, or some combination of the two. They feel that although many companies serve customers through a broad array of interfaces, from retail sales clerks to Web sites to voice-response telephone systems, the whole often does not add up to the sum of its parts, increasing complexity, costs, and customer dissatisfaction as a result. Successfully integrating technology into the workforce thus requires a comprehensive reengineering of the front office to identify what people do best, what machines do best, and how to deploy them separately and together.

 

Many person-to-person service interactions nowadays are being replaced by Self-Service Technologies (SSTs) for increasing convenience in services. Though, not all SSTs improve service quality, but they can make service transactions more accurate, convenient, cheaper and faster.

Question 51
Given below are 2 statements - one is labeled as Assertion and the other is labeled as Reason:Assertion “A”:Customers do not merely purchase and use a service; they play an active role in its delivery.Reason “R”:Customers words and actions affect the quality of their service experiences and those of others, and the productivity of frontline employees.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true but R is false
  • D.A is false but R is true
Correct Answer: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

The correct answer is (A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion "A" states that customers do not merely purchase and use a service; they play an active role in its delivery. This is true because in many service interactions, customers actively participate and their behavior can influence the quality of service they receive.

 

Reason "R" explains that customers' words and actions affect the quality of their service experiences and those of others, as well as the productivity of frontline employees. This is also true because customers' behavior, feedback, and interactions with service providers can impact not only their own experience but also the experiences of other customers and the efficiency of service delivery.

Question 52
The chain that links service firm profits with employee and customer satisfaction is
  • A.Service Value Chain
  • B.Service Supply Chain
  • C.Service Profit Chain
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Service Profit Chain

The correct answer is (C) Service Profit Chain.

 

The Service Profit Chain is a concept that describes the interconnected relationships between employee satisfaction, customer satisfaction, and a company's profitability. It suggests that satisfied and motivated employees lead to better customer service, which in turn leads to higher customer satisfaction and loyalty, ultimately resulting in increased company profits. This chain illustrates how these factors are linked and how they impact the overall success of a service-oriented business.

Question 53
Which among the following is NOT the key dimension of online service quality as given by academic researchers, Wolfinbarger and Gilly.
  • A.Customer service
  • B.Personalization
  • C.Privacy
  • D.Reliability
Correct Answer: Personalization

The correct answer is (B) Personalization.

 

Wolfinbarger and Gilly identified three key dimensions of online service quality, which are:

  • Customer service
  • Privacy
  • Reliability

 

Personalization is not one of the key dimensions they identified in their research on online service quality.

Question 54
The _________ establishes relationships between profitability, customer loyalty, and employee satisfaction, loyalty, and productivity.
  • A.Internal Marketing
  • B.Service-Profit Chains
  • C.Interactive Marketing
  • D.Service Differentiation
Correct Answer: Service-Profit Chains

The Service-Profit Chain establishes relationships between profitability, customer loyalty, and employee satisfaction, loyalty, and productivity. The links in the chain (which should be regarded as propositions) are as follows:

 

Profit and growth are stimulated primarily by customer loyalty. Loyalty is a direct result of customer satisfaction. Satisfaction is largely influenced by the value of services provided to customers. Value is created by satisfied, loyal, and productive employees. Employee satisfaction, in turn, results primarily from high-quality support services and policies that enable employees to deliver results to customers.

 

Internal Marketing is an element of marketing, it is the task of hiring, training, and motivating able employees who want to serve customers well. It ensures that everyone in the organization embraces appropriate marketing principles, especially senior management.

 

Interactive Marketing describes the employees’ skills in serving the client. In this situation the buyers specify the nature and application of products they wish to buy and sellers try to match these requests almost instantly or in a very short time. A large part of trading over the internet is through interactive marketing.

 

Service Differentiation is the design and delivery of a service to have unique and valuable characteristics relative to other services in the market.

Question 55
Service Marketing
  • A.Empathy
  • B.Responsiveness
  • C.Reliability
  • D.Assurance
Correct Answer: Assurance

The term that explains "the knowledge and courtesy of employees and their ability to convey trust and confidence" is Assurance (Option D).

 

Assurance is one of the five dimensions of service quality as identified in the SERVQUAL model, which is widely used for assessing and measuring service quality. This model helps organizations evaluate the gap between customer expectations and perceptions of service. Each dimension of SERVQUAL represents a specific aspect of service quality.

 

In the context of the given question, "the knowledge and courtesy of employees and their ability to convey trust and confidence" directly relate to the dimension of Assurance. This dimension focuses on the competence, courtesy, credibility, and ability of service providers to instil confidence in customers. When employees are knowledgeable, courteous, and capable of conveying trust, customers feel confident in the service being provided.

 

For instance, imagine a financial institution where the employees are well-trained, have a deep understanding of financial products, and can communicate effectively with customers. They provide accurate information, address customer concerns, and create an environment of trust. In this scenario, the assurance dimension is being effectively met, contributing to a positive perception of service quality.

Question 56
Which one of the following is “the ability to perform the promised service dependably and accurately determinant of service quality”? (UGC NET Management Aug 2016)
  • A.Assurance
  • B.Empathy
  • C.Reliability
  • D.Responsiveness
Correct Answer: Reliability

The correct answer is (C) Reliability.

 

Reliability in the context of service quality refers to the ability to perform the promised service dependably and accurately. It is one of the key determinants of service quality, along with factors like assurance, empathy, and responsiveness. Reliability means that customers can trust that the service will be consistently delivered as promised without errors or disruptions.

Question 57
Match the items of List - I with those of List - II: (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)List - I(a) Standards Gap(b) Knowledge Gap(c) Perception Gap(d) Interpretation GapList - II(i) Difference between what is, in fact, delivered and what customers perceive they have received(ii) Difference between what a service provider's communication efforts promise and what a customer thinks, was promised by these communications(iii) Difference between what service providers believe customers expect and customer's actual needs and expectations(iv) Difference between management's perception of customer expectations and the quality standards established for service deliveryCodes:
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii
  • B.(B )a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii

The correct answer is (A) a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii. This answer aligns the descriptions provided in the content with the corresponding gaps in List - II.

 

Step 1. Knowledge Gap: This gap occurs when there is a disparity between customers' needs/expectations and what the marketers believe them to be. This aligns with the description in List - II (iii).

 

Step 2. Standards Gap: This gap arises when there is a disparity between management's perceptions and the actual delivery standards established by the service provider. This matches the description in List - II (iv).

 

Step 3. Delivery Gap: This gap occurs when the actual performance ability of the service provider doesn't match the set delivery standards. While this gap is mentioned, it does not have a direct match in List - II, so we'll need to see if it aligns with any of the remaining options.

 

Step 4. Internal Communications Gap: This gap happens when promotional campaigns overpromise by conveying more features, quality, and performance than what the service provider can actually deliver. This aligns with the description in List - II (ii).

 

Step 5. Perceptions Gap: This gap occurs in terms of what is actually delivered and how customers perceive what is delivered. This matches the description in List - II (i).

 

Step 6. Interpretation Gap: This gap occurs when what the service provider promises is interpreted differently by the customers. This matches the description in List - II (iv).

 

Step 7. Service Gap: This is described as a culmination of the other gaps, and it happens when there's a disparity between what the customer expected from the service and how they perceived the eventual service delivery. This doesn't directly match any of the descriptions in List - II, so we'll need to see if it aligns with the remaining options.

 

Based on the analysis, the correct matching is:

 

(a) Standards Gap - (iv) Difference between management's perception of customer expectations and the quality standards established for service delivery

(b) Knowledge Gap - (iii) Difference between what service providers believe customers expect and customers' actual needs and expectations

(c) Perception Gap - (i) Difference between what is, in fact, delivered and what customers perceive they have received

(d) Interpretation Gap - (ii) Difference between what a service provider's communication efforts promise and what a customer thinks were promised by these communications.

Question 58
Which of the following is not included in 7 Ps of services marketing? (UGC NET Management Jun 2010)
  • A.Process
  • B.People
  • C.Pricing
  • D.Public relations
Correct Answer: Public relations

The correct answer is indeed (D) Public relations.

 

The traditional 7 Ps of services marketing are:

1. Product (or Service)

2. Price

3. Place (Distribution)

4. Promotion

5. People

6. Process

7. Physical Evidence

 

"Public relations" is typically not considered one of the 7 Ps but is often a part of the broader promotional efforts and communication strategies within the marketing mix.

Question 59
Match List-I and List-II. (UGC NET Management Jun 2011)List – I (Characteristics of Services)I. IntangibilityII. InseparabilityIII. VariabilityIV. PerishabilityList – II (Marketing Strategy applied considering a characteristic of service)1. Preparing a service blue print showing each service and process in a flow chart.2. Tangiblize the intangible3. To train more service providers and build up client confidence.4. Use differential pricingCode:
  • A.I-2, II- 1, III- 3, IV- 4
  • B.I-2, II-3, III- 1, IV- 4
  • C.I-1, II- 3, III-2, IV- 4
  • D.I- 2, II- 1, III- 4, IV- 3
Correct Answer: I-2, II-3, III- 1, IV- 4

The correct match of Characteristics of Services in List-I with the Marketing Strategy applied considering a characteristic of service in List-II is as follows:

 

I. Intangibility - 2. Tangiblize the intangible

II. Inseparability - 3. To train more service providers and build up client confidence.

III. Variability - 1. Preparing a service blueprint showing each service and process in a flow chart.

IV. Perishability - 4. Use differential pricing

 

I. Intangibility - 2. Tangiblize the intangible:

The characteristic of intangibility refers to the fact that services cannot be touched or seen before purchase. To address this, marketing strategies aim to make the intangible aspects of the service more tangible. Tangiblizing the intangible involves creating physical or visual representations of the service to help customers understand and appreciate it. For example, a luxury spa might provide brochures or videos showcasing the serene environment, experienced staff, and relaxation ambiance to make the service more tangible.

 

II. Inseparability - 3. To train more service providers and build up client confidence:

Inseparability means that services are often produced and consumed simultaneously, and customers are part of the service delivery process. To manage this characteristic, training service providers is crucial to ensure consistent service quality. Building client confidence is also essential, as it helps customers feel more comfortable with the inseparability of the service. For instance, a high-end restaurant may extensively train its waitstaff to provide excellent service and build confidence among diners.

 

III. Variability - 1. Preparing a service blueprint showing each service and process in a flow chart:

Variability indicates that services may differ from one interaction to another due to factors such as employee performance or customer expectations. To address this, companies create service blueprints that outline each step of the service process in a flowchart. This helps standardize service delivery, reducing variability and ensuring a consistent customer experience. Service blueprints are valuable tools for maintaining quality.

 

IV. Perishability - 4. Use differential pricing:

Perishability means that services cannot be stored or inventoried; if not used, they are lost. To manage this characteristic, companies often use differential pricing strategies. These strategies involve adjusting prices based on demand, time, or other factors. For example, airlines may lower prices during off-peak hours to encourage bookings and maximize revenue, addressing the perishability of their services.

 

So, the correct code is I-2, II-3, III-1, IV-4

Question 60
Which of the following indicates "Perishability" aspect of service characteristics? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)
  • A.Customers participate in and affect the transaction.
  • B.Service delivery and customer satisfaction depend on employee actions.
  • C.Customers affect each other.
  • D.It is difficult to synchronize supply and demand with services.
Correct Answer: It is difficult to synchronize supply and demand with services.

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The concept of “perishability” in the context of service characteristics refers to the fact that services are often perishable in nature and cannot be stored for future use. Unlike physical goods, services cannot be produced in advance and kept in inventory. As a result, the supply of services must be closely matched with customer demand in real-time.

 

This makes it difficult to synchronize supply and demand with services, as it requires the service provider to accurately predict and manage customer demand in real-time.

Quiz Attempts 641-650 of 849
